“又是我那件旧的白色的，如果我能把它修好，让大家看到的话，它昨晚就被撕破了，”梅格说，试图轻松地说出来，但感觉很不舒服。

‘Why don’t you send home for another?’ said Sallie, who was not an observing young lady.
“你为什么不回家再找一个呢？”莎莉说道，她不是一个善于观察的年轻女士。

‘I haven’t got any other.’ It cost Meg an effort to say that, but Sallie did not see it and exclaimed in amiable surprise, ‘Only that?’ How funny...’ She did not finish her speech, for Belle shook her head at her and broke in, saying kindly...
“我没有其他的了。”梅格费了好大劲才说出这句话，但莎莉没有看到，她和蔼可亲地惊讶地喊道，“只有这个？”真有趣……”她没有把话说完，因为贝儿对她摇了摇头，插话道，善意地说……

‘Not at all. Where is the use of having a lot of dresses when she isn’t out yet? There’s no need of sending home, Daisy, even if you had a dozen, for I’ve got a sweet blue silk laid away, which I’ve outgrown, and you shall wear it to please me, won’t you, dear?’
'一点也不。还没出门，穿那么多衣服有什么用呢？黛西，即使你有一打，也没有必要送回家，因为我已经准备好了一条甜美的蓝色丝绸，我已经穿不下了，你应该穿着它来取悦我，不是吗，亲爱的？ '

‘You are very kind, but I don’t mind my old dress if you don’t, it does well enough for a little girl like me,’ said Meg.
“你非常友善，但如果你不介意的话，我也不介意我的旧衣服，对于像我这样的小女孩来说，它已经足够好了，”梅格说。

‘Now do let me please myself by dressing you up in style. I admire to do it, and you’d be a regular little beauty with a touch here and there. I shan’t let anyone see you till you are done, and then we’ll burst upon them like Cinderella and her godmother going to the ball,’ said Belle in her persuasive tone.
“现在就让我把你打扮得漂漂亮亮吧，让我自己高兴一下。”我很高兴这样做，你会成为一个普通的小美女，到处都有一点点。在你完成之前我不会让任何人看到你，然后我们就会像灰姑娘和她的教母去参加舞会一样冲向他们。”贝儿用她有说服力的语气说道。

Meg couldn’t refuse the offer so kindly made, for a desire to see if she would be ‘a little beauty’ after touching up caused her to accept and forget all her former uncomfortable feelings toward the Moffats.
梅格无法拒绝如此善意的提议，因为她想看看自己修饰后是否会变得“小美人”，这让她接受并忘记了以前对莫法特夫妇的所有不舒服的感觉。

On the Thursday evening, Belle shut herself up with her maid, and between them they turned Meg into a fine lady. They crimped and curled her hair, they polished her neck and arms with some fragrant powder, touched her lips with coralline salve to make them redder, and Hortense would have added ‘a soupcon of rouge’, if Meg had not rebelled. They laced her into a sky-blue dress, which was so tight she could hardly breathe and so low in the neck that modest Meg blushed at herself in the mirror. A set of silver filagree was added, bracelets, necklace, brooch, and even earrings, for Hortense tied them on with a bit of pink silk which did not show. A cluster of tea-rose buds at the bosom and a ruche, reconciled Meg to the display of her pretty, white shoulders, and a pair of high-heeled silk boots satisfied the last wish of her heart. A lace handkerchief, a plumy fan, and a bouquet in a shoulder holder finished her off, and Miss Belle surveyed her with the satisfaction of a little girl with a newly dressed doll.
星期四晚上，贝拉和她的女仆把自己关起来，她们把梅格变成了一位优雅的女士。他们把她的头发卷曲、卷曲，用一些香粉擦亮她的脖子和手臂，用珊瑚药膏擦她的嘴唇，让它们变得更红，如果梅格没有反抗的话，霍滕斯会加“一碗胭脂汤”。他们给她穿上了一件天蓝色的裙子，这条裙子太紧了，她几乎无法呼吸，而且脖子太低，谦虚的梅格对镜中的自己脸红了。添加了一套银丝，手镯，项链，胸针，甚至耳环，因为霍滕斯用一点粉红色的丝绸将它们绑在了一起，但没有露出来。胸前的一簇茶玫瑰花蕾和褶皱，让梅格调和了自己漂亮白皙的肩膀，一双高跟丝靴满足了她心中最后的愿望。一条花边手帕、一把羽毛扇子和肩托上的一束花就完成了她的收尾工作，贝拉小姐满意地打量着她，就像一个小女孩拿着新穿的洋娃娃一样。

‘Mademoiselle is chatmante, tres jolie, is she not?’ cried Hortense, clasping her hands in an affected rapture.
“小姐是个查曼特，特雷斯·朱莉，不是吗？”霍顿斯喊道，双手紧握，假装狂喜。

‘Come and show yourself,’ said Miss Belle, leading the way to the room where the others were waiting.
“来吧，展示一下自己。”贝尔小姐一边说着，一边领着大家走向其他人正在等待的房间。

As Meg went rustling after, with her long skirts trailing, her earrings tinkling, her curls waving, and her heart beating, she felt as if her fun had really begun at last, for the mirror had plainly told her that she was ‘a little beauty’. Her friends repeated the pleasing phrase enthusiastically, and for several minutes she stood, like a jackdaw in the fable, enjoying her borrowed plumes, while the rest chattered like a party of magpies.
当梅格窸窸窣窣地跟在后面，她的长裙拖着，耳环叮当作响，卷发飘扬，心在跳动，她觉得她的乐趣终于真正开始了，因为镜子清楚地告诉她，她“有点美丽'。她的朋友们热情地重复着这句令人愉悦的短语，她站了几分钟，就像寓言中的寒鸦，享受着借来的羽毛，而其他人则像一群喜鹊一样叽叽喳喳。

‘While I dress, do you drill her, Nan, in the management of her skirt and those French heels, or she will trip herself up. Take your silver butterfly, and catch up that long curl on the left side of her head, Clara, and don’t any of you disturb the charming work of my hands,’ said Belle, as she hurried away, looking well pleased with her success.
“南，当我穿衣服的时候，你会训练她如何管理裙子和法式高跟鞋，否则她会绊倒的。”带上你的银色蝴蝶，抓住她左边头的长卷发，克拉拉，你们谁都别打扰我那迷人的双手，”贝儿一边说，一边匆匆离去，看上去对她很满意。成功。

‘You don’t look a bit like yourself, but you are very nice. I’m nowhere beside you, for Belle has heaps of taste, and you’re quite French, I assure you. Let your flowers hang, don’t be so careful of them, and be sure you don’t trip,’ returned Sallie, trying not to care that Meg was prettier than herself.
‘虽然你看起来不太像你自己，但你人很好。我不在你身边，因为贝尔很有品味，而且你很法国人，我向你保证。让你的花挂起来吧，别太小心它们，确保你不会绊倒。”萨莉回答道，尽量不去在意梅格比她自己漂亮。

Keeping that warning carefully in mind, Margaret got safely downstairs and sailed into the drawing rooms where the Moffats and a few early guests were assembled. She very soon discovered that there is a charm about fine clothes which attracts a certain class of people and secures their respect. Several young ladies, who had taken no notice of her before, were very affectionate all of a sudden. Several young gentlemen, who had only stared at her at the other party, now not only stared, but asked to be introduced, and said all manner of foolish but agreeable things to her, and several old ladies, who sat on the sofas, and criticized the rest of the party, inquired who she was with an air of interest. She heard Mrs. Moffat reply to one of them...
玛格丽特牢记这一警告，安全地下楼，走进莫法夫妇和一些早期客人聚集的客厅。她很快就发现，精美的衣服有一种魅力，可以吸引特定阶层的人并赢得他们的尊重。几个原本没放在心上的小姐，一下子变得十分亲热。刚才对方只盯着她看的几个年轻绅士，现在不但盯着她看，还主动要求介绍，对她说了各种傻话，还说些好听的话，还有几个坐在沙发上的老太太，批评了其他人，饶有兴趣地询问她是谁。她听到莫法特夫人对其中一封的回复……

‘Daisy March—father a colonel in the army—one of our first families, but reverses of fortune, you know; intimate friends of the Laurences; sweet creature, I assure you; my Ned is quite wild about her.’
“黛西·马奇——父亲是陆军上校——我们的第一个家庭，但你知道，时运不济；劳伦斯夫妇的亲密朋友；可爱的生物，我向你保证；我的内德对她非常着迷。

‘Dear me!’ said the old lady, putting up her glass for another observation of Meg, who tried to look as if she had not heard and been rather shocked at Mrs. Moffat’s fibs. The ‘queer feeling’ did not pass away, but she imagined herself acting the new part of fine lady and so got on pretty well, though the tight dress gave her a side-ache, the train kept getting under her feet, and she was in constant fear lest her earrings should fly off and get lost or broken. She was flirting her fan and laughing at the feeble jokes of a young gentleman who tried to be witty, when she suddenly stopped laughing and looked confused, for just opposite, she saw Laurie. He was staring at her with undisguised surprise, and disapproval also, she thought, for though he bowed and smiled, yet something in his honest eyes made her blush and wish she had her old dress on. To complete her confusion, she saw Belle nudge Annie, and both glance from her to Laurie, who, she was happy to see, looked unusually boyish and shy.
“天哪！”老太太说，举起杯子再次观察梅格，梅格试图装出一副没有听到的样子，而且对莫法特太太的谎言感到相当震惊。 “奇怪的感觉”并没有消失，但她想象自己扮演了新的淑女角色，所以相处得很好，尽管紧身连衣裙让她感到侧痛，火车总是从她脚下踩下来，她一直担心她的耳环会飞走、丢失或损坏。她正一边调弄着扇子，一边听着一位年轻绅士故作机智的无力笑话，突然笑不出来，一脸困惑，因为就在对面，她看到了劳里。她想，他正用毫不掩饰的惊讶和不以为然的眼神看着她，因为尽管他鞠躬微笑，但他诚实的眼神中的某些东西让她脸红，希望她能穿上旧衣服。更让她困惑的是，她看到贝儿推了安妮一下，两人的目光都从她身上转向劳里，她很高兴看到劳里看起来异常孩子气和害羞。

‘Silly creatures, to put such thoughts into my head. I won’t care for it, or let it change me a bit,’ thought Meg, and rustled across the room to shake hands with her friend.
‘愚蠢的生物，竟然把这样的想法塞进我的脑子里。我不会在意它，或者让它改变我一点，”梅格想，然后沙沙地穿过房间与她的朋友握手。

‘I’m glad you came, I was afraid you wouldn’t.’ she said, with her most grown-up air.
“我很高兴你来了，我担心你不会来。”她带着最成熟的神气说道。

‘Jo wanted me to come, and tell her how you looked, so I did,’ answered Laurie, without turning his eyes upon her, though he half smiled at her maternal tone.
“乔想让我过去，告诉她你的样子，所以我就这么做了。”劳里回答道，眼睛没有转向她，但对她母亲般的语气微微一笑。

‘What shall you tell her?’ asked Meg, full of curiosity to know his opinion of her, yet feeling ill at ease with him for the first time.
“你要告诉她什么？”梅格问道，她充满好奇地想知道他对她的看法，但第一次对他感到不自在。

‘I shall say I didn’t know you, for you look so grown-up and unlike yourself, I’m quite afraid of you,’ he said, fumbling at his glove button.
“我得说我不认识你，因为你看起来那么大人，不像你自己，我很害怕你，”他一边说，一边摸索着手套上的纽扣。

‘How absurd of you! The girls dressed me up for fun, and I rather like it. Wouldn’t Jo stare if she saw me?’ said Meg, bent on making him say whether he thought her improved or not. ‘Yes, I think she would,’ returned Laurie gravely.
‘你真荒唐！女孩们给我打扮得很有趣，我很喜欢。如果乔看到我，她不会盯着我看吗？”梅格说道，一心想让他说出他是否认为她有所进步。 “是的，我想她会的，”劳里严肃地回答道。

‘Don’t you like me so?’ asked Meg.
“你不那么喜欢我吗？”梅格问。

‘No, I don’t,’ was the blunt reply.
“不，我不，”他直率地回答。

‘Why not?’ in an anxious tone.
“为什么不呢？”语气焦急。

He glanced at her frizzled head, bare shoulders, and fantastically trimmed dress with an expression that abashed her more than his answer, which had not particle of his usual politeness in it.
他瞥了一眼她的卷发头、裸露的肩膀和剪裁精美的裙子，他的表情比他的回答更令她羞愧，他的回答完全没有他平时的礼貌。

‘I don’t like fuss and feathers.’
“我不喜欢大惊小怪和羽毛。”

That was altogether too much from a lad younger than herself, and Meg walked away, saying petulantly, ‘You are the rudest boy I ever saw.’
对于一个比她年轻的小伙子来说，这实在是太过分了，梅格走开了，脾气暴躁地说，“你是我见过的最粗鲁的男孩。”

Feeling very much ruffled, she went and stood at a quiet window to cool her cheeks, for the tight dress gave her an uncomfortably brilliant color. As she stood there, Major Lincoln passed by, and a minute after she heard him saying to his mother...
她感到非常烦躁，走到一扇安静的窗前站着凉凉脸颊，因为紧身连衣裙给她带来了一种令人不舒服的艳丽色彩。当她站在那里时，林肯少校经过，一分钟后她听到他对他的母亲说……

‘They are making a fool of that little girl. I wanted you to see her, but they have spoiled her entirely. She’s nothing but a doll tonight.’
‘他们在愚弄那个小女孩。我想让你见见她，但他们已经把她彻底宠坏了。今晚她只不过是一个洋娃娃。”

‘Oh, dear!’ sighed Meg. ‘I wish I’d been sensible and worn my own things, then I should not have disgusted other people, or felt so uncomfortable and ashamed of myself.’
“哦，天哪！”梅格叹了口气。 “我希望我当时是明智的，穿自己的东西，那么我就不应该让其他人感到厌恶，或者对自己感到如此不舒服和羞耻。”

She leaned her forehead on the cool pane, and stood half hidden by the curtains, never minding that her favorite waltz had begun, till some one touched her, and turning, she saw Laurie, looking penitent, as he said, with his very best bow and his hand out...
她把额头靠在凉爽的窗玻璃上，站在半遮着窗帘的地方，全然不顾她最喜欢的华尔兹已经开始，直到有人碰了碰她，转过身来，她看到劳里，正如他所说，一脸忏悔，带着他最好的样子。鞠躬，伸出手……

‘Please forgive my rudeness, and come and dance with me.’
“请原谅我的无礼，来和我跳舞吧。”

‘I’m afraid it will be to disagreeable to you,’ said Meg, trying to look offended and failing entirely.
“我担心这会让你不舒服，”梅格说，试图表现出被冒犯的样子，但完全失败了。

‘Not a bit of it, I’m dying to do it. Come, I’ll be good. I don’t like your gown, but I do think you are just splendid.’ And he waved his hands, as if words failed to express his admiration.
‘一点也不，我很想这么做。来吧，我会很好的。我不喜欢你的礼服，但我确实觉得你很漂亮。”他挥了挥手，仿佛言语无法表达他的钦佩。

Meg smiled and relented, and whispered as they stood waiting to catch the time, ‘Take care my skirt doesn’t trip you up. It’s the plague of my life and I was a goose to wear it.’
梅格微笑着，态度软化了，在他们站着等待时机时低声说道：“小心我的裙子别绊倒你。”这是我一生的瘟疫，而我戴上它真是太蠢了。”

‘Pin it round your neck, and then it will be useful,’ said Laurie, looking down at the little blue boots, which he evidently approved of. Away they went fleetly and gracefully, for having practiced at home, they were well matched, and the blithe young couple were a pleasant sight to see, as they twirled merrily round and round, feeling more friendly than ever after their small tiff.
“把它别在你脖子上，这样就会有用了，”劳里低头看着那双蓝色小靴子说道，显然他很喜欢这双靴子。他们走得轻快而优雅，因为在家里练习过，他们很般配，这对快乐的年轻夫妇令人赏心悦目，他们欢快地转了一圈又一圈，小争执之后感觉比以往任何时候都友好。

‘Laurie, I want you to do me a favor, will you?’ said Meg, as he stood fanning her when her breath gave out, which it did very soon though she would not own why.
“劳里，我想让你帮我一个忙，可以吗？”梅格说，当她喘不过气来时，他站在那里给她扇风，很快就喘不过气来了，尽管她不知道为什么。

‘Won’t I!’ said Laurie, with alacrity.
“我不会！”劳里高兴地说。

‘Please don’t tell them at home about my dress tonight. They won’t understand the joke, and it will worry Mother.’
“请不要在家里告诉他们我今晚穿的衣服。他们听不懂这个笑话，这会让妈妈担心。”

‘Then why did you do it?’ said Laurie’s eyes, so plainly that Meg hastily added...
“那你为什么要这么做？”劳里的眼神如此直白，梅格赶紧补充道……

‘I shall tell them myself all about it, and ‘fess’ to Mother how silly I’ve been. But I’d rather do it myself. So you’ll not tell, will you?’
“我会亲自告诉他们这一切，并向母亲‘承认’我是多么愚蠢。但我宁愿自己做。所以你不会说出来，是吗？

‘I give you my word I won’t, only what shall I say when they ask me?’
“我向你保证我不会，只是当他们问我时我该怎么说？”

‘Just say I looked pretty well and was having a good time.’
“只是说我看起来很好而且玩得很开心。”

‘I’ll say the first with all my heart, but how about the other? You don’t look as if you were having a good time. Are you?’ And Laurie looked at her with an expression which made her answer in a whisper...
“我会全心全意地说第一个，但是另一个呢？你看起来好像过得不太开心。你是吗？”劳里看着她，她的表情让她低声回答……

‘No, not just now. Don’t think I’m horrid. I only wanted a little fun, but this sort doesn’t pay, I find, and I’m getting tired of it.’
‘不，不只是现在。别以为我很可怕。我只想找点乐子，但我发现这种做法并没有什么回报，而且我已经厌倦了。”

‘Here comes Ned Moffat. What does he want?’ said Laurie, knitting his black brows as if he did not regard his young host in the light of a pleasant addition to the party.
“内德·莫法特来了。 “他想要什么？”劳里皱着眉头说道，好像他并没有把这位年轻的主人视为聚会中的一个令人愉快的成员。

‘He put his name down for three dances, and I suppose he’s coming for them. What a bore!’ said Meg, assuming a languid air which amused Laurie immensely.
“他为三场舞会写下了自己的名字，我想他一定会来参加的。真是无聊啊！”梅格一副无精打采的样子说道，这让劳里觉得好笑。

He did not speak to her again till suppertime, when he saw her drinking champagne with Ned and his friend Fisher, who were behaving ‘like a pair of fools’, as Laurie said to himself, for he felt a brotherly sort of right to watch over the Marches and fight their battles whenever a defender was needed.
直到晚饭时间，他才再次和她说话，当时他看到她和奈德以及他的朋友费舍尔一起喝香槟，正如劳里对自己说的那样，他们的行为“就像一对傻瓜”，因为他觉得有一种兄弟般的权利来观看。在行军上空，并在需要防守者时进行战斗。

‘You’ll have a splitting headache tomorrow, if you drink much of that. I wouldn’t, Meg, your mother doesn’t like it, you know,’ he whispered, leaning over her chair, as Ned turned to refill her glass and Fisher stooped to pick up her fan.
“如果你喝太多的话，明天你会头痛欲裂。”我不会，梅格，你知道，你妈妈不喜欢这样，”他靠在她的椅子上低声说道，这时内德转身给她倒酒，费舍尔弯腰拿起她的扇子。

‘I’m not Meg tonight, I’m ‘a doll’ who does all sorts of crazy things. Tomorrow I shall put away my ‘fuss and feathers’ and be desperately good again,’ se answered with an affected little laugh.
“今晚我不是梅格，我是一个做各种疯狂事情的​​‘洋娃娃’。明天我就会收起我的‘大惊小怪’，再次表现得非常好。”瑟假装笑道。

‘Wish tomorrow was here, then,’ muttered Laurie, walking off, ill-pleased at the change he saw in her.
“那么，希望明天就在这里。”劳里低声说道，走开，对他在她身上看到的变化感到不满。

Meg danced and flirted, chattered and giggled, as the other girls did. After supper she undertook the German, and blundered through it, nearly upsetting her partner with her long skirt, and romping in a way that scandalized Laurie, who looked on and meditated a lecture. But he got no chance to deliver it, for Meg kept away from him till he came to say good night.
梅格和其他女孩一样跳舞、调情、喋喋不休、咯咯笑。晚饭后，她开始学德语，结果跌跌撞撞，她的长裙差点惹恼了她的搭档，而且嬉戏的方式让劳里感到震惊，劳里在一旁观看并沉思着一场讲座。但他没有机会把它送出去，因为梅格一直远离他，直到他过来道晚安。

‘Remember!’ she said, trying to smile, for the splitting headache had already begun.
“记住！”她努力微笑着说道，因为头痛已经开始了。

‘Silence a‘ la mort,’ replied Laurie, with a melodramatic flourish, as he went away.
“死时保持沉默，”劳里在离开时用夸张的夸张语气回答道。

This little bit of byplay excited Annie’s curiosity, but Meg was too tired for gossip and went to bed, feeling as if she had been to a masquerade and hadn’t enjoyed herself as much as she expected. She was sick all the next day, and on Saturday went home, quite used up with her fortnight’s fun and feeling that she had ‘sat in the lap of luxury’ long enough.
这个小插曲激起了安妮的好奇心，但梅格太累了，不想再闲聊，就上床睡觉了，感觉自己好像参加了一场化装舞会，并没有像她想象的那样玩得开心。第二天她一整天都在生病，周六回家了，两周的乐趣让她精疲力尽，感觉自己“坐在奢华的腿上”已经够久了。

‘It does seem pleasant to be quiet, and not have company manners on all the time. Home is a nice place, though it isn’t splendid,’ said Meg, looking about her with a restful expression, as she sat with her mother and Jo on the Sunday evening.
“保持安静、不总是表现出公司礼仪似乎确实令人愉快。周日晚上，梅格与母亲和乔坐在一起，用一种平静的表情环顾四周，说道：“家是一个好地方，尽管并不华丽。”

‘I’m glad to hear you say so, dear, for I was afraid home would seem dull and poor to you after your fine quarters,’ replied her mother, who had given her many anxious looks that day. For motherly eyes are quick to see any change in children’s faces.
“我很高兴听到你这么说，亲爱的，因为我担心在你美好的住所之后，你的家会显得沉闷和贫穷，”她的母亲回答道，那天她向她投来了许多焦虑的目光。因为母亲的眼睛很快就能看到孩子脸上的任何变化。

Meg had told her adventures gayly and said over and over what a charming time she had had, but something still seemed to weigh upon her spirits, and when the younger girls were gone to bed, she sat thoughtfully staring at the fire, saying little and looking worried. As the clock struck nine and Jo proposed bed, Meg suddenly left her chair and, taking Beth’s stool, leaned her elbows on her mother’s knee, saying bravely...
梅格兴高采烈地讲述了她的冒险经历，一遍又一遍地说她度过了多么愉快的时光，但似乎仍然有什么东西压在她的精神上，当年轻的女孩们上床睡觉时，她若有所思地坐在那儿，盯着火，很少说话，也没有说话。看起来很担心。当时钟敲响九点，乔提议上床睡觉时，梅格突然离开椅子，拿起贝丝的凳子，把胳膊肘靠在母亲的膝盖上，勇敢地说……

‘Marmee, I want to ‘fess’.’
“妈妈，我想‘坦白’。”

‘I thought so. What is it, dear?’
'我是这么想的。亲爱的，这是什么？

‘Shall I go away?’ asked Jo discreetly.
“我要走吗？”乔小心翼翼地问道。

‘Of course not. Don’t I always tell you everything? I was ashamed to speak of it before the younger children, but I want you to know all the dreadful things I did at the Moffats’.’
'当然不是。我不是总是告诉你一切吗？我羞于在年幼的孩子们面前谈论这件事，但我想让你们知道我在莫法茨家所做的所有可怕的事情。

‘We are prepared,’ said Mrs. March, smiling but looking a little anxious.
“我们已经准备好了，”马奇夫人微笑着说，但看上去有点焦虑。

‘I told you they dressed me up, but I didn’t tell you that they powdered and squeezed and frizzled, and made me look like a fashion plate. Laurie thought I wasn’t proper. I know he did, though he didn’t say so, and one man called me ‘a doll’. I knew it was silly, but they flattered me and said I was a beauty, and quantities of nonsense, so I let them make a fool of me.’
“我告诉过你它们给我打扮得漂漂亮亮，但我没告诉过你它们给我扑粉、挤压、卷曲，让我看起来像一个时装盘。”劳里认为我不合适。我知道他做到了，尽管他没有这么说，还有一个人称我为“洋娃娃”。我知道这很傻，但他们却奉承我，说我是个美人，还废话一大堆，我就让他们愚弄我了。

‘Is that all?’ asked Jo, as Mrs. March looked silently at the downcast face of her pretty daughter, and could not find it in her heart to blame her little follies.
“就这些吗？”乔问道，马奇太太默默地看着她漂亮女儿那张沮丧的脸，心里找不到责怪她的小愚蠢行为。

‘No, I drank champagne and romped and tried to flirt, and was altogether abominable,’ said Meg self-reproachfully.
“不，我喝香槟，嬉闹，试图调情，真是令人厌恶，”梅格自责地说。

‘There is something more, I think.’ And Mrs. March smoothed the soft cheek, which suddenly grew rosy as Meg answered slowly...
“我想，还有更多的事情。”马奇太太抚平柔软的脸颊，梅格慢慢地回答，脸颊突然变得红润……

‘Yes. It’s very silly, but I want to tell it, because I hate to have people say and think such things about us and Laurie.’
'是的。这很愚蠢，但我想把它说出来，因为我讨厌人们对我们和劳里说这样的话、这样想。

Then she told the various bits of gossip she had heard at the Moffats’, and as she spoke, Jo saw her mother fold her lips tightly, as if ill pleased that such ideas should be put into Meg’s innocent mind.
然后她讲述了她在莫法茨家听到的各种八卦，当她说话时，乔看到她母亲紧紧地闭着嘴唇，似乎很高兴梅格天真的脑子里灌输了这些想法。

‘Well, if that isn’t the greatest rubbish I ever heard,’ cried Jo indignantly. ‘Why didn’t you pop out and tell them so on the spot?’
“好吧，如果这不是我听过的最糟糕的废话，”乔愤怒地喊道。 “你为什么不当场跳出来告诉他们呢？”

‘I couldn’t, it was so embarrassing for me. I couldn’t help hearing at first, and then I was so angry and ashamed, I didn’t remember that I ought to go away.’
“我不能，这对我来说太尴尬了。我一开始忍不住听了，然后我又生气又羞愧，我不记得我应该走开。

‘Just wait till I see Annie Moffat, and I’ll show you how to settle such ridiculous stuff. The idea of having ‘plans’ and being kind to Laurie because he’s rich and may marry us by-and-by! Won’t he shout when I tell him what those silly things say about us poor children?’ And Jo laughed, as if on second thoughts the thing struck her as a good joke.
“等我见到安妮·莫法特，我会告诉你如何解决这些荒谬的事情。有“计划”并善待劳里的想法，因为他很有钱，可能很快就会嫁给我们！当我告诉他那些愚蠢的事情对我们可怜的孩子的评价时，他会不会大喊大叫？”乔笑了，仿佛转念一想，这件事让她觉得这是一个很好的笑话。

‘If you tell Laurie, I’ll never forgive you! She mustn’t, must she, Mother?’ said Meg, looking distressed.
“如果你告诉劳里，我永远不会原谅你！” “妈妈，她一定不能这样吗？”梅格一脸苦恼地说。

‘No, never repeat that foolish gossip, and forget it as soon as you can,’ said Mrs. March gravely. ‘I was very unwise to let you go among people of whom I know so little, kind, I dare say, but worldly, ill-bred, and full of these vulgar ideas about young people. I am more sorry than I can express for the mischief this visit may have done you, Meg.’
“不，永远不要再重复这种愚蠢的流言蜚语，并且尽快忘记它，”马奇太太严肃地说。 “我很不明智地让你去和那些我认识甚少的人在一起，我敢说，他们很友善，但很世俗，没有教养，对年轻人充满了这些粗俗的想法。对于这次访问可能给你带来的伤害，我感到非常抱歉，梅格。

‘Don’t be sorry, I won’t let it hurt me. I’ll forget all the bad and remember only the good, for I did enjoy a great deal, and thank you very much for letting me go. I’ll not be sentimental or dissatisfied, Mother. I know I’m a silly little girl, and I’ll stay with you till I’m fit to take care of myself. But it is nice to be praised and admired, and I can’t help saying I like it,’ said Meg, looking half ashamed of the confession.
‘别抱歉，我不会让它伤害我。我会忘记所有不好的事情，只记得好的事情，因为我确实享受了很多，非常感谢你让我离开。我不会多愁善感或不满意，母亲。我知道我是一个愚蠢的小女孩，我会一直陪着你，直到我能够照顾自己。但受到赞扬和钦佩真是太好了，我情不自禁地说我喜欢这样。”梅格说道，看上去对自己的坦白感到有些羞愧。

‘That is perfectly natural, and quite harmless, if the liking does not become a passion and lead one to do foolish or unmaidenly things. Learn to know and value the praise which is worth having, and to excite the admiration of excellent people by being modest as well as pretty, Meg.’
“如果这种喜好不会变成一种激情并导致人们做出愚蠢或不成熟的事情，那是完全自然的，而且完全无害。梅格，要学会认识并珍惜值得拥有的赞美，并通过谦虚和漂亮来激发优秀人士的钦佩。

Margaret sat thinking a moment, while Jo stood with her hands behind her, looking both interested and a little perplexed, for it was a new thing to see Meg blushing and talking about admiration, lovers, and things of that sort. And Jo felt as if during that fortnight her sister had grown up amazingly, and was drifting away from her into a world where she could not follow.
玛格丽特坐在那里想了一会儿，而乔双手放在身后站着，看上去既感兴趣又有点困惑，因为看到梅格脸红着谈论钦佩、爱人之类的事情是一件新鲜事。乔觉得在那两周里，她的妹妹似乎惊人地长大了，并且正在远离她，进入一个她无法跟随的世界。

‘Mother, do you have ‘plans’, as Mrs. Moffat said?’ asked Meg bashfully.
“妈妈，你有莫法特夫人说的‘计划’吗？”梅格害羞地问。

‘Yes, my dear, I have a great many, all mothers do, but mine differ somewhat from Mrs. Moffat’s, I suspect. I will tell you some of them, for the time has come when a word may set this romantic little head and heart of yours right, on a very serious subject. You are young, Meg, but not too young to understand me, and mothers’ lips are the fittest to speak of such things to girls like you. Jo, your turn will come in time, perhaps, so listen to my ‘plans’ and help me carry them out, if they are good.’
“是的，亲爱的，我有很多，所有母亲都有，但我怀疑我的和莫法特夫人的有些不同。”我会告诉你其中的一些，因为现在已经到了，一句话就能让你这个浪漫的小头脑和心灵在一个非常严肃的话题上得到正确的认识。梅格，你很年轻，但也不算小到无法理解我，而母亲的嘴唇最适合对像你这样的女孩谈论这些事情。乔，也许很快就会轮到你了，所以听听我的‘计划’，如果计划不错的话，帮我实现它们。”

Jo went and sat on one arm of the chair, looking as if she thought they were about to join in some very solemn affair. Holding a hand of each, and watching the two young faces wistfully, Mrs. March said, in her serious yet cheery way...
乔走到椅子的一只扶手上坐下，看上去好像她认为他们即将参加一场非常庄严的活动。马奇太太握着两人的手，若有所思地看着两张年轻的脸，严肃而愉快地说道……

‘I want my daughters to be beautiful, accomplished, and good. To be admired, loved, and respected. To have a happy youth, to be well and wisely married, and to lead useful, pleasant lives, with as little care and sorrow to try them as God sees fit to send. To be loved and chosen by a good man is the best and sweetest thing which can happen to a woman, and I sincerely hope my girls may know this beautiful experience. It is natural to think of it, Meg, right to hope and wait for it, and wise to prepare for it, so that when the happy time comes, you may feel ready for the duties and worthy of the joy. My dear girls, I am ambitious for you, but not to have you make a dash in the world, marry rich men merely because they are rich, or have splendid houses, which are not homes because love is wanting. Money is a needful and precious thing, and when well used, a noble thing, but I never want you to think it is the first or only prize to strive for. I’d rather see you poor men’s wives, if you were happy, beloved, contented, than queens on thrones, without self-respect and peace.’
“我希望我的女儿们美丽、多才多艺、善良。被人钦佩、被爱戴、被尊重。拥有一个幸福的青春，拥有美好而明智的婚姻，过着有益而愉快的生活，在上帝认为合适的情况下，尽量少地关心和悲伤地尝试这些生活。被一个好男人所爱和选择是一个女人能遇到的最好、最甜蜜的事情，我真诚地希望我的女儿们能知道这种美好的经历。梅格，想到这一点是很自然的，希望和等待它是正确的，为它做好准备是明智的，这样当幸福的时刻到来时，你可能会觉得自己已经准备好承担责任，值得享受快乐。亲爱的姑娘们，我对你们有雄心壮志，但不是让你们闯天下，仅仅因为有钱就嫁给有钱人，或者拥有豪华的房子，但因为缺少爱而不是家。金钱是一种必需且珍贵的东西，如果使用得当，它是一种高贵的东西，但我绝不希望你认为它是奋斗的第一个或唯一的奖品。我宁愿看到你们是穷人的妻子，如果你们幸福、受人爱戴、心满意足，也不愿看到你们是没有自尊与平静的王位上的女王。

‘Poor girls don’t stand any chance, Belle says, unless they put themselves forward,’ sighed Meg.
“贝尔说，可怜的女孩没有任何机会，除非她们挺身而出，”梅格叹息道。

‘Then we’ll be old maids,’ said Jo stoutly. ‘right, Jo. Better be happy old maids than unhappy wives, or unmaidenly girls, running about to find husbands,’ said Mrs. March decidedly. ‘Don’t be troubled, Meg, poverty seldom daunts a sincere lover. Some of the best and most honored women I know were poor girls, but so love-worthy that they were not allowed to be old maids. Leave these things to time. Make this home happy, so that you may be fit for homes of your own, if they are offered you, and contented here if they are not. One thing remember, my girls. Mother is always ready to be your confidante, Father to be your friend, and both of hope and trust that our daughters, whether married or single, will be the pride and comfort of out lives.’
“那我们就当老处女了。”乔坚定地说。 “对了，乔。最好是做快乐的老处女，而不是做不快乐的妻子，或者是四处寻找丈夫的不成熟的女孩。”马奇夫人斩钉截铁地说。 “别担心，梅格，贫穷很少能吓倒真诚的爱人。我认识的一些最优秀、最受尊敬的女性都是贫穷的女孩，但她们非常值得爱，以至于她们不被允许当老处女。这些事情就交给时间吧。让这个家变得幸福，这样，如果有人为你提供了自己的家，你就可以适应；如果没有，你也可以在这里感到满足。记住一件事，我的女儿们。母亲随时准备成为您的红颜知己，父亲随时准备成为您的朋友，并且希望并相信我们的女儿，无论已婚还是单身，都将成为我们生活的骄傲和安慰。

‘We will, Marmee, we will!’ cried both, with all their hearts, as she bade them good night.
“我们会的，妈妈，我们会的！”当她向他们道晚安时，两人全心全意地喊道。

CHAPTER TEN
第十章

As spring came on, a new set of amusements became the fashion, and the lengthening days gave long afternoons for work and play of all sorts. The garden had to be put in order, and each sister had a quarter of the little plot to do what she liked with. Hannah used to say, ‘I’d know which each of them gardings belonged to, ef I see ‘em in Chiny,’ and so she might, for the girls’ tastes differed as much as their characters. Meg’s had roses and heliotrope, myrtle, and a little orange tree in it. Jo’s bed was never alike two seasons, for she was always trying experiments. This year it was to be a plantation of sun flowers, the seeds of which cheerful land aspiring plant were to feed Aunt Cockle-top and her family of chicks. Beth had old-fashioned fragrant flowers in her garden, sweet peas and mignonette, larkspur, pinks, pansies, and southernwood, with chickweed for the birds and catnip for the pussies. Amy had a bower in hers, rather small and earwiggy, but very pretty to look at, with honeysuckle and morning-glories hanging their colored horns and bells in graceful wreaths all over it, tall white lilies, delicate ferns, and as many brilliant, picturesque plants as would consent to blossom there.
随着春天的到来，一系列新的娱乐活动成为时尚，白天的延长为各种工作和娱乐提供了漫长的下午。花园必须整理得井井有条，每个姐妹都有四分之一的小地可以做她喜欢做的事。汉娜常常说，“如果我在中国看到它们，我就会知道它们属于哪一个，”她可能会这样，因为女孩们的品味和她们的性格一样不同。梅格的花园里有玫瑰、天芥菜、桃金娘和一棵小橙树。乔的床在两个季节里从来都不一样，因为她总是在尝试实验。今年，这里将成为一个向日葵种植园，这些向往陆地的植物的种子将用来喂养科克托普阿姨和她的小鸡一家人。贝丝的花园里种着老式的芳香花卉，有甜豌豆、木犀草、飞燕草、粉红花、三色堇和南木，还有繁缕给小鸟用，猫薄荷给小猫用。艾米的房间里有一个凉亭，相当小，耳垂，但看起来非常漂亮，金银花和牵牛花挂满了彩色的喇叭和铃铛，在优雅的花环上到处都是，高大的白色百合花，精致的蕨类植物，还有许多灿烂的，风景如画的植物愿意在那里开花。

Gardening, walks, rows on the river, and flower hunts employed the fine days, and for rainy ones, they had house diversions, some old, some new, all more or less original. One of these was the ‘P.C’, for as secret societies were the fashion, it was thought proper to have one, and as all of the girls admired Dickens, they called themselves the Pickwick Club. With a few interruptions, they had kept this up for a year, and met every Saturday evening in the big garret, on which occasions the ceremonies were as follows: Three chairs were arranged in a row before a table on which was a lamp, also four white badges, with a big ‘P.C.’ in different colors on each, and the weekly newspaper called, The Pickwick Portfolio, to which all contributed something, while Jo, who reveled in pens and ink, was the editor. At seven o’clock, the four members ascended to the clubroom, tied their badges round their heads, and took their seats with great solemnity. Meg, as the eldest, was Samuel Pickwick, Jo, being of a literary turn, Augustus Snodgrass, Beth, because she was round and rosy, Tracy Tupman, and Amy, who was always trying to do what she couldn’t, was Nathaniel Winkle. Pickwick, the president, read the paper, which was filled with original tales, poetry, local news, funny advertisements, and hints, in which they good-naturedly reminded each other of their faults and short comings. On one occasion, Mr. Pickwick put on a pair of spectacles without any glass, rapped upon the table, hemmed, and having stared hard at Mr. Snodgrass, who was tilting back in his chair, till he arranged himself properly, began to read:
天气晴朗时，他们会做园艺、散步、在河上划船、采花，而在下雨天，他们会进行一些房屋消遣，有的旧的，有的新的，或多或少都是原创的。其中之一就是“P.C”，因为秘密结社很流行，因此人们认为拥有一个是合适的，而且由于所有的女孩都崇拜狄更斯，所以她们称自己为“匹克威克俱乐部”。中间有几次中断，他们就这样维持了一年，每周六晚上都在大阁楼里聚会，每次的仪式如下：三把椅子排成一排，桌子前放着一盏灯，还有一张桌子。四个白色徽章，每个徽章上都有一个不同颜色的大“P.C”，周报名为《匹克威克组合》，所有人都对此做出了贡献，而陶醉于钢笔和墨水的乔是编辑。七点钟，四位会员登上俱乐部会议室，将徽章戴在头上，庄严地入座。梅格是长女塞缪尔·匹克威克，乔是一位文学家，奥古斯塔斯·斯诺德格拉斯，贝丝是因为她圆润而红润，特蕾西·图普曼，而艾米则是纳撒尼尔，她总是试图做她做不到的事情温克尔。总统匹克威克读了报纸，报纸上充满了原创故事、诗歌、当地新闻、有趣的广告和暗示，他们善意地互相提醒对方的缺点和缺点。有一次，匹克威克先生戴上一副没有镜片的眼镜，敲打着桌子，缝好边缘，死死地盯着靠在椅子上的斯诺德格拉斯先生，直到他调整好自己的姿势，开始读书。 :

‘THE PICKWICK PORTFOLIO&#x2019
“匹克威克组合”2019


MAY 20, 18—-
2018 年 5 月 20 日——


POET’S CORNER
诗人之角


ANNIVERSARY ODE
周年颂歌


Again we meet to celebrate
我们再次相聚庆祝

With badge and solemn rite,
带着徽章和庄严的仪式，

Our fifty-second anniversary,
我们五十二周年纪念日，

In Pickwick Hall, tonight.
今晚在匹克威克庄园。


We all are here in perfect health,
我们都健康地在这里，

None gone from our small band:
我们的小乐队没有消失：

Again we see each well-known face,
我们再次看到每一张熟悉的面孔，

And press each friendly hand.
并按下每只友好的手。


Our Pickwick, always at his post,
我们的匹克威克，永远坚守岗位，

With reverence we greet,
我们怀着崇敬的心情迎接，

As, spectacles on nose, he reads
当他鼻子上戴着眼镜时，他读到

Our well-filled weekly sheet.
我们的每周工作表填得满满的。


Although he suffers from a cold,
尽管他患有感冒，

We joy to hear him speak,
我们很高兴听到他讲话，

For words of wisdom from him fall,
因为他的智慧言语落下，

In spite of croak or squeak.
尽管有嘎嘎声或吱吱声。


Old six-foot Snodgrass looms on high,
老六英尺高的斯诺德格拉斯高高耸立，

With elephantine grace,
带着大象般的优雅，

And beams upon the company,
并照耀着公司，

With brown and jovial face.
有着棕色而快乐的脸。


Poetic fire lights up his eye,
诗意的火焰照亮了他的眼睛，

He struggles ‘gainst his lot.
他努力“争取自己的命运”。

Behold ambition on his brow,
看他额头上的野心，

And on his nose, a blot.
在他的鼻子上，有一个污点。

Next our peaceful Tupman comes,
接下来我们平静的图普曼来了，

So rosy, plump, and sweet,
那么红润、饱满、甜美，

Who chokes with laughter at the puns,
谁因双关语而笑得窒息，

And tumbles off his seat.
然后从座位上摔下来。


Prim little Winkle too is here,
古板的小温克尔也在这里，

With every hair in place,
每根头发都到位后，

A model of propriety,
礼仪之邦的典范，

Though he hates to wash his face.
虽然他讨厌洗脸。

The year is gone, we still unite
年已过去，我们依然团结

To joke and laugh and read,
开玩笑、大笑、读书，

And tread the path of literature
并踏上文学之路

That doth to glory lead.
这确实会带来荣耀。

Long may our paper prosper well,
祝我们的报纸繁荣昌盛，

Our club unbroken be,
我们的俱乐部不间断，

And coming years their blessings pour
未来的岁月里，他们的祝福倾泻而下

On the useful, gay ‘P. C.’.
关于有用的同性恋“P”。 C。'。

A. SNODGRASS
A·斯诺德格拉斯

THE MASKED MARRIAGE
假面婚姻

(A Tale Of Venice)
（威尼斯故事）

Gondola after gondola swept up to the marble steps, and left its lovely load to swell the brilliant throng that filled the stately halls of Count Adelon. Knights and ladies, elves and pages, monks and flower girls, all mingled gaily in the dance. Sweet voices and rich melody filled the air, and so with mirth and music the masquerade went on. ‘Has your Highness seen the Lady viola tonight?’ asked a gallant troubadour of the fairy queen who floated down the hall upon his arm. ‘Yes, is she not lovely, though so sad! Her dress is well chosen, too, for in a week she weds Count Antonio, whom she passionately hates.’
一艘又一艘的贡多拉驶向大理石台阶，留下可爱的货物，让阿德隆伯爵庄严的大厅里挤满了光彩夺目的人群。骑士和贵妇、精灵和侍童、僧侣和花童，所有人都欢快地参与到舞蹈中。甜美的歌声和丰富的旋律弥漫在空气中，化装舞会在欢乐和音乐中继续进行。 “殿下今晚见到维奥拉女士了吗？”一位英勇的吟游诗人问道，仙后挽着他的手臂飘过大厅。 “是的，虽然她很悲伤，但她不是很可爱吗！”她的衣服也选得很好，因为一周后她就嫁给了她非常讨厌的安东尼奥伯爵。

‘By my faith, I envy him. Yonder he comes, arrayed like a bridegroom, except the black mask. When that is off we shall see how he regards the fair maid whose heart he cannot win, though her stern father bestows her hand,’ returned the troubadour.
‘凭我的信心，我很羡慕他。他来到了那边，除了戴着黑色面具外，他的打扮就像新郎一样。当那件事结束时，我们将看看他如何看待这位美丽的少女，尽管她严厉的父亲向她伸出了援助之手，但他无法赢得她的心。”吟游诗人回答道。

‘Tis whispered that she loves the young English artist who haunts her steps, and is spurned by the old Count,’ said the lady, as they joined the dance. The revel was at its height when a priest appeared, and withdrawing the young pair to an alcove, hung with purple velvet, he motioned them to kneel. Instant silence fell on the gay throng, and not a sound, but he dash of fountains or the rustle of orange groves sleeping in the moonlight, broke the hush, as Count de Adelon spoke thus:
“有传言说，她爱上了那位萦绕在她脚下的年轻英国艺术家，却被老伯爵拒绝了。”当他们加入舞会时，这位女士说道。当一位牧师出现时，狂欢达到了高潮，他把这对年轻人带到一个挂着紫色天鹅绒的壁龛里，示意他们跪下。欢乐的人群立刻鸦雀无声，没有任何声音，但喷泉的喷水声或月光下熟睡的橘子林的沙沙声打破了寂静，阿德隆伯爵这样说道：

‘My lords and ladies, pardon the ruse by which I have gathered you here to witness the marriage of my daughter. Father, we wait your services.’ All eyes turned toward the bridal party, and a murmur of amazement went through the throng, for neither bride nor groom removed their masks. Curiosity and wonder possessed all hearts, but respect restrained all tongues till the holy rite was over. Then the eager spectators gathered round the count, demanding an explanation.
“各位大人，各位女士，请原谅我把你们聚集到这里来见证我女儿的婚礼的诡计。父亲，我们等待您的服务。”所有的目光都转向新娘队伍，人群中传出一阵惊讶的低语，因为新娘和新郎都没有摘下面具。好奇心和惊奇占据了所有人的心，但尊重抑制了所有人的舌头，直到神圣的仪式结束。然后热切的观众聚集在伯爵周围，要求作出解释。

‘Gladly would I give it if I could, but I only know that it was the whim of my timid Viola, and I yielded to it. Now, my children, let the play end. Unmask and receive my blessing.’
“如果可以的话，我很乐意给它，但我只知道这是我胆怯的维奥拉的一时兴起，我屈服了。现在，我的孩子们，让游戏结束吧。揭开面具并接受我的祝福。

But neither bent the knee, for the young bridegroom replied in a tone that startled all listeners as the mask fell, disclosing the noble face of Ferdinand Devereux, the artist lover, and leaning on the breast where now flashed the star of an English earl was the lovely Viola, radiant with joy and beauty.
但两人都没有弯曲膝盖，因为当面具落下时，年轻的新郎用一种令所有听众震惊的语气回答，露出了艺术家爱好者费迪南德·德弗罗的高贵面孔，靠在胸前，现在闪烁着英国伯爵的星星。可爱的维奥拉，容光焕发，充满欢乐和美丽。

‘My lord, you scornfully bade me claim your daughter when I could boast as high a name and vast a fortune as the Count antonio. I can do more, for even your ambitious soul cannot refuse the Earl of Devereux and De Vere, when he gives his ancient name and boundless wealth in return for the beloved hand of this fair lady, now my wife.
“大人，当我可以像安东尼奥伯爵一样拥有崇高的名声和巨大的财富时，您却轻蔑地命令我拥有您的女儿。我可以做得更多，因为即使是你雄心勃勃的灵魂也无法拒绝德弗罗伯爵和德维尔伯爵，当他献出自己古老的名字和无尽的财富来回报这位美丽女士（现在是我的妻子）的心爱之手时。

The count stood like one changed to stone, and turning to the bewildered crowd, Ferdinand added, with a gay smile of triumph, ‘To you, my gallant friends, I can only wish that your wooing may prosper as mine has done, and that you may all win as fair a bride as I have by this masked marriage.’
伯爵像变成了石头一样站着，转向困惑的人群，费迪南德带着胜利的快乐微笑补充道，“对你们，我勇敢的朋友们，我只能希望你们的追求能够像我一样成功，而且你们都可以通过这场假面婚姻赢得像我一样美丽的新娘。

S. PICKWICK
S·匹克威克

Why is the P. C. like the Tower of Babel?
为什么PC就像巴别塔？

It is full of unruly members.
它充满了不守规矩的成员。

THE HISTORY OF A SQUASH
南瓜的历史

Once upon a time a farmer planted a little seed. in his garden, and after a while it sprouted and became a vine and bore many squashes. One day in October, when they were ripe, he picked one and took it to market. A gorcerman bought and put it in his shop. That same morning, a little girl in a brown hat and blue dress, with a round face and snub nose, went and bought it for her mother. She lugged it home, cut it up, and boiled it in the big pot, mashed some of it salt and butter, for dinner. And to the rest she added a pint of milk, two eggs, four spoons of sugar, nutmeg, and some crackers, put it in a deep dish, and baked it till it was brown and nice, and next day it was eaten by a family named March.
从前，有一位农民种下了一颗小种子。在他的花园里，过了一会儿，它发芽了，变成了一棵藤蔓，结了许多南瓜。十月的一天，当它们成熟时，他摘了一棵并把它带到市场上。一个杂货店主买了它并把它放在他的店里。那天早上，一个戴着棕色帽子、穿着蓝色衣服、圆脸、塌鼻子的小女孩去给她妈妈买了它。她把它拖回家，切碎，放在大锅里煮，捣碎一些盐和黄油，作为晚餐。剩下的，她加了一品脱牛奶、两个鸡蛋、四勺糖、肉豆蔻和一些饼干，把它们放在一个深盘里，烤到它变成棕色，好看极了，第二天，它被一个人吃掉了。家庭名叫马奇。

T. TUPMAN
T·图普曼

Mr. Pickwick, Sir:I address you upon the subject of sin the sinner I mean is a man named Winkle who makes trouble in his club by laughing and sometimes won’t write his piece in this fine paper I hope you will pardon his badness and let him send a French fable because he can’t write out of his head as he has so many lessons to do and no brains in future I will try to take time by the fetlock and prepare some work which will be all commy la fo that means all right I am in haste as it is nearly school time
匹克威克先生，先生：我向您介绍的是罪孽，我指的是一个名叫温克尔的人，他在他的俱乐部里大笑，有时不肯把他的文章写在这篇精美的报纸上，我希望您能原谅他的坏行为。让他发一篇法国寓言，因为他不能凭自己的头脑写出来，因为他有很多功课要做，而且将来没有脑子。我会尽力花时间准备一些工作，这些工作都将是commy la fo这意味着好吧，我很着急，因为快到放学时间了

Yours respectably,
尊敬的您，

N. WINKLE
N·温克尔

[The above is a manly and handsome aknowledgment of past misdemeanors. If our young friend studied punctuation, it would be well.]
【以上是对过去的轻罪的男子气概和帅气的承认。如果我们的小朋友学一下标点符号就好了。]

A SAD ACCIDENT
一次悲伤的事故

On Friday last, we were startled by a violent shock in our basement, followed by cries of distress. On rushing in a body to the cellar, we discovered our beloved President prostrate upon the floor, having tripped and fallen while getting wood for domestic purposes. A perfect scene of ruin met our eyes, for in his fall Mr. Pickwick had plunged his head and shoulders into a tub of water, upset a keg of soft soap upon his manly form, and torn his garments badly. On being removed from this perilous situation, it was discovered that he had suffered no injury but several bruises, and we are happy to add, is now doing well.
上周五，我们被地下室里的剧烈震动吓了一跳，随后传来了呼救声。当我们冲进地窖时，我们发现我们敬爱的总统跪倒在地板上，他是在为家庭取木材时绊倒的。我们眼前呈现出一幅完美的毁灭景象，匹克威克先生摔倒时，他的头和肩膀浸入一盆水中，一桶软肥皂打翻了他男子气概的身体，衣服也被撕破了。当他被从这个危险的地方转移出来时，我们发现他没有受伤，只是有几处瘀伤，我们很高兴地补充说，他现在情况良好。

ED.
埃德。

THE PUBLIC BEREAVEMENT
公众的丧亲之痛

It is our painful duty to record the sudden and mysterious disappearance of our cherished friend, Mrs. Snowball Pat Paw. This lovely and beloved cat was the pet of a large circle of warm and admiring friends; for her beauty attracted all eyes, her graces and virtues endeared her to all hearts, and her loss is deeply felt by the whole community.
我们有痛苦的责任来记录我们挚爱的朋友斯诺鲍·帕特·波夫人的突然神秘失踪。这只可爱又受人喜爱的猫是一大群热情而钦佩的朋友的宠物。因为她的美丽吸引了所有人的目光，她的优雅和美德让她受到所有人的喜爱，而她的去世让整个社会深感痛心。

When last seen, she was sitting at the gate, watching the butcher’s cart, and it is feared that some villain, tempted by her charms, basely stole her. Weeks have passed, but no trace of her has been discovered, and we relinquish all hope, tie a black ribbon to her basket, set aside her dish, and weep for her as one lost to us forever.
最后一次见到时，她正坐在门口，看着屠夫的车，恐怕有小人被她的魅力所诱惑，卑鄙地偷走了她。几个星期过去了，但没有发现她的踪迹，我们放弃了所有希望，在她的篮子上系了一条黑丝带，把她的盘子放在一边，为她哭泣，就像我们永远失去了她一样。

A sympathizing friend sends the following gem:
一位富有同情心的朋友发送了以下宝石：

A LAMENT
哀叹

(FOR S. B. PAT PAW)
（致 S. B. 帕特·波）

We mourn the loss of our little pet,
我们哀悼失去我们的小宠物，

And sigh o’er her hapless fate,
并叹息她不幸的命运，

For never more by the fire she’ll sit,
她再也不会坐在火边，

Nor play by the old green gate.
也不在古老的绿色大门旁玩耍。

The little grave where her infant sleeps
她的婴儿睡觉的小坟墓

Is ‘neath the chestnut tree.
就在栗树下。

But o’er her grave we may not weep,
但在她的坟墓上我们可能不会哭泣，

We know not where it may be.
我们不知道它可能在哪里。

Her empty bed, her idle ball,
她的空床，她闲置的球，

Will never see her more;
再也见不到她了；

No gentle tap, no loving purr
没有轻柔的敲击，没有爱的呼噜声

Is heard at the parlor door.
客厅门口传来。

Another cat comes after her mice,
另一只猫追赶她的老鼠，

A cat with a dirty face,
一只脸脏兮兮的猫，

But she does not hunt as our darling did,
但她不像我们亲爱的那样打猎，

Nor play with her airy grace.
也不玩弄她那飘逸的优雅。

Her stealthy paws tread the very hall
她偷偷摸摸的爪子踏过大厅

Where Snowball used to play,
雪球以前玩的地方

But she only spits at the dogs our pet
但她只向我们的宠物狗吐口水

So gallantly drove away.
于是潇洒的开车走了。

She is useful and mild, and does her best,
她很有用，很温和，并且尽力而为，

But she is not fair to see,
但她不公平地看到，

And we cannot give her your place dear,
亲爱的，我们不能给她你的位置，

Nor worship her as we worship thee.
也不要像我们崇拜你那样崇拜她。

A.S.
作为。

ADVERTISEMENTS
广告

Miss Oranthy Bluggage, the accomplished strong-minded lecturer, will deliver her famous lecture on ‘WOMAN AND HER POSITION’ at Pickwick Hall, next Saturday Evening, after the usual performances.
奥兰西·布鲁吉小姐 (Oranthy Blugage) 是一位多才多艺、意志坚强的讲师，她将于下周六晚上在常规表演结束后在匹克威克厅发表她著名的演讲“女人和她的位置”。

A weekly meeting will be held at Kitchen place, to teach young ladies how to cook. Hannah Brown will preside, and all are invited to attend.
每周都会在厨房举行一次会议，教年轻女士如何做饭。汉娜·布朗将主持会议，并邀请所有人参加。

The DUSTPAN SOCIETY will meet on Wednesday next, and parade in the upper story of the Club House. All members to appear in uniform and shoulder their brooms at nine precisely.
DUSTPAN SOCIETY 将于下周三举行会议，并在俱乐部楼上举行游行。所有成员必须穿着制服，并在九点整时肩负扫帚。

Mrs. Beth Bouncer will open her new assortment of Doll’s Millinery next week. The latest Paris fashions have arrived, and orders are respectfully solicited.
Beth Bouncer 女士将于下周推出她的 Doll’s Millinery 新品种。最新巴黎时装已到货，敬请订购。

A new play will appear at the Barnville Theatre, in the course of a few weeks, which will surpass anything ever seen on the American stage. The Greek Slave, or Constantine the Avenger, is the name of this thrilling drama.!!!
几周后，一部新剧将在巴恩维尔剧院上演，这将超越美国舞台上所见过的任何剧目。希腊奴隶，或复仇者君士坦丁，是这部惊心动魄的戏剧的名字。！！！

WEEKLY REPORT
每周报告

Meg—Good.
梅格——很好。

Jo—Bad.
乔——坏。

Beth—Very Good.
贝丝——非常好。

Amy—Middling.
艾米——中等。

As the President finished reading the paper (which I beg leave to assure my readers is a bona fide copy of one written by bona fide girls once upon a time), a round of applause followed, and then Mr. Snodgrass rose to make a proposition.
当主席读完这篇论文时（我请允许向我的读者保证，这篇论文是由真正的女孩们从前写的一篇文章的真实副本），随之而来的是一阵掌声，然后斯诺德格拉斯先生起身提出一项提议。

‘Mr. President and gentlemen,’ he began, assuming a parliamentary attitude and tone, ‘I wish to propose the admission of a new member—one who highly deserves the honor, would be deeply grateful for it, and would add immensely to the spirit of the club, the literary value of the paper, and be no end jolly and nice. I propose Mr. Theodore Laurence as an honorary member of the P. C. Come now, do have him.’
'先生。主席先生们，”他以议会的态度和语气开始说道，“我希望提议接纳一位新成员，他非常值得这一荣誉，他将对此深表感激，并将极大地增强我们的精神。”俱乐部，报纸的文学价值，是永无休止的欢乐和美好。我提议西奥多·劳伦斯先生担任政治委员会荣誉委员。来吧，请他吧。

Jo’s sudden change of tone made the girls laugh, but all looked rather anxious, and no one said a word as Snodgrass took his seat.
乔突然改变的语气让女孩们笑了起来，但大家都显得很焦虑，当斯诺德格拉斯落座时，没有人说一句话。

‘We’ll put it to a vote,’ said the President. ‘All in favor of this motion please to manifest it by saying, ‘Aye’.’
“我们将对其进行表决，”总统说。 “所有支持这项动议的人请表示‘同意’。”

‘Contrary-minded say, ‘No’.’
“持相反意见的人说‘不’。”

Meg and Amy were contrary-minded, and Mr. Winkle rose to say with great elegance, ‘We don’t wish any boys, they only joke and bounce about. This is a ladies’ club, and we wish to be private and proper.’
梅格和艾米的想法相反，温克尔先生起身优雅地说：“我们不希望有男孩，他们只会开玩笑和蹦蹦跳跳。”这是一个女士俱乐部，我们希望保持私密性和适当性。”

‘I’m afraid he’ll laugh at our paper, and make fun of us afterward,’ observed Pickwick, pulling the little curl on her forehead, as she always did when doubtful.
“我担心他会嘲笑我们的报纸，然后又取笑我们，”匹克威克说道，拉扯额头上的小卷发，就像她在怀疑时总是做的那样。

Up rose Snodgrass, very much in earnest. ‘Sir, I give you my word as a gentleman, Laurie won’t do anything of the sort. He likes to write, and he’ll give a tone to our contributions and keep us from being sentimental, don’t you see? We can do so little for him, and he does so much for us, I think the least we can do is to offer him a place here, and make him welcome if he comes.’
斯诺德格拉斯站了起来，语气非常认真。 “先生，作为一个绅士，我向你保证，劳里不会做这种事。他喜欢写作，他会给我们的贡献定一个基调，让我们不再感伤，你明白吗？我们能为他做的事情很少，而他为我们做了很多，我认为我们至少可以为他提供一个地方，并在他来的时候欢迎他。

This artful allusion to benefits conferred brought Tupman to his feet, looking as if he had quite made up his mind.
这种对所赋予利益的巧妙暗示让塔普曼站了起来，看起来好像他已经下定决心了。

‘Yes, we ought to do it, even if we are afraid. I say he may come, and his grandpa, too, if he likes.’
“是的，我们应该这样做，即使我们害怕。我说他可以来，如果他愿意的话，他的爷爷也可以来。

This spirited burst from Beth electrified the club, and Jo left her seat to shake hands approvingly. ‘Now then, vote again. Everybody remember it’s our Laurie, and say, ‘Aye!’’ cried Snodgrass excitedly.
贝丝的热情爆发让整个俱乐部都沸腾了，乔离开座位，赞同地握手。 「那么，现在再投票吧。」每个人都记得这是我们的劳里，并说，“是的！”斯诺德格拉斯兴奋地喊道。

‘Aye! Aye! Aye!’ replied three voices at once.
‘是啊！是啊！是啊！”三个声音同时回答。

‘Good! Bless you! Now, as there’s nothing like ‘taking time by the fetlock’, as Winkle characteristically observes, allow me to present the new member.’ And, to the dismay of the rest of the club, Jo threw open the door of the closet, and displayed Laurie sitting on a rag bag, flushed and twinkling with suppressed laughter.
'好的！祝福你！现在，正如温克尔所观察到的那样，没有什么比‘花时间抓住球节’更好的了，请允许我介绍一下新成员。”令俱乐部其他成员沮丧的是，乔打开了衣柜的门，然后照片中劳里坐在一个破布袋上，脸色通红，闪烁着压抑的笑声。

‘You rogue! You traitor! Jo, how could you?’ cried the three girls, as Snodgrass led her friend triumphantly forth, and producing both a chair and a badge, installed him in a jiffy.
‘你这个流氓！你这个叛徒！乔，你怎么能这样？”三个女孩喊道，斯诺德格拉斯得意洋洋地领着她的朋友向前走，并拿出一把椅子和一枚徽章，很快就让他安顿下来。

‘The coolness of you two rascals is amazing,’ began Mr. Pickwick, trying to get up an awful frown and only succeeding in producing an amiable smile. But the new member was equal to the occasion, and rising, with a grateful salutation to the Chair, said in the most engaging manner, ‘Mr. President and ladies—I beg pardon, gentlemen—allow me to introduce myself as Sam Weller, the very humble servant of the club.’
“你们两个无赖的冷静真是令人惊奇，”匹克威克先生开始说道，他试图皱起眉头，但最后却成功地露出了和蔼可亲的微笑。但新成员很适应这个场合，并起身向主席致以感激的敬意，并以最迷人的方式说道：“先生。”主席和女士们——请原谅，先生们——请允许我介绍自己，我是萨姆·韦勒，俱乐部非常谦虚的仆人。”

‘Good! Good!’ cried Jo, pounding with the handle of the old warming pan on which she leaned.
'好的！好极了！”乔喊道，一边用她靠着的旧暖锅的手柄敲击着。

‘My faithful friend and noble patron,’ continued Laurie with a wave of the hand, ‘who has so flatteringly presented me, is not to be blamed for the base stratagem of tonight. I planned it, and she only gave in after lots of teasing.’
“我忠实的朋友和高贵的赞助人，”劳里挥挥手继续说道，“他如此谄媚地介绍了我，今晚的卑鄙策略不应受到责备。我计划好了，但她在多次取笑后才屈服了。”

‘Come now, don’t lay it all on yourself. You know I proposed the cupboard,’ broke in Snodgrass, who was enjoying the joke amazingly.
‘来吧，别把一切都压在自己身上。你知道我提议了橱柜，”斯诺德格拉斯插话道，他非常喜欢这个笑话。

‘Never mind what she says. I’m the wretch that did it, sir,’ said the new member, with a Welleresque nod to Mr. Pickwick. ‘But on my honor, I never will do so again, and henceforth devote myself to the interest of this immortal club.’
‘别管她说什么。先生，我就是干这事的坏蛋。”新成员说道，并像韦勒式那样向匹克威克先生点了点头。 “但以我的名誉担保，我再也不会这样做了，从今以后我将全身心投入到这个不朽俱乐部的利益中。”

‘Hear! Hear!’ cried Jo, clashing the lid of the warming pan like a cymbal.
'听到！听着！”乔喊道，像铙钹一样敲打着暖锅的盖子。

‘Go on, go on!’ added Winkle and Tupman, while the President bowed benignly.
“继续，继续！”温克尔和图普曼补充道，而总统则友善地鞠了一躬。

‘I merely wish to say, that as a slight token of my gratitude for the honor done me, and as a means of promoting friendly relations between adjoining nations, I have set up a post office in the hedge in the lower corner of the garden, a fine, spacious building with padlocks on the doors and every convenience for the mails, also the females, if I may be allowed the expression. It’s the old martin house, but I’ve stopped up the door and made the roof open, so it will hold all sorts of things, and save our valuable time. Letters, manuscripts, books, and bundles can be passed in there, and as each nation has a key, it will be uncommonly nice, I fancy. Allow me to present the club key, and with many thanks for your favor, take my seat.’
“我只想说，为了表达对我所获得的荣誉的感激之情，并作为促进毗邻国家之间友好关系的一种手段，我在花园下角的树篱里设立了一个邮局这是一座精美、宽敞的建筑，门上挂着挂锁，为邮件提供了一切便利，如果允许我这么说的话，也为女性提供便利。这是老马丁的房子，但我把门堵住了，把屋顶打开了，这样它就可以容纳各种各样的东西，节省了我们宝贵的时间。信件、手稿、书籍和包裹都可以在那里传递，而且每个国家都有一把钥匙，我想这会非常好。请允许我出示俱乐部钥匙，非常感谢您的支持，请入座。

Great applause as Mr. Weller deposited a little key on the table and subsided, the warming pan clashed and waved wildly, and it was some time before order could be restored. A long discussion followed, and everyone came out surprising, for everyone did her best. So it was an unusually lively meeting, and did not adjourn till a late hour, when it broke up with three shrill cheers for the new member. No one ever regretted the admittance of Sam Weller, for a more devoted, well-behaved, and jovial member no club could have. He certainly did add ‘spirit’ to the meetings, and ‘a tone’ to the paper, for his orations convulsed his hearers and his contributions were excellent, being patriotic, classical, comical, or dramatic, but never sentimental. Jo regarded them as worthy of Bacon, Milton, or Shakespeare, and remodeled her own works with good effect, she thought.
当韦勒先生把一把小钥匙放在桌子上并平息后，热烈的掌声平息下来，暖锅剧烈地碰撞和摆动，过了一段时间才恢复秩序。接下来是长时间的讨论，每个人都感到惊讶，因为每个人都尽力了。因此，这次会议异常热闹，直到很晚才休会，在为新成员带来的三声尖锐欢呼声中结束。没有人后悔萨姆·韦勒的加入，因为他是任何俱乐部都无法拥有的一位更忠诚、更乖巧、更快乐的成员。他确实为会议增添了“精神”，为报纸增添了“基调”，因为他的演讲震撼了听众，他的贡献也很出色，爱国的、古典的、滑稽的或戏剧性的，但从不感伤。乔认为它们堪比培根、弥尔顿或莎士比亚，并改造了自己的作品，效果很好。

The P. O. was a capital little institution, and flourished wonderfully, for nearly as many queer things passed through it as through the real post office. Tragedies and cravats, poetry and pickles, garden seeds and long letters, music and gingerbread, rubbers, invitations, scoldings, and puppies. The old gentleman liked the fun, and amused himself by sending odd bundles, mysterious messages, and funny telegrams, and his gardener, who was smitten with Hannah’s charms, actually sent a love letter to Jo’s care. How they laughed when the secret came out, never dreaming how many love letters that little post office would hold in the years to come.
邮政局是一个重要的小机构，而且非常繁荣，因为几乎和真正的邮局一样，有很多奇怪的东西通过它。悲剧和领带、诗歌和泡菜、花园种子和长信、音乐和姜饼、橡皮、邀请函、责骂和小狗。老先生很喜欢这种乐趣，他通过发送奇怪的包裹、神秘的信息和有趣的电报来取乐自己，而他的园丁被汉娜的魅力迷住了，实际上给乔的照顾寄了一封情书。当这个秘密被揭晓时，他们笑得很开心，没想到在未来的岁月里，这个小邮局会容纳多少封情书。

CHAPTER ELEVEN
第十一章

‘The first of June! The Kings are off to the seashore tomorrow, and I’m free. Three months’ vacation—how I shall enjoy it!’ exclaimed Meg, coming home one warm day to find Jo laid upon the sofa in an unusual state of exhaustion, while Beth took off her dusty boots, and Amy made lemonade for the refreshment of the whole party.
‘六月一日！国王队明天要去海边，我有空。三个月的假期——我该多么享受啊！”梅格在一个温暖的日子回到家，发现乔躺在沙发上，一副异常疲惫的样子，贝丝脱掉沾满灰尘的靴子，艾米泡了柠檬水提神。整个聚会。

‘Aunt March went today, for which, oh, be joyful!’ said Jo. ‘I was mortally afraid she’d ask me to go with her. If she had, I should have felt as if I ought to do it, but Plumfield is about as gay as a churchyard, you know, and I’d rather be excused. We had a flurry getting the old lady off, and I had a fright every time she spoke to me, for I was in such a hurry to be through that I was uncommonly helpful and sweet, and feared she’d find it impossible to part from me. I quaked till she was fairly in the carriage, and had a final fright, for as it drove of, she popped out her head, saying, ‘Josyphine, won’t you—?’ I didn’t hear any more, for I basely turned and fled. I did actually run, and whisked round the corner whee I felt safe.’
“马奇姨妈今天去了，为此，哦，高兴吧！”乔说。 “我非常害怕她会邀请我和她一起去。如果她这么做了，我会觉得我应该这样做，但普拉姆菲尔德就像墓地一样快乐，你知道，我宁愿被原谅。我们匆忙地把老太太送走，每次她跟我说话时我都感到害怕，因为我是如此匆忙地完成任务，以至于我异常乐于助人且友善，并且担心她会发现无法分开从我。我一直颤抖着，直到她完全在马车里，我才感到最后的恐惧，因为当马车开走时，她探出头来，说：“乔西芬，你不会——吗？”我再也没有听到任何声音，因为我卑鄙地转身逃跑。我确实跑了，当我感到安全时，我迅速绕过了拐角。

‘Poor old Jo! She came in looking as if bears were after her,’ said Beth, as she cuddled her sister’s feet with a motherly air.
‘可怜的老乔！ “她进来时看起来就像有熊在追她一样。”贝丝一边说道，一边带着慈母般的表情拥抱着姐姐的脚。

‘Aunt March is a regular samphire, is she not?’ observed Amy, tasting her mixture critically.
“马奇婶婶是个普通的海蓬子，不是吗？”艾米评论道，一边批判地品尝着她的混合物。

‘She means vampire, not seaweed, but it doesn’t matter. It’s too warm to be particular about one’s parts of speech,’ murmured Jo.
‘她指的是吸血鬼，不是海藻，但这并不重要。 “天气太热了，不能拘泥于词性。”乔低声说道。

‘What shall you do all your vacation?’ asked Amy, changing the subject with tact.
“你整个假期都打算做什么？”艾米巧妙地转移了话题。

‘I shall lie abed late, and do nothing,’ replied Meg, from the depths of the rocking chair. ‘I’ve been routed up early all winter and had to spend my days working for other people, so now I’m going to rest and revel to my heart’s content.’
“我会躺在床上很晚，什么也不做，”梅格在摇椅深处回答道。 “整个冬天我都早早就下班了，不得不整天为别人工作，所以现在我要休息并尽情享受。”

‘No,’ said Jo, ‘that dozy way wouldn’t suit me. I’ve laid in a heap of books, and I’m going to improve my shining hours reading on my perch in the old apple tree, when I’m not having l...’
“不，”乔说，“那种昏昏欲睡的方式不适合我。”我已经躺在一堆书里了，当我没有时间的时候，我会坐在老苹果树上读书，以提高我的光辉岁月。”

‘Don’t say ‘larks!’’ implored Amy, as a return snub for the samphire’ correction.
“别说‘云雀’！”艾米恳求道，以此作为对海蓬子纠正的回击。

‘I’ll say ‘nightingales’ then, with Laurie. That’s proper and appropriate, since he’s a warbler.’
“那么我会和劳里一起说‘夜莺’。这是正确且恰当的，因为他是一只莺。

‘Don’t let us do any lessons, Beth, for a while, but play all the time and rest, as the girls mean to,’ proposed Amy.
“贝丝，暂时不要让我们上任何课，而是一直玩耍并休息，就像女孩们的意思一样，”艾米提议道。

‘Well, I will, if Mother doesn’t mind. I want to learn some new songs, and my children need fitting up for the summer. They are dreadfully out of order and really suffering for clothes.’
“好吧，如果妈妈不介意的话，我会的。”我想学一些新歌，我的孩子们需要为暑假做准备。他们的情况严重失调，而且真的很缺衣服。”

‘May we, Mother?’ asked Meg, turning to Mrs. March, who sat sewing in what they called ‘Marmee’s corner’. ‘You may try your experiment for a week and see how you like it. I think by Saturday night you will find that all play and no work is as bad as all work and no play.’
“我们可以吗，妈妈？”梅格转向马奇太太问道，马奇太太坐在他们所谓的“妈妈的角落”里做针线活。 ‘你可以尝试一周的实验，看看你是否喜欢它。我想到周六晚上你就会发现只玩不工作和只玩不玩一样糟糕。

‘Oh, dear, no! It will be delicious, I’m sure,’ said Meg complacently.
‘噢，亲爱的，不！我确信它会很美味。”梅格得意地说。

‘I now propose a toast, as my ‘friend and pardner, Sairy Gamp’, says. Fun forever, and no grubbing!’ cried Jo, rising, glass in hand, as the lemonade went round.
正如我的‘朋友兼伙伴赛里·甘普’所说，我现在提议干杯。永远充满乐趣，别再挖苦了！”当柠檬水流淌时，乔站了起来，手里拿着玻璃杯。

They all drank it merrily, and began the experiment by lounging for the rest of the day. Next morning, Meg did not appear till ten o’clock. Her solitary breakfast did not taste nice, and the room seemed lonely and untidy, for Jo had not filled the vases, Beth had not dusted, and Amy’s books lay scattered about. Nothing was neat and pleasant but ‘Marmee’s corner’, which looked as usual. And there Meg sat, to ‘rest and read’, which meant to yawn and imagine what pretty summer dresses she would get with her salary. Jo spent the morning on the river with Laurie and the afternoon reading and crying over The Wide, Wide World, up in the apple tree. Beth began by rummaging everything out of the big closet where her family resided, but getting tired before half done, she left her establishment topsy-turvy and went to her music, rejoicing that she had no dishes to wash. Amy arranged her bower, put on her best white frock, smoothed her curls, and sat down to draw under the honeysuckle, hoping someone would see and inquire who the young artist was. As no one appeared but an inquisitive daddy-longlegs, who examined her work with interest, she went to walk, got caught in a shower, and came home dripping.
他们都兴高采烈地喝了下去，然后在这一天剩下的时间里闲逛着开始了实验。第二天早上，梅格直到十点才出现。她独自吃的早餐味道不好，房间显得孤独而凌乱，因为乔没有把花瓶装满，贝丝也没有掸去灰尘，艾米的书散落在各处。除了“妈妈的角落”之外，没有什么整洁和令人愉快的，它看起来和往常一样。梅格坐在那里“休息和读书”，这意味着打哈欠并想象她用自己的薪水会得到多么漂亮的夏装。乔和劳里一起在河边度过了一个上午，下午则在苹果树上边读书边哭着读《广阔的世界》。贝丝开始从她家人居住的大壁橱里翻出所有东西，但还没完成一半就累了，她从家里乱七八糟地离开了，开始听音乐，庆幸自己没有盘子要洗。艾米布置好她的凉亭，穿上她最好的白色连衣裙，抚平卷发，然后坐下来在金银花下画画，希望有人能看到并询问这位年轻艺术家是谁。由于没有人出现，只有一位好奇的长腿爸爸饶有兴趣地审视着她的作品，她出去散步，淋了一场雨，回到家时浑身湿淋淋的。

At teatime they compared notes, and all agreed that it had been a delightful, though unusually long day. Meg, who went shopping in the afternoon and got a ‘sweet blue muslin, had discovered, after she had cut the breadths off, that it wouldn’t wash, which mishap made her slightly cross. Jo had burned the skin off her nose boating, and got a raging headache by reading too long. Beth was worried by the confusion of her closet and the difficulty of learning three or four songs at once, and Amy deeply regretted the damage done her frock, for Katy Brown’s party was to be the next day and now like Flora McFlimsey, she had ‘nothing to wear’. But these were mere trifles, and they assured their mother that the experiment was working finely. She smiled, said nothing, and with Hannah’s help did their neglected work, keeping home pleasant and the domestic machinery running smoothly. It was astonishing what a peculiar and uncomfortable state of things was produced by the ‘resting and reveling’ process. The days kept getting longer and longer, the weather was unusually variable and so were tempers, and unsettled feeling possessed everyone, and Satan found plenty of mischief for the idle hands to do. As the height of luxury, Meg put out some of her sewing, and then found time hang so heavily that she fell to snipping and spoiling her clothes in her attempts to furbish them up a‘la Moffat. Jo read till her eyes gave out and she was sick of books, got so fidgety that even good-natured Laurie had a quarrel with her, and so reduced in spirits that she desperately wished she had gone with Aunt March. Beth got on pretty well, for she was constantly forgetting that it was to be all play and no work, and fell back into her old ways now and then. But something in the air affected her, and more than once her tranquility was much disturbed, so much so that on one occasion she actually shook poor dear Joanna and told her she was a fright’. Amy fared worst of all, for her resources were small, and when her sisters left her to amuse herself, she soon found that accomplished and important little self a great burden. She didn’t like dolls, fairy tales were childish, and one couldn’t draw all the time. Tea parties didn’t amount to much neither did picnics unless very well conducted. ‘If one could have a fine house, full of nice girls, or go traveling, the summer would be delightful, but to stay at home with three selfish sisters and a grown-up boy was enough to try the patience of a Boaz,’ complained Miss Malaprop, after several days devoted to pleasure, fretting, and ennui.
下午茶时间，他们交换了意见，一致认为这是令人愉快的一天，尽管这一天异常漫长。梅格下午去购物，买了一条“甜蓝色平纹细布”，在剪掉宽度后，她发现它无法清洗，这个意外让她有点生气。乔在划船时烧伤了鼻子上的皮肤，并且由于阅读时间太长而感到剧烈头痛。贝丝担心她的衣橱混乱，而且很难同时学习三到四首歌，艾米对她的连衣裙损坏深感遗憾，因为凯蒂·布朗的派对将在第二天举行，现在像弗洛拉·麦克弗利姆西一样，她有“无衣可穿'。但这些都只是小事，他们向母亲保证实验进展顺利。她微笑着，什么也没说，在汉娜的帮助下完成了她们被忽视的工作，让家里保持愉快，家用机器运转顺利。令人惊讶的是，“休息和狂欢”的过程产生了一种奇特和不舒服的状态。日子越来越长，天气变幻莫测，脾气也变幻莫测，每个人都心神不宁，撒旦为闲着的人做了很多坏事。正当奢华之际，梅格放弃了一些缝纫工作，然后发现时间紧迫，以至于她在试图把衣服打扮得像莫法特一样时，开始剪断和弄坏自己的衣服。乔读到眼睛昏花，她厌倦了书本，变得如此烦躁，甚至好心的劳里也和她吵架，她的精神如此沮丧，以至于她非常希望自己和马奇姨妈一起去。贝丝相处得很好，因为她总是忘记这只是玩耍而不是工作，并且时不时地又回到原来的方式。 但空气中的某种东西影响了她，她的平静不止一次受到了极大的干扰，以至于有一次她真的摇晃着可怜的亲爱的乔安娜，并告诉她她是一个可怕的人。艾米的处境最糟糕，因为她的资源很少，当她的姐妹们离开她去自娱自乐时，她很快发现这个多才多艺、重要的小自我成为了巨大的负担。她不喜欢洋娃娃，童话很幼稚，也不能一直画画。茶会和野餐都没有多大意义，除非进行得很好。 “如果一个人能有一栋漂亮的房子，里面住满了漂亮的女孩，或者去旅行，夏天会很愉快，但和三个自私的姐妹和一个成年男孩呆在家里就足以考验波阿斯的耐心了。”马拉普罗普小姐抱怨道，几天后她沉浸在快乐、烦恼和倦怠之中。

No one would own that they were tired of the experiment, but by Friday night each acknowledged to herself that she was glad the week was nearly done. Hoping to impress the lesson more deeply, Mrs. March, who had a good deal of humor, resolved to finish off the trial in an appropriate manner, so she gave Hannah a holiday and let the girls enjoy the full effect of the play system.
没有人会承认他们已经厌倦了这个实验，但到了周五晚上，每个人都对自己承认，她很高兴这一周即将结束。为了让这节课留下更深刻的印象，幽默的马奇老师决定以适当的方式结束这次审判，于是她给汉娜放了个假，让女孩们充分享受游戏系统的效果。

When they got up on Saturday morning, there was no fire in the kitchen, no breakfast in the dining room, and no mother anywhere to be seen.
周六早上他们起床时，厨房里没有生火，餐厅里没有早餐，也看不到母亲的身影。

‘Mercy on us! What has happened?’ cried Jo, staring about her in dismay.
‘怜悯我们吧！发生了什么事？”乔惊愕地看着她，喊道。

Meg ran upstairs and soon came back again, looking relieved but rather bewildered, and a little ashamed.
梅格跑上楼，很快又回来了，看上去松了口气，但又有些困惑，还有点羞愧。

‘Mother isn’t sick, only very tired, and she says she is going to stay quietly in her room all day and let us do the best we can. It’s a very queer thing for her to do, she doesn’t act a bit like herself. But she says it has been a hard week for her, so we mustn’t grumble but take care of ourselves.’
“妈妈没有生病，只是很累，她说她会安静地呆在房间里一整天，让我们尽力而为。”对她来说这是一件非常奇怪的事情，她的行为一点也不像她自己。但她说这对她来说是艰难的一周，所以我们不能抱怨，要照顾好自己。”

‘That’s easy enough, and I like the idea, I’m aching for something to do, that is, some new amusement, you know,’ added Jo quickly.
“这很简单，我喜欢这个主意，我渴望找点事做，也就是说，一些新的娱乐，你知道，”乔很快补充道。

In fact it was an immense relief to them all to have a little work, and they took hold with a will, but soon realized the truth of Hannah’s saying, ‘Housekeeping ain’t no joke.’ There was plenty of food in the larder, and while Beth and Amy set the table, Meg and Jo got breakfast, wondering as they did why servants ever talked about hard work.
事实上，有一点工作对他们所有人来说都是一种巨大的解脱，他们坚定地坚持了下来，但很快就意识到汉娜所说的真理：“家政不是开玩笑。”食品储藏室里有充足的食物。当贝丝和艾米摆桌子的时候，梅格和乔吃早餐，一边想知道为什么仆人们总是谈论辛勤的工作。

‘I shall take some up to Mother, though she said we were not to think of her, for she’d take care of herself,’ said Meg, who presided and felt quite matronly behind the teapot.
“我会带一些给妈妈，尽管她说我们不要想起她，因为她会照顾自己，”梅格说，她在茶壶后面主持，感觉很有主妇的感觉。

So a tray was fitted out before anyone began, and taken up with the cook’s compliments. The boiled tea was very bitter, the omelet scorched, and the biscuits speckled with saleratus, but Mrs. March received her repast with thanks and laughed heartily over it after Jo was gone.
因此，在任何人开始之前，就已经准备好了托盘，并接受了厨师的称赞。煮的茶很苦，煎蛋卷烧焦了，饼干上撒满了小苏打粉，但马奇太太满怀感激地接受了她的晚餐，并在乔离开后开怀大笑。

‘Poor little souls, they will have a hard time, I’m afraid, but they won’t suffer, and it will do them good,’ she said, producing the more palatable viands with which she had provided herself, and disposing of the bad breakfast, so that their feelings might not be hurt, a motherly little deception for which they were grateful.
“可怜的小灵魂，我担心他们会过得很艰难，但他们不会受苦，这对他们有好处。”她一边说，一边拿出自己准备的更美味的食物，然后处理掉糟糕的早餐，这样他们的感情就不会受到伤害，这是一个母亲般的小欺骗，他们对此表示感激。

Many were the complaints below, and great the chagrin of the head cook at her failures. ‘Never mind, I’ll get the dinner and be servant, you be mistress, keep your hands nice, see company, and give orders,’ said Jo, who knew still less than Meg, about culinary affairs.
下面的抱怨很多，主厨对她的失败感到非常懊恼。 “没关系，我去拿晚饭，当仆人，你当女主人，保持双手友好，拜访同伴，下达命令，”乔说，他对烹饪的了解比梅格还少。

This obliging offer was gladly accepted, and Margaret retired to the parlor, which she hastily put in order by whisking the litter under the sofa and shutting the blinds to save the trouble of dusting. Jo, with perfect faith in her own powers and a friendly desire to make up the quarrel, immediately put a note in the office, inviting Laurie to dinner.
玛格丽特很高兴地接受了这个殷勤的提议，玛格丽特回到了客厅，她匆忙把沙发底下的垃圾清理干净，关上百叶窗，省去了除尘的麻烦。乔对自己的能力充满信心，并友好地希望弥补争吵，立即在办公室放了一张纸条，邀请劳里共进晚餐。

‘You’d better see what you have got before you think of having company,’ said Meg, when informed of the hospitable but rash act.
当梅格得知这种热情好客但鲁莽的行为时，她说：“在考虑有人陪伴之前，你最好先看看自己有什么。”

‘Oh, there’s corned beef and plenty of poatoes, and I shall get some asparagus and a lobster, ‘for a relish’, as Hannah says. We’ll have lettuce and make a salad. I don’t know how, but the book tells. I’ll have blancmange and strawberries for dessert, and coffee too, if you want to be elegant.’
“哦，有咸牛肉和大量土豆，我要买一些芦笋和龙虾，‘为了调味’，正如汉娜所说。我们要吃生菜并做沙拉。我不知道怎么做，但书上是这么说的。我要牛奶冻和草莓作为甜点，如果你想优雅的话，还有咖啡。

‘Don’t try too many messes, Jo, for you can’t make anything but gingerbread and molasses candy fit to eat. I wash my hands of the dinner party, and since you have asked Laurie on your own responsibility, you may just take care of him.’
“乔，别尝试太多乱七八糟的事情，因为除了姜饼和糖蜜糖果之外，你什么也做不了。”我不再参加晚宴了，既然你已经要求劳里承担你自己的责任，你就照顾他吧。

‘I don’t want you to do anything but be civil to him and help to the pudding. You’ll give me your advice if I get in a muddle, won’t you?’ asked Jo, rather hurt.
“我不想让你做任何事，除了对他有礼貌，帮忙做布丁。”如果我陷入困境，你会给我建议，不是吗？”乔问道，语气颇为受伤。

‘Yes, but I don’t know much, except about bread and a few trifles. You had better ask Mother’s leave before you order anything,’ returned Meg prudently.
“是的，但我知道的不多，除了面包和一些小东西。你点东西之前最好先请妈妈允许。”梅格谨慎地回答道。

‘Of course I shall. I’m not a fool.’ And Jo went off in a huff at the doubts expressed of her powers.
“我当然会的。我不是傻瓜。”乔因为对她的能力表示怀疑而生气地走了。

‘Get what you like, and don’t disturb me. I’m going out to dinner and can’t worry about things at home,’ said Mrs. March, when Jo spoke to her. ‘I never enjoyed housekeeping, and I’m going to take a vacation today, and read, write, go visiting, and amuse myself.’
“你喜欢什么就拿什么吧，别打扰我。” “我要出去吃晚饭，不用担心家里的事情。”当乔对马奇夫人说话时，她说道。 “我从来不喜欢做家务，今天我要去度假，读书、写作、参观、娱乐自己。”

The unusual spectacle of her busy mother rocking comfortably and reading early in the morning made Jo feel as if some unnatural phenomenon had occurred, for an eclipse, an earthquake, or a volcanic eruption would hardly have seemed stranger.
忙碌的母亲一大早舒适地摇晃着书本，这种不寻常的景象让乔觉得好像发生了某种不自然的现象，因为日食、地震或火山爆发并不奇怪。

‘Everything is out of sorts, somehow,’ she said to herself, going downstairs. ‘There’s Beth crying, that’s a sure sign that something is wrong in this family. If Amy is bothering, I’ll shake her.’
“不知何故，一切都不太对劲，”她一边自言自语，一边下楼。 “贝丝在哭，这是这个家庭出了问题的明确信号。如果艾米打扰了，我会摇晃她。

Feeling very much out of sorts herself, Jo hurried into the parlor to find Beth sobbing over Pip, the canary, who lay dead in the cage with his little claws pathetically extended, as if imploring the food for want of which he had died.
乔自己也感到非常不舒服，急忙走进客厅，发现贝丝正在为金丝雀皮普哭泣，皮普死在笼子里，可怜兮兮地伸出小爪子，仿佛在乞求他死去时所缺少的食物。

‘It’s all my fault, I forgot him, there isn’t a seed or a drop left. Oh, Pip! Oh, Pip! How could I be so cruel to you?’ cried Beth, taking the poor thing in her hands and trying to restore him.
‘都是我的错，我忘记了他，一粒种子、一滴水都没有留下。哦，皮普！哦，皮普！我怎么能对你这么残忍？”贝丝喊道，她把这个可怜的东西握在手里，试图把他救回来。

Jo peeped into his half-open eye, felt his little heart, and finding him stiff and cold, shook her head, and offered her domino box for a coffin.
乔窥视他半睁的眼睛，摸摸他的小心脏，发现他僵硬冰冷，摇了摇头，把她的多米诺骨牌盒子当了棺材。

‘Put him in the oven, and maybe his will get warm and revive,’ said Amy hopefully.
“把他放进烤箱，也许他会变暖并复活，”艾米满怀希望地说。

‘He’s been starved, and he shan’t be baked now he’s dead. I’ll make him a shroud, and he shall be buried in the garden, and I’ll never have another bird, never, my Pip! For I am too bad to own one,’ murmured Beth, sitting on the floor with her pet folded in her hands. ‘The funeral shall be this afternoon, and we will all go. Now, don’t cry, Bethy. It’s a pity, but nothing goes right this week, and Pip has had the worst of the experiment. Make the shroud, and lay him in my box, and after the dinner party, we’ll have a nice little funeral,’ said Jo, beginning to feel as if she had undertaken a good deal.
“他已经饿死了，现在他已经死了，不能再被烤了。”我会给他做一块裹尸布，然后把他埋在花园里，我再也不会再养一只鸟了，永远不会，我的皮普！因为我太糟糕了，不能拥有一只。”贝丝坐在地板上，手里抱着她的宠物，低声说道。 “葬礼将于今天下午举行，我们都会去。现在，别哭，贝丝。遗憾的是，但这周一切都不顺利，皮普经历了最糟糕的实验。做裹尸布，把他放在我的盒子里，晚宴结束后，我们将举行一个愉快的小型葬礼。”乔说，开始觉得自己好像做了一件好事。

Leaving the others to console Beth, she departed to the kitchen, which was in a most discouraging state of confusion. Putting on a big apron, she fell to work and got the dishes piled up ready for washing, when she discovered that the fire was out.
她留下其他人去安慰贝丝，自己去了厨房，厨房里一片混乱，令人沮丧。她系上大围裙，开始干活，把盘子堆起来准备洗，这时她发现火已经灭了。

‘Here’s a sweet prospect!’ muttered Jo, slamming the stove door open, and poking vigorously among the cinders.
“这是一个美好的前景！”乔低声说道，猛地打开炉门，用力地在煤渣中戳戳。

Having rekindled the fire, she thought she would go to market while the water heated. The walk revived her spirits, and flattering herself that she had made good bargins, she trudged home again, after buying a very young lobster, some very old asparagus, and two boxes of acid strawberries. By the time she got cleared up, the dinner arrived and the stove was red-hot. Hannah had left a pan of bread to rise, Meg had worked it up early, set it on the hearth for a second rising, and forgotten it. Meg was entertaining Sallie Gardiner in the parlor, when the door flew open and a floury, crocky, flushed, and disheveled figure appeared, demanding tartly...
重新点燃火后，她想趁水热的时候去市场。这次散步让她精神焕发，自以为讨价还价，买了一只很嫩的龙虾、一些很老的芦笋和两盒酸草莓后，她又拖着沉重的脚步回家了。等她收拾干净的时候，晚饭已经到了，炉子已经烧得通红。汉娜留下了一盘面包等待发酵，梅格很早就把它做好了，把它放在壁炉上进行第二次发酵，然后就忘记了。梅格正在客厅里招待莎莉·加德纳，这时门突然打开了，一个满身面粉、脏兮兮、满脸通红、衣衫不整的身影出现了，尖刻地要求……

‘I say, isn’t bread ‘riz’ enough when it runs over the pans?’
“我说，面包从平底锅上流下来还不够‘riz’吗？”

Sallie began to laugh, but Meg nodded and lifted her eyebrows as high as they would go, which caused the apparition to vanish and put the sour bread into the oven without further delay. Mrs. March went out, after peeping here and there to see how matters went, also saying a word of comfort to Beth, who sat making a winding sheet, while the dear departed lay in state in the domino box. A strange sense of helplessness fell upon the girls as the gray bonnet vanished round the corner, and despair seized them when a few minutes later Miss Crocker appeared, and said she’d come to dinner. Now this lady was a thin, yellow spinster, with a sharp nose and inquisitive eyes, who saw everything and gossiped about all she saw. They disliked her, but had been taught to be kind to her, simply because she was old and poor and had few friends. So Meg gave her the easy chair and tried to entertain her, while she asked questions, critsized everything, and told stories of the people whom she knew.
莎莉开始大笑，但梅格点点头，眉毛抬得最高，这使得幽灵消失了，并立即将酸面包放入烤箱。马奇夫人出去了，四处张望了一番，看看情况如何，还向贝丝说了几句安慰的话。贝丝坐在那儿做裹尸布，而亲爱的死者则安然地躺在多米诺骨牌盒子里。当灰色帽子消失在拐角处时，一种奇怪的无助感降临在女孩们身上，几分钟后，当克罗克小姐出现并说她要来吃晚饭时，绝望抓住了她们。现在这位女士是一个瘦弱的黄老处女，鼻子尖尖，眼睛好奇，她看到了一切，并八卦她所看到的一切。他们不喜欢她，但被教导要善待她，仅仅因为她又老又穷，朋友又少。于是，梅格给了她一把安乐椅，试图逗她开心，而她则提出问题，批评一切，并讲述她认识的人的故事。

Language cannot describe the anxieties, experiences, and exertions which Jo underwent that morning, and the dinner she served up became a standing joke. Fearing to ask any more advice, she did her best alone, and discovered that something more than energy and good will is necessary to make a cook. She boiled the asparagus for an hour and was grieved to find the heads cooked off and the stalks harder than ever. The bread burned black, for the salad dressing so aggravated her that she could not make it fit to ear. The lobster was a scarlet mystery to her, but she hammered and poked till it was unshelled and its meager proportions concealed in a grove of lettuce leaves. The potatoes had to be hurried, not to keep the asparagus waiting, and were not done at the last. The blancmange was lumpy, and the strawberries not as ripe as they looked, having been skilfully ‘deaconed’.
语言无法描述乔那天早上所经历的焦虑、经历和努力，她提供的晚餐成了一个老笑话。她不敢再寻求任何建议，独自尽力而为，并发现要做一名厨师，除了精力和善意之外，还需要一些东西。她把芦笋煮了一个小时，悲伤地发现芦笋头被煮熟了，茎也比以前更硬了。面包烧黑了，因为沙拉酱太让她恼火了，她无法把它放在耳朵里。龙虾对她来说是一个猩红色的谜团，但她又锤又戳，直到它被剥去壳，它那微薄的部分隐藏在一片生菜叶中。土豆得赶紧，不能让芦笋久等，最后没做好。牛奶冻是块状的，草莓也没有看起来那么成熟，只是被巧妙地“执事”了。

‘Well, they can eat beef and bread and butter, if they are hungry, only it’s mortifying to have to spend your whole morning for nothing,’ thought Jo, as she rang the bell half an hour later than usual, and stood, hot, tired, and dispirited, surveying the feast spread before Laurie, accustomed to all sorts of elegance, and Miss Crocker, whose tattling tongue would report them far and wide.
“好吧，他们可以吃牛肉、面包和黄油，如果他们饿了，只是一整个上午都白白度过，真是丢脸。”乔比平时晚了半个小时按响了门铃，站了起来，浑身热气腾腾。劳里已经习惯了各种优雅，而克罗克小姐则用喋喋不休的舌头向四面八方报告着这一切。

Poor Jo would gladly have gone under the table, as one thing after another was tasted and left, while Amy giggled, Meg looked distressed, Miss Crocker pursed her lips, and Laurie talked and laughed with all his might to give a cheerful tone to the festive scene. Jo’s one strong point was the fruit, for she had sugared it well, and had a pitcher of rich cream to eat with it. Her hot cheeks cooled a trifle, and she drew a long breath as the pretty glass plates went round, and everyone looked graciously at the little rosy islands floating in a sea of cream. Miss Crocker tasted first, made a wry face, and drank some water hastily. Jo, who refused, thinking there might not be enough, for they dwindled sadly after the picking over, glanced at Laurie, but he was eating away manfully, though there was a slight pucker about his mouth and he kept his eye fixed on his plate. Amy, who was fond of delicate fare, took a heaping spoonful, choked, hid her face in her napkin, and left the table precipitately.
可怜的乔很乐意躲到桌子底下，因为一件又一件的东西被品尝后就离开了，而艾米咯咯地笑，梅格看起来很苦恼，克罗克小姐撅起嘴唇，劳里竭尽全力地说笑，给这个房间带来愉快的语气。喜庆的场景。乔的一个强项是水果，因为她给水果加了很好的糖，并配了一罐浓郁的奶油一起吃。她滚烫的脸颊稍稍冷却了一些，当漂亮的玻璃板转动时，她长长地吸了一口气，每个人都亲切地看着漂浮在奶油色海洋中的玫瑰色小岛。克罗克小姐先尝了一口，做了个苦脸，急忙喝了点水。乔拒绝了，因为认为可能不够，因为摘完后它们可悲地减少了，她看了一眼劳里，但他正在很有男子气概地吃着，尽管他的嘴角微微皱起，眼睛一直盯着他的盘子。 。艾米喜欢吃精致的食物，她舀了一大勺，噎住了，餐巾里捂着脸，匆匆离开了餐桌。

‘Oh, what is it?’ exclaimed Jo, trembling.
“哦，这是什么？”乔颤抖着喊道。

‘Salt instead of sugar, and the cream is sour,’ replied Meg with a tragic gesture.
“用盐代替糖，奶油是酸的，”梅格用悲惨的手势回答道。

Jo uttered a groan and fell back in her chair, remembering that she had given a last hasty powdering to the berries out of one of the two boxes on the kitchen table, and had neglected to put the milk in the refrigerator. She turned scarlet and was on the verge of crying, when she met Laurie’s eyes, which would look merry in spite of his heroic efforts. The comical side of the affair suddenly struck her, and she laughed till the tears ran down her cheeks. So did everyone else, even ‘Croaker’ as the girls called the old lady, and the unfortunate dinner ended gaily, with bread and butter, olives and fun.
乔发出一声呻吟，向后靠在椅子上，想起她刚刚从厨房桌子上的两个盒子之一里匆忙给浆果撒了粉，却忘了把牛奶放进冰箱。当她看到劳里的眼睛时，她的脸涨得通红，快要哭了，尽管他做出了英勇的努力，但他的眼睛仍然看起来很快乐。这件事的滑稽一面突然袭击了她，她笑得眼泪顺着脸颊流下来。其他人也是如此，甚至包括女孩们对老太太的称呼“黄花鱼”，这顿不幸的晚餐在面包和黄油、橄榄和乐趣中愉快地结束了。

‘I haven’t strength of mind enough to clear up now, so we will sober ourselves with a funeral,’ said Jo, as they rose, and Miss Crocker made ready to go, being eager to tell the new story at another friend’s dinner table.
“我现在没有足够的精神来清理，所以我们要通过葬礼来清醒一下自己，”他们起身时乔说道，克罗克小姐准备出发，渴望在另一个朋友的晚宴上讲述这个新故事。桌子。

They did sober themselves for Beth’s sake. Laurie dug a grave under the ferns in the grove, little Pip was laid in, with many tears by his tender-hearted mistress, and covered with moss, while a wreath of violets and chickweed was hung on the stone which bore his epitaph, composed by Jo while she struggled with the dinner.
为了贝丝，他们确实清醒了。劳里在树林里的蕨类植物下挖了一个坟墓，小皮普被他温柔的女主人安葬了，上面长满了青苔，紫罗兰和繁缕的花环挂在刻有他墓志铭的石头上，组成乔在为晚餐而苦苦挣扎时。

Here lies Pip March,
这里躺着皮普·马奇，

Who died the 7th of June;
谁于 6 月 7 日去世；

Loved and lamented sore,
爱过又痛惜，

And not forgotten soon.
并且不会很快被遗忘。

At the conclusion of the ceremonies, Beth retired to her room, overcome with emotion and lobster, but there was no place of repose, for the beds were not made, and she found her grief much assuaged by beating up the pillows and putting things in order. Meg helped Jo clear away the remains of the feast, which took half the afternoon and left them so tired that they agreed to be contented with tea and toast for supper.
仪式结束后，贝丝回到了自己的房间，心情激动，吃着龙虾，但没有地方休息，因为床还没有铺好，她发现，拍打枕头，把东西放进去，悲伤就减轻了很多。命令。梅格帮助乔清理了宴会的残余物，这花了半个下午的时间，让他们太累了，所以他们同意以茶和烤面包作为晚餐就满足了。

Laurie took Amy to drive, which was a deed of charity, for the sour cream seemed to have had a bad effect upon her temper. Mrs. March came home to find the three older girls hard at work in the middle of the afternoon, and a glance at the closet gave her an idea of the success of one part of the experiment.
劳里带艾米开车，这是一种慈善行为，因为酸奶油似乎对她的脾气产生了不好的影响。下午，马奇太太回到家，发现三个大一点的女孩正在努力工作，她看了一眼衣柜，就知道实验的一部分很成功。

Before the housewives could rest, several people called, and there was a scramble to get ready to see them. Then tea must be got, errands done, and one or two necessary bits of sewing neglected until the last minute. As twilight fell, dewy and still, one by one they gathered on the porch where the June roses were budding beautifully, and each groaned or sighed as she sat down, as if tired or troubled.
家庭主妇们还没来得及休息，就有几个人打来电话，争先恐后地准备去见她们。然后必须去喝茶，完成差事，直到最后一刻才忽略一两件必要的缝纫工作。暮色降临，带着露水，寂静无声，她们一朵一朵地聚集在门廊上，那里六月玫瑰正绽放着美丽的花蕾，每个人坐下时都呻吟或叹息，仿佛疲倦或烦恼。

‘What a dreadful day this has been!’ began Jo, usually the first to speak.
“这是多么可怕的一天啊！”乔开始说道，她通常是第一个说话的。

‘It has seemed shorter than usual, but so uncomfortable,’ said Meg.
“它看起来比平常短，但很不舒服，”梅格说。

‘Not a bit like home,’ added Amy.
“一点也不像家，”艾米补充道。

‘It can’t seem so without Marmee and little Pip,’ sighed Beth, glancing with full eyes at the empty cage above her head.
“如果没有妈妈和小皮普，事情就不可能这样了。”贝丝叹了口气，睁大眼睛看着头顶上空空如也的笼子。

‘Here’s Mother, dear, and you shall have another bird tomorrow, if you want it.’
“这是妈妈，亲爱的，如果你想要的话，明天你还会再养一只鸟。”

As she spoke, Mrs. March came and took her place among them, looking as if her holiday had not been much pleasanter than theirs.
她说话的时候，马奇太太走过来，坐在他们中间，看上去她的假期并不比他们愉快多少。

‘Are you satisfied with your experiment, girls, or do you want another week of it?’ she asked, as Beth nestled up to her and the rest turned toward her with brightening faces, as flowers turn toward the sun.
“姑娘们，你们对自己的实验满意吗？还是还想再进行一周？”她问道，贝丝依偎在她身边，其他人都面带笑容地转向她，就像花朵转向太阳一样。

‘I don’t!’ cried Jo decidedly.
“我不！”乔坚决地喊道。

‘Nor I,’ echoed the others.
“我也没有，”其他人附和道。

‘You think then, that it is better to have a few duties and live a little for others, do you?’
“那么你认为，承担一些责任并为别人生活一点更好，是吗？”

‘Lounging and larking doesn’t pay,’ observed Jo, shaking her head. ‘I’m tired of it and mean to go to work at something right off.’
“闲逛和嬉闹是没有好处的，”乔摇着头说道。 “我厌倦了，打算马上去做点什么。”

‘Suppose you learn plain cooking. That’s a useful accomplishment, which no woman should be without,’ said Mrs. March, laughing inaudibly at the recollection of Jo’s dinner party, for she had met Miss Crocker and heard her account of it.
‘假设你学习简单的烹饪。这是一项有用的成就，任何女人都不应没有它。”马奇夫人回忆起乔的晚宴，无声地笑了起来，因为她见过克罗克小姐，也听过她的讲述。

‘Mother, did you go away and let everything be, just to see how we’d get on?’ cried Meg, who had had suspicions all day.
“妈妈，你离开并让一切都顺其自然，只是为了看看我们相处得怎么样吗？”一整天都心存疑虑的梅格喊道。

‘Yes, I wanted you to see how the comfort of all depends on each doing her share faithfully. While Hannah and I did your work, you got on pretty well, though I don’t think you were very happy or amiable. So I thought, as a little lesson, I would show you what happens when everyone thinks only of herself. Don’t you feel that it is pleasanter to help one another, to have daily duties which make leisure sweet when it comes, and to bear and forbear, that home may be comfortable and lovely to us all?’
“是的，我想让你看到所有人的舒适如何取决于每个人忠实地履行自己的职责。当汉娜和我做你的工作时，你相处得很好，尽管我不认为你很快乐或和蔼可亲。所以我想，作为一个小教训，我会向你们展示当每个人只考虑自己时会发生什么。难道你不觉得互相帮助、承担日常职责、让闲暇变得甜蜜、忍受和隐忍，让我们大家的家变得舒适和可爱，是更令人愉快的事吗？

‘We do, Mother we do!’ cried the girls.
“我们愿意，妈妈，我们愿意！”女孩们喊道。

‘Then let me advise you to take up your little burdens again, for though they seem heavy sometimes, they are good for us, and lighten as we learn to carry them. Work is wholesome, and there is plenty for everyone. It keeps us from ennui and mischief, is good for health and spirits, and gives us a sense of power and independence better than money or fashion.’
‘那么，让我建议你再次承担起你的小负担，因为虽然它们有时看起来很重，但它们对我们有好处，当我们学会承担它们时，它们就会减轻。工作是有益健康的，每个人都能得到很多。它让我们远离无聊和恶作剧，有益于健康和精神，比金钱或时尚更能赋予我们力量和独立感。

‘We’ll work like bees, and love it too, see if we don’t,’ said Jo. ‘I’ll learn plain cooking for my holiday task, and the dinner party I have shall be a success.’
“我们会像蜜蜂一样工作，并且也喜欢它，看看我们是否不这样做，”乔说。 “我会为我的假期任务学习简单的烹饪，我的晚宴一定会成功。”

‘I’ll make the set of shirts for father, instead of letting you do it, Marmee. I can and I will, though I’m not fond of sewing. That will be better than fussing over my own things, which are plenty nice enough as they are.’ said Meg.
“我会为父亲做一套衬衫，而不是让你来做，妈咪。我可以而且我会的，尽管我不喜欢缝纫。这比为自己的东西大惊小怪要好，因为它们本来就已经足够好了。”梅格说。

‘I’ll do my lessons every day, and not spend so much time with my music and dolls. I am a stupid thing, and ought to be studying, not playing,’ was Beth’s resolution, while Amy followed their example by heroically declaring, ‘I shall learn to make buttonholes, and attend to my parts of speech.’
