一位俄罗斯王子屈尊坐在角落里与一位身材魁梧的女士交谈了一个小时，这位女士穿着像哈姆雷特的母亲一样的黑色天鹅绒，下巴下戴着珍珠缰绳。一位十八岁的波兰伯爵全心全意地为女士们服务，女士们称他为“一位令人着迷的亲爱的”，而一位德国的宁静的东西，独自来吃晚饭，茫然地四处闲逛，寻找他可以吞下的东西。罗斯柴尔德男爵的私人秘书是一位穿着紧身靴子的大鼻子犹太人，和蔼可亲地对着世界微笑，仿佛他主人的名字给他戴上了金色的光环。一位认识皇帝的胖法国人来满足他对舞蹈的狂热，英国主妇德·琼斯夫人带着她的八口之家点缀了这一场景。当然，有许多脚步轻快、声音尖锐的美国女孩，英俊而毫无生气的英国女孩，还有一些朴素但辛辣的法国少女，就像常见的一群旅行的年轻绅士，他们快乐地玩耍，而所有的妈妈当他们和自己的女儿们跳舞时，各国人民沿着城墙排列，向他们亲切地微笑。

Any young girl can imagine Amy’s state of mind when she ‘took the stage’ that night, leaning on Laurie’s arm. She knew she looked well, she loved to dance, she felt that her foot was on her native heath in a ballroom, and enjoyed the delightful sense of power which comes when young girls first discover the new and lovely kingdom they are born to rule by virtue of beauty, youth, and womanhood. She did pity the Davis girls, who were awkward, plain, and destitute of escort, except a grim papa and three grimmer maiden aunts, and she bowed to them in her friendliest manner as she passed, which was good of her, as it permitted them to see her dress, and burn with curiosity to know who her distinguished-looking friend might be. With the first burst of the band, Amy’s color rose, her eyes began to sparkle, and her feet to tap the floor impatiently, for she danced well and wanted Laurie to know it. Therefore the shock she received can better be imagined than described, when he said in a perfectly tranquil tone, ‘Do you care to dance?’
任何年轻女孩都可以想象艾米那天晚上靠着劳里的手臂“走上舞台”时的心态。她知道自己看起来很漂亮，她喜欢跳舞，她觉得自己的脚踩在舞厅里的原生石地上，享受着当年轻女孩第一次发现她们生来要统治的新而可爱的王国时所带来的令人愉悦的力量感。美丽、青春和女人味的美德。她确实可怜戴维斯家的女孩们，除了一个冷酷的爸爸和三个冷酷的未婚阿姨之外，她们笨拙、相貌平庸，没有人护送，她经过时以最友好的方式向她们鞠躬，这对她来说是件好事，因为它允许他们好奇地想看看她的衣服，想知道她那位相貌高贵的朋友可能是谁。随着乐队的第一声爆发，艾米的脸色涨红了，她的眼睛开始闪闪发光，她的脚不耐烦地敲着地板，因为她跳得很好，想让劳里知道这一点。因此，当他用完全平静的语气说：“你想跳舞吗？”时，她所受到的震惊是可以想象的，而不是描述的。

‘One usually does at a ball.’
“人们通常在舞会上这样做。”

Her amazed look and quick answer caused Laurie to repair his error as fast as possible.
她惊讶的表情和快速的回​​答使劳里尽快纠正了他的错误。

‘I meant the first dance. May I have the honor?’
“我指的是第一支舞。我可以有幸吗？

‘I can give you one if I put off the Count. He dances devinely, but he will excuse me, as you are an old friend,’ said Amy, hoping that the name would have a good effect, and show Laurie that she was not to be trifled with.
“如果我推迟伯爵的话，我可以给你一份。”他跳舞跳得非常美妙，不过他会原谅我的，因为你是我的老朋友了。”艾米说道，希望这个名字能起到很好的效果，让劳里知道她是不好惹的。

‘Nice little boy, but rather a short Pole to support . .. A daughter of the gods, Devinely tall, and most devinely fair,’
“不错的小男孩，但需要支撑一根短杆。” ..众神的女儿，极其高大，极其美丽，”

was all the satisfaction she got, however.
然而，这就是她得到的全部满足。

The set in which they found themselves was composed of English, and Amy was compelled to walk decorously through a cotillion, feeling all the while as if she could dance the tarantella with relish. Laurie resigned her to the ‘nice little boy’, and went to do his duty to Flo, without securing Amy for the joys to come, which reprehensible want of forethought was properly punished, for she immediately engaged herself till supper, meaning to relent if he then gave any signs penitence. She showed him her ball book with demure satisfaction when he strolled instead of rushed up to claim her for the next, a glorious polka redowa. But his polite regrets didn’t impose upon her, and when she galloped away with the Count, she saw Laurie sit down by her aunt with an actual expression of relief.
他们发现自己所处的场景是由英语组成的，艾米被迫优雅地走过舞会，一直感觉自己好像可以津津有味地跳塔兰泰拉舞。劳里把她交给了“好小男孩”，然后去履行他对弗洛的职责，没有确保艾米享受即将到来的欢乐，这种应受谴责的缺乏深谋远虑的行为受到了适当的惩罚，因为她立即忙到晚饭，打算放松一下，如果然后他做出了任何忏悔的迹象。当他漫步而不是冲上来要求她参加下一场光荣的波尔卡雷多瓦舞时，她带着端庄的满足向他展示了她的球册。但他礼貌的遗憾并没有强加给她，当她和伯爵一起飞奔而去时，她看到劳里坐在她姨妈旁边，脸上露出真正松了口气的表情。

That was unpardonable, and Amy took no more notice of him for a long while, except a word now and then when she came to her chaperon between the dances for a necessary pin or a moment’s rest. Her anger had a good effect, however, for she hid it under a smiling face, and seemed unusually blithe and brilliant. Laurie’s eyes followed her with pleasure, for she neither romped nor sauntered, but danced with spirit and grace, making the delightsome pastime what it should be. He very naturally fell to studying her from this new point of view, and before the evening was half over, had decided that ‘little Amy was going to make a very charming woman’.
这是不可原谅的，艾米很长一段时间都没有再理会他，除了在舞会间隙走到她的监护人那里进行必要的别针或片刻休息时，偶尔说一句话。不过，她的愤怒却起到了很好的效果，因为她把愤怒隐藏在微笑之下，显得异常的愉快和聪明。劳里的目光愉快地追随着她，因为她既不嬉戏也不闲逛，而是充满活力和优雅地跳舞，使这种令人愉悦的消遣成为本应有的样子。他很自然地开始从这个新的角度来研究她，在晚上过半之前，他决定“小艾米会成为一个非常迷人的女人”。

It was a lively scene, for soon the spirit of the social season took possession of everyone, and Christmas merriment made all faces shine, hearts happy, and heels light. The musicians fiddled, tooted, and banged as if they enjoyed it, everybody danced who could, and those who couldn’t admired their neighbors with uncommon warmth. The air was dark with Davises, and many Jones gamboled like a flock of young giraffes. The golden secretary darted through the room like a meteor with a dashing frenchwoman who carped the floor with her pink satin train. The serene Teuton found the supper table and was happy, eating steadily through the bill of fare, and dismayed the garcons by the ravages he committed. But the Emperor’s friend covered himself with glory, for he danced everything, whether he knew it or not, and introduced impromptu pirouettes when the figures bewildered him. The boyish abandon of that stout man was charming to behold, for though he ‘carried weight’, he danced like an India-rubber ball. He ran, he flew, he pranced, his face glowed, his bald head shown, his coattails waved wildly, his pumps actually twinkled in the air, and when the music stopped, he wiped the drops from his brow, and beamed upon his fellow men like a French Pickwick without glasses.
这是一个热闹的场面，很快，社交季节的气氛就笼罩了每个人，圣诞节的欢乐让每个人的脸上都焕发着光彩，心中充满了快乐，脚后跟也变得轻盈起来。音乐家们演奏着小提琴，吹着喇叭，敲着，好像他们很享受，每个能跳舞的人都跳舞，而那些不能跳舞的人则以不同寻常的热情钦佩他们的邻居。戴维斯的空气一片漆黑，许多琼斯像一群小长颈鹿一样嬉戏。金色秘书像流星一样冲过房间，身边是一位风度翩翩的法国女人，她的粉红色缎子裾裙拖地地板。平静的条顿人找到了晚饭桌，他很高兴，稳定地吃完账单，他所犯下的破坏令加尔康人感到沮丧。但皇帝的朋友却洋溢着荣耀，因为无论他是否知道，他都会跳舞，当那些人物让他感到困惑时，他就会即兴旋转。那个粗壮的男人孩子气的放纵看上去很迷人，因为尽管他“负重”，但他跳舞却像印度橡皮球一样。他跑，他飞，他腾跃，他的脸容光焕发，他的光头露出来，他的燕尾服疯狂地挥舞，他的高跟鞋实际上在空中闪烁，当音乐停止时，他擦掉额头上的水滴，微笑着看着他的同伴男人就像不戴眼镜的法国匹克威克。

Amy and her Pole distinguished themselves by equal enthusiasm but more graceful agility, and Laurie found himself involuntarily keeping time to the rhythmic rise and fall of the white slippers as they flew by as indefatigably as if winged. When little Vladimir finally relinquished her, with assurances that he was ‘desolated to leave so early’, she was ready to rest, and see how her recreant knight had borne his punishment.
艾米和她的波兰人以同样的热情和更加优雅的敏捷而著称，劳里发现自己不由自主地跟上白色拖鞋有节奏的起落，因为它们不知疲倦地飞过，就像长了翅膀一样。当小弗拉基米尔最终放弃了她，并保证他“这么早离开很伤心”时，她准备休息，看看她那个胆怯的骑士如何承受他的惩罚。

It had been successful, for at three-and-twenty, blighted affections find a balm in friendly society, and young nerves will thrill, young blood dance, and healthy young spirits rise, when subjected to the enchantment of beauty, light, music, and motion. Laurie had a waked-up look as he rose to give her his seat, and when he hurried away to bring her some supper, she said to herself, with a satisfied smile, ‘Ah, I thought that would do him good!’
它是成功的，因为在三岁和二十岁的时候，枯萎的情感在友好的社会中找到了安慰，当受到美、光、音乐、和运动。当他起身给她让座时，劳里一脸清醒，当他匆​​匆走开去给她送晚饭时，她满意地微笑着对自己说：“啊，我想这对他有好处！”

‘You look like Balzac’s ‘FEMME PEINTE PAR ELLE-NENE’,’ he said, as he fanned her with one hand and held her coffee cup in the other.
“你看起来就像巴尔扎克的《FEMME PEINTE PAR ELLE-NENE》，”他一边说，一边用一只手为她扇风，另一只手握住她的咖啡杯。

‘My rouge won’t come off.’ And Amy rubbed her brilliant cheek, and showed him her white glove with a sober simplicity that made him laugh outright.
“我的胭脂不会掉下来。”艾米揉了揉她光彩照人的脸颊，向他展示了她的白手套，朴素的表情让他哈哈大笑。

‘What do you call this stuff?’ he asked, touching a fold of her dress that had blown over his knee.
“你管这个东西叫什么？”他问道，摸着她裙子上的一处被风吹过他膝盖的褶子。

‘Illusion.’
'错觉。'

‘Good name for it. It’s very pretty—new thing, isn’t it?’
‘这个名字起得好。它非常漂亮——新事物，不是吗？

‘It’s as old as the hills. You have seen it on dozens of girls, and you never found out that it was pretty till now? Stupide!’
‘它和山一样古老。你已经在几十个女孩身上看到过它，但你到现在都没发现它漂亮吗？蠢货！’

‘I never saw it on you before, which accounts for the mistake, you see.’
“我以前从没在你身上看到过它，这就是这个错误的原因，你瞧。”

‘None of that, it is forbidden. I’d rather take coffee than compliments just now. No, don’t lounge, it makes me nervous.’
‘这都不是，这是禁止的。我现在宁愿喝咖啡也不愿接受赞美。不，别闲着，这让我紧张。”

Laurie sat bold upright, and meekly took her empty plate feeling an odd sort of pleasure in having ‘little Amy’ order him about, for she had lost her shyness now, and felt an irrestible desire to trample on him, as girls have a delightful way of doing when lords of creation show any signs of subjection.
劳里大胆地坐直了身子，温顺地接过她的空盘子，因为“小艾米”对他指手画脚，她感到一种奇怪的快乐，因为她现在已经不再害羞了，她感到一种不可抗拒的想要踩在他身上的欲望，就像女孩子们有一种令人愉快的感觉一样。当造物之主表现出任何屈服迹象时的做法。

‘Where did you learn all this sort of thing?’ he asked with a quizzical look.
“你从哪里学到这些东西的？”他一脸疑惑地问道。

‘As ‘this sort of thing’ is rather a vague expression, would you kindly explain?’ returned Amy, knowing perfectly well what he meant, but wickedly leaving him to describe what is indescribable.
“‘这种事’是一个相当模糊的表达，你能解释一下吗？”艾米回答道，她完全明白他的意思，但邪恶地让他去描述那些难以描述的事情。

‘Well—the general air, the style, the self-possession, the— the—illusion—you know’, laughed Laurie, breaking down and helping himself out of his quandary with the new word.
“嗯——整体氛围、风格、沉着、——你知道的——幻觉”，劳里笑着说，他崩溃了，用这个新词帮助自己摆脱了困境。

Amy was gratified, but of course didn’t show it, and demurely answered, ‘Foreign life polishes one in spite of one’s self. I study as well as play, and as for this’—with a little gesture toward her dress—‘why, tulle is cheap, posies to be had for nothing, and I am used to making the most of my poor little things.’
艾米心中一喜，但当然没有表现出来，故作端庄地回答道：“异国生活不顾一切磨砺人。”我一边学习一边玩耍，至于这一点——对着她的衣服做了个手势——“为什么，薄纱很便宜，花束是免费的，而我习惯于充分利用我可怜的小东西。”

Amy rather regretted that last sentence, fearing it wasn’t in good taste, but Laurie liked her better for it, and found himself both admiring and respecting the brave patience that made the most of opportunity, and the cheerful spirit that covered poverty with flowers. Amy did not know why he looked at her so kindly, now why he filled up her book with his own name, and devoted himself to her for the rest of the evening in the most delightful manner, but the impulse that wrought this agreeable change was the result of one of the new impressions which both of them were unconsciously giving and receiving.
艾米对最后一句话感到相当后悔，担心这不合时宜，但劳里因此更喜欢她，并发现自己既钦佩又尊重她充分利用机会的勇敢耐心，以及用鲜花掩盖贫困的快乐精神。 。艾米不知道他为什么如此友善地看着她，为什么他在她的书上填满了自己的名字，并以最令人愉快的方式在整个晚上把自己奉献给了她，但造成这种令人愉快的变化的冲动是这是他们两人无意识地给予和接受的一种新印象的结果。

CHAPTER THIRTY-EIGHT
第三十八章

In France the young girls have a dull time of it till they are married, when ‘Vive la liberte!’ becomes their motto. In America, as everyone knows, girls early sign the declaration of independence, and enjoy their freedom with republican zest, but the young matrons usually abdicate with the first heir to the throne and go into a seclusion almost as close as a French nunnery, though by no means as quiet. Whether they like it or not, they are virtually put upon the shelf as soon as the wedding excitement is over, and most of them might exclaim, as did a very pretty woman the other day, ‘I’m as handsome as ever, but no one takes any notice of me because I’m married.’
在法国，年轻女孩在结婚之前会度过一段无聊的时光，“自由万岁！”成为她们的座右铭。众所周知，在美国，女孩们很早就签署了独立宣言，带着共和主义的热情享受着自由，但年轻的主妇们通常会和第一任王位继承人一起退位，然后隐居到几乎像法国修道院一样的地方。绝不是那么安静。不管他们喜欢与否，一旦婚礼的兴奋一结束，他们实际上就被束之高阁了，他们中的大多数人可能会像前几天一个非常漂亮的女人那样惊呼，“我和以前一样英俊，但是没有人注意到我，因为我已经结婚了。”

Not being a belle or even a fashionable lady, Meg did not experience this affliction till her babies were a year old, for in her little world primitive customs prevailed, and she found herself more admired and beloved than ever.
梅格不是一个美女，甚至不是一个时尚女士，直到她的孩子一岁时才经历这种痛苦，因为在她的小世界里，原始习俗盛行，她发现自己比以往任何时候都更受钦佩和爱戴。

As she was a womanly little woman, the maternal instinct was very strong, and she was entirely absorbed in her children, to the utter exclusion of everything and everybody else. Day and night she brooded over them with tireless devotion and anxiety, leaving John to the tender mercies of the help, for an Irish lady now presided over the kitchen department. Being a domestic man, John decidedly missed the wifely attentions he had been accustomed to receive, but as he adored his babies, he cheerfully relinquished his comfort for a time, supposing with masculine ignorance that peace would soon be restored. But three months passed, and there was no return of repose. Meg looked worn and nervous, the babies absorbed every minute of her time, the house was neglected, and Kitty, the cook, who took life ‘aisy’, kept him on short commons. When he went out in the morning he was bewildered by small commissions for the captive mamma, if he came gaily in at night, eager to embrace his family, he was quenched by a ‘Hush! They are just asleep after worrying all day.’ If he proposed a little amusement at home, ‘No, it would disturb the babies.’ If he hinted at a lecture or a concert, he was answered with a reproachful look, and a decided ‘Leave my children for pleasure, never!’ His sleep was broken by infant wails and visions of a phantom figure pacing noiselessly to and fro in the watches of the night. His meals were interrupted by the frequent flight of the presiding genius, who deserted him, half-helped, if a muffled chirp sounded from the nest above. And when he read his paper of an evening, Demi’s colic got into the shipping list and Daisy’s fall affected the price of stocks, for Mrs. Brooke was only interested in domestic news.
由于她是一个有女人味的小女人，母性本能非常强烈，她完全专注于自己的孩子，完全排斥一切和其他人。她日以继夜地以不知疲倦的奉献和焦虑来照顾他们，让约翰得到温柔的帮助，因为现在由一位爱尔兰女士主持厨房部门。作为一个顾家的男人，约翰显然怀念他所习惯的妻子般的关注，但由于他爱他的孩子，他高兴地暂时放弃了他的舒适，以男性的无知认为和平很快就会恢复。但三个月过去了，还没有恢复平静。梅格看起来疲惫而紧张，孩子们把她的每一分钟都投入其中，房子被忽视了，基蒂，这位厨师，过着“轻松”的生活，让他的公地资源短缺。当他早上出去时，他会对被俘虏的妈妈的小任务感到困惑，如果他晚上高兴地回来，渴望拥抱他的家人，他会被一声“嘘！他们担心了一整天之后就睡着了。”如果他提议在家里搞一点娱乐活动，“不，这会打扰婴儿。”如果他暗示要举办一场讲座或一场音乐会，他得到的回答是责备的表情和坚决的态度。 “让我的孩子们去享乐吧，永远不要！”他的睡眠被婴儿的哭声和夜里无声地来回踱步的幻影所打破。他的饭菜被主持的天才的频繁飞行打断了，如果上面的鸟巢里传来一声低沉的叽叽喳喳声，他就会半途而废地抛弃他。当他读到晚上的报纸时，黛米的肠绞痛进入了发货清单，黛西的跌倒影响了股票价格，因为布鲁克夫人只对国内新闻感兴趣。

The poor man was very uncomfortable, for the children had bereft him of his wife, home was merely a nursery and the perpetual ‘hushing’ made him feel like a brutal intruder whenever he entered the sacred precincts of Babyland. He bore it very patiently for six months, and when no signs of amendment appeared, he did what other paternal exiles do—tried to get a little comfort elsewhere. Scott had married and gone to housekeeping not far off, and John fell into the way of running over for an hour or two of an evening, when his own parlor was empty, and his own wife singing lullabies that seemed to have no end. Mrs. Scott was a lively, pretty girl, with nothing to do but be agreeable, and she performed her mission most successfully. The parlor was always bright and attractive, the chessboard ready, the piano in tune, plenty of gay gossip, and a nice little supper set forth in tempting style.
这个可怜的男人感到非常不舒服，因为孩子们失去了他的妻子，家只是一个托儿所，永远的“安静”让他每次进入巴比兰的神圣区域时都感觉自己像一个残酷的入侵者。他非常耐心地忍受了六个月，当没有出现任何改变的迹象时，他做了其他父亲流亡者所做的事情——试图在别处得到一点安慰。斯科特已经结婚了，去不远的地方做家务，而约翰则陷入了每天晚上跑过来一两个小时的习惯，那时他自己的客厅空无一人，而他自己的妻子则唱着似乎没完没了的摇篮曲。斯科特夫人是一个活泼、漂亮的女孩，除了和蔼可亲之外无所事事，她非常成功地完成了她的使命。客厅总是明亮而迷人，棋盘准备好了，钢琴调准了，有很多同性恋的八卦，还有一顿诱人的小晚餐。

John would have preferred his own fireside if it had not been so lonely, but as it was he gratefully took the next best thing and enjoyed his neighbor’s society.
如果不是那么孤独的话，约翰会更喜欢自己的炉边，但事实上，他感激地接受了退而求其次的选择，并享受与邻居的交往。

Meg rather approved of the new arrangement at first, and found it a relief to know that John was having a good time instead of dozing in the parlor, or tramping about the house and waking the children. But by-and-by, when the teething worry was over and the idols went to sleep at proper hours, leaving Mamma time to rest, she began to miss John, and find her workbasket dull company, when he was not sitting opposite in his old dressing gown, comfortably scorching his slippers on the fender. She would not ask him to stay at home, but felt injured because he did not know that she wanted him without being told, entirely forgetting the many evenings he had waited for her in vain. She was nervous and worn out with watching and worry, and in that unreasonable frame of mind which the best of mothers occasionally experience when domestic cares oppress them. Want of exercise robs them of cheerfulness, and too much devotion to that idol of American women, the teapot, makes them feel as if they were all nerve and no muscle.
梅格一开始相当赞同这个新安排，当知道约翰玩得很开心，而不是在客厅里打瞌睡，或者在房子里走来走去，吵醒孩子们时，她感到很欣慰。但渐渐地，当出牙期的忧虑过去了，偶像们在适当的时间入睡，让妈妈有时间休息时，她开始想念约翰，发现她的工作篮无聊地陪伴着他，因为他没有坐在他对面的座位上。旧晨衣，拖鞋在挡泥板上舒服地烤焦。她不会要求他留在家里，但她感到很受伤，因为他不知道她在没有告诉的情况下想要他，完全忘记了他徒劳地等待她的许多个夜晚。她因注视和担心而感到紧张和疲惫，并且处于那种不合理的心态中，这是最好的母亲在家庭琐事压迫她们时偶尔会经历的。缺乏锻炼使她们失去了快乐，而过多地迷恋美国女性的偶像——茶壶，​​又让她们觉得自己神经兮兮，没有肌肉。

‘Yes,’ she would say, looking in the glass, ‘I’m getting old and ugly. John doesn’t find me interesting any longer, so he leaves his faded wife and goes to see his pretty neighbor, who has no incumbrances. Well, the babies love me, they don’t care if I am thin and pale and haven’t time to crimp my hair, they are my comfort, and some day John will see what I’ve gladly sacrificed for them, won’t he, my precious?’
“是的，”她看着镜子说，“我变老了，也变丑了。”约翰不再觉得我有趣了，所以他离开了他褪色的妻子，去看他漂亮的邻居，她没有任何负担。好吧，孩子们爱我，他们不在乎我是否又瘦又苍白，也没有时间卷曲我的头发，他们是我的安慰，有一天约翰会看到我欣然为他们牺牲的一切，不会的。是吗，我的宝贝？

To which pathetic appeal daisy would answer with a coo, or Demi with a crow, and Meg would put by her lamentations for a maternal revel, which soothed her solitude for the time being. But the pain increased as politics absorbed John, who was always running over to discuss interesting points with Scott, quite unconscious that Meg missed him. Not a word did she say, however, till her mother found her in tears one day, and insisted on knowing what the matter was, for Meg’s drooping spirits had not escaped her observation.
黛西会用咕咕声回应可怜的请求，或者黛米用乌鸦回应，而梅格会放下她的哀叹，转​​而享受母性的狂欢，这暂时缓解了她的孤独。但随着政治的介入，约翰的痛苦也随之增加，约翰总是跑过去和斯科特讨论有趣的观点，完全没有意识到梅格想念他。然而，她一言不发，直到有一天她母亲发现她在流泪，并坚持要知道发生了什么事，因为梅格低落的情绪没有逃过她的观察。

‘I wouldn’t tell anyone except you, Mother, but I really do need advice, for if John goes on much longer I might as well be widowed,’ replied Mrs. Brooke, drying her tears on Daisy’s bib with an injured air.
“除了你，我不会告诉任何人，妈妈，但我确实需要建议，因为如果约翰再这样下去，我还不如守寡呢。”布鲁克太太回答道，用黛西的围脖擦干眼泪，神情受伤。

‘Goes on how, my dear?’ asked her mother anxiously.
“怎么样了，亲爱的？”妈妈焦急地问。

‘He’s away all day, and at night when I want to see him, he is continually going over to the Scotts’. It isn’t fair that I should have the hardest work, and never any amusement. Men are very selfish, even the best of them.’
“他整天都不在家，晚上当我想见他时，他总是去找斯科特一家。”我应该从事最艰苦的工作，却没有任何娱乐，这是不公平的。男人都是非常自私的，即使是最优秀的人也是如此。”

‘So are women. Don’t blame John till you see where you are wrong yourself.’
‘女人也是如此。在你自己明白自己错在哪里之前，不要责怪约翰。

‘But it can’t be right for him to neglect me.’
“但他忽视我是不对的。”

‘Don’t you neglect him?’
“你没有忽视他吗？”

‘Why, Mother, I thought you’d take my part!’
“哎呀，妈妈，我以为你会支持我呢！”

‘So I do, as far as sympathizing goes, but I think the fault is yours, Meg.’
“就同情而言，我确实这么做，但我认为错在你，梅格。”

‘I don’t see how.’
“我不明白怎么办。”

‘Let me show you. Did John ever neglect you, as you call it, while you made it a point to give him your society of an evening, his only leisure time?’
'我来给你展示。约翰有没有忽视过你，正如你所说的那样，而你却特意给他一个晚上的陪伴，这是他唯一的休闲时间？

‘No, but I can’t do it now, with two babies to tend.’
“不，但我现在不能这么做，因为我要照顾两个孩子。”

‘I think you could, dear, and I think you ought. May I speak quite freely, and will you remember that it’s Mother who blames as well as Mother who sympathizes?’
“我认为你可以，亲爱的，而且我认为你应该这样做。我可以畅所欲言吗？你还记得吗，责怪的是母亲，同情的也是母亲？

‘Indeed I will! Speak to me as if I were little Meg again. I often feel as if I needed teaching more than ever since these babies look to me for everything.’
‘我确实会的！跟我说话，就像我又是小梅格一样。我常常觉得自己比以往任何时候都更需要教学，因为这些婴儿的一切都指望我。”

Meg drew her low chair beside her mother’s, and with a little interruption in either lap, the two women rocked and talked lovingly together, feeling that the tie of motherhood made them more one than ever.
梅格把她的矮椅子拉到她母亲的旁边，两个女人在两边的腿上稍稍休息了一下，摇晃着，亲切地交谈着，感觉母性的纽带使她们比以往任何时候都更加团结。

‘You have only made the mistake that most young wives make-forgotten your duty to your husband in your love for your children. A very natural and forgivable mistake, Meg, but one that had better be remedied before you take to different ways, for children should draw you nearer than ever, not separate you, as if they were all yours, and John had nothing to do but support them. I’ve seen it for some weeks, but have not spoken, feeling sure it would come right in time.’
“你只是犯了大多数年轻妻子常犯的错误——在爱孩子的过程中忘记了对丈夫的责任。这是一个非常自然和可以原谅的错误，梅格，但在你采取不同的方式之前最好纠正这个错误，因为孩子们应该比以往任何时候都更接近你，而不是分开你，就好像他们都是你的，而约翰无事可做，除了支持他们。我已经看到它好几个星期了，但没有说话，我确信它会及时到来。”

‘I’m afraid it won’t. If I ask him to stay, he’ll think I’m jealous, and I wouldn’t insult him by such an idea. He doesn’t see that I want him, and I don’t know how to tell him without words.’
‘恐怕不会。如果我让他留下来，他会认为我嫉妒，而我不会用这样的想法来侮辱他。他没有看出我想要他，我不知道如何不用言语告诉他。

‘Make it so pleasant he won’t want to go away. My dear, he’s longing for his little home, but it isn’t home without you, and you are always in the nursery.’
‘让一切变得如此愉快，他不想离开。亲爱的，他渴望他的小家，但没有你就不是家，而你总是在托儿所里。

‘Oughtn’t I to be there?’
“我不应该在那儿吗？”

‘Not all the time, too much confinement makes you nervous, and then you are unfitted for everything. Besides, you owe something to John as well as to the babies. Don’t neglect husband for children, don’t shut him out of the nursery, but teach him how to help in it. His place is there as well as yours, and the children need him. Let him feel that he has a part to do, and he will do it gladly and faithfully, and it will be better for you all.’
“并非总是如此，太多的限制会让你紧张，然后你就无法适应一切。此外，你还欠约翰和孩子们一些东西。不要为了孩子而忽视丈夫，不要把他拒之门外，而要教他如何帮忙。他的位置和你的一样，孩子们需要他。让他觉得他有自己的职责要做，他会高兴而忠实地去做，这对你们大家来说都会更好。

‘You really think so, Mother?’
“你真的这么认为吗，妈妈？”

‘I know it, Meg, for I’ve tried it, and I seldom give advice unless I’ve proved its practicability. When you and Jo were little, I went on just as you are, feeling as if I didn’t do my duty unless I devoted myself wholly to you. Poor Father took to his books, after I had refused all offers of help, and left me to try my experiment alone. I struggled along as well as I could, but Jo was too much for me. I nearly spoiled her by indulgence. You were poorly, and I worried about you till I fell sick myself. Then Father came to the rescue, quietly managed everything, and made himself so helpful that I saw my mistake, and never have been able to got on without him since. That is the secret of our home happiness. He does not let business wean him from the little cares and duties that affect us all, and I try not to let domestic worries destroy my interest in his pursuits. Each do our part alone in many things, but at home we work together, always.’
“我知道，梅格，因为我已经尝试过了，除非我证明了它的实用性，否则我很少提出建议。当你和乔还小的时候，我就和你们一样，觉得除非我把自己完全奉献给你们，否则我就没有尽到自己的职责。在我拒绝了所有的帮助后，可怜的父亲开始看他的书，留下我独自尝试我的实验。我尽我所能地挣扎着，但乔对我来说太难了。我的纵容几乎把她宠坏了。你身体不好，我很担心你，直到我自己也生病了。后来父亲出手相救，默默地处理着一切，他也帮了我很大的忙，让我认识到了自己的错误，从那以后，没有他我就再也活不下去了。这就是我们家庭幸福的秘诀。他并没有让生意让他放弃影响我们所有人的小事和责任，我也尽量不让家庭忧虑破坏我对他追求的兴趣。每个人在很多事情上都独自完成自己的部分，但在家里我们总是一起工作。

‘It is so, Mother, and my great wish is to be to my husband and children what you have been to yours. Show me how, I’ll do anything you say.’
“是的，母亲，我最大的愿望就是像您对待自己的丈夫和孩子一样。告诉我怎么做，我会照你说的做。

‘You were always my docile daughter. Well, dear, if I were you, I’d let John have more to do with the management of Demi, for the boy needs training, and it’s none too soon to begin. Then I’d do what I have often proposed, let Hannah come and help you. She is a capital nurse, and you may trust the precious babies to her while you do more housework. You need the exercise, Hannah would enjoy the rest, and John would find his wife again. Go out more, keep cheerful as well as busy, for you are the sunshine-maker of the family, and if you get dismal there is no fair weather. Then I’d try to take an interest in whatever John likes—talk with him, let him read to you, exchange ideas, and help each other in that way. Don’t shut yourself up in a bandbox because you are a woman, but understand what is going on, and educate yourself to take your part in the world’s work, for it all affects you and yours.’
‘你一直是我温顺的女儿。好吧，亲爱的，如果我是你，我会让约翰更多地参与黛米的管理，因为这个男孩需要训练，而且现在开始还不算太早。然后我会按照我经常建议的那样，让汉娜来帮助你。她是一名首都护士，你可以在做更多家务的同时，把宝贝宝宝托付给她。你需要锻炼，汉娜会享受休息，约翰会再次找到他的妻子。多出去走走，保持心情愉快，忙碌起来，因为你是家里的阳光制造者，心情郁闷就没有好天气。然后我会尝试对约翰喜欢的任何事情感兴趣——与他交谈，让他读书给你听，交换想法，并以这种方式互相帮助。不要因为你是一个女人而把自己关在乐队里，而是要了解正在发生的事情，并教育自己参与世界的工作，因为这一切都会影响你和你的家人。

‘John is so sensible, I’m afraid he will think I’m stupid if I ask questions about politics and things.’
“约翰很懂事，我担心如果我问政治之类的问题，他会认为我很蠢。”

‘I don’t believe he would. Love covers a multitude of sins, and of whom could you ask more freely than of him? Try it, and see if he doesn’t find your society far more agreeable than Mrs. Scott’s suppers.’
‘我不相信他会。爱能遮掩许多的罪孽，你还能向谁提出比他更自由的请求呢？试试吧，看看他是否觉得你们的交往比斯科特夫人的晚餐更令人愉快。

‘I will. Poor John! I’m afraid I have neglected him sadly, but I thought I was right, and he never said anything.’
'我会。可怜的约翰！我担心我悲伤地忽视了他，但我认为我是对的，他什么也没说。

‘He tried not to be selfish, but he has felt rather forlorn, I fancy. This is just the time, Meg, when young married people are apt to grow apart, and the very time when they ought to be most together, for the first tenderness soon wears off, unless care is taken to preserve it. And no time is so beautiful and precious to parents as the first years of the little lives given to them to train. Don’t let John be a stranger to the babies, for they will do more to keep him safe and happy in this world of trial and temptation than anything else, and through them you will learn to know and love one another as you should. Now, dear, good-by. Think over Mother’s preachment, act upon it if it seems good, and God bless you all.’
“他试图不自私，但我想他感到相当孤独。梅格，这正是年轻已婚人士容易疏远的时候，也是他们最应该在一起的时候，因为最初的温柔很快就会消失，除非小心翼翼地保存它。对于父母来说，没有什么时间比给予他们训练的小生命的最初几年更美好和珍贵了。不要让约翰对孩子们来说是一个陌生人，因为在这个充满考验和诱惑的世界里，他们会做更多的事情来让他安全和快乐，而不是其他任何事情，通过他们，你会学会按照你应该的方式去了解和爱彼此。现在，亲爱的，再见。想想母亲的说教，如果觉得不错就付诸行动，愿上帝保佑你们大家。”

Meg did think it over, found it good, and acted upon it, though the first attempt was not made exactly as she planned to have it. Of course the children tyrannized over her, and ruled the house as soon as they found out that kicking and squalling brought them whatever they wanted. Mamma was an abject slave to their caprices, but Papa was not so easily subjugated, and occasionally afflicted his tender spouse by an attempt at paternal discipline with his obstreperous son. For Demi inherited a trifle of his sire’s firmness of character, we won’t call it obstinacy, and when he made up his little to have or to do anything, all the king’s horses and all the king’s men could not change that pertinacious little mind. Mamma thought the dear too young to be taught to conquer his prejudices, but Papa believed that it never was too soon to learn obedience. So Master Demi early discovered that when he undertook to ‘wrastle’ with ‘Parpar’, he always got the worst of it, yet like the Englishman, baby respected the man who conquered him, and loved the father whose grave ‘No, no,’ was more impressive than all Mamma’s love pats. A few days after the talk with her mother, Meg resolved to try a social evening with John, so she ordered a nice supper, set the parlor in order, dressed herself prettily, and put the children to bed early, that nothing should interfere with her experiment. But unfortunately Demi’s most unconquerable prejudice was against going to bed, and that night he decided to go on a rampage. So poor Meg sang and rocked, told stories and tried every sleep-prevoking wile she could devise, but all in vain, the big eyes wouldn’t shut, and long after Daisy had gone to byelow, like the chubby little bunch of good nature she was, naughty Demi lay staring at the light, with the most discouragingly wide-awake expression of countenance.
梅格确实仔细考虑过，发现它很好，并采取了行动，尽管第一次尝试并没有完全按照她的计划进行。当然，孩子们对她很专横，当他们发现踢打和吵闹可以为他们带来他们想要的任何东西时，他们就统治了这个房子。妈妈是他们反复无常的卑鄙奴隶，但爸爸却不那么容易屈服，有时，他试图以父亲般的方式管教他顽固的儿子，这让他温柔的妻子感到痛苦。因为黛米继承了他父亲的一点坚定的性格，我们不会称之为固执，当他下定决心要拥有或做任何事情时，国王的所有马匹和所有国王的人都无法改变那个顽固的小心思。 。妈妈认为亲爱的孩子还太小，不适合被教导去克服他的偏见，但爸爸相信，学习服从永远不会太早。所以黛米大师很早就发现，当他与“帕尔帕尔”“搏斗”时，他总是得到最坏的结果，但就像英国人一样，婴儿尊重征服他的人，并爱他的父亲，他的坟墓上写着“不，不， ”比妈妈所有的爱抚更令人印象深刻。与母亲谈话几天后，梅格决定尝试与约翰一起度过一个社交晚会，所以她订了一顿丰盛的晚餐，把客厅收拾得井井有条，把自己打扮得漂漂亮亮的，并让孩子们早点上床睡觉，以免任何事情干扰。她的实验。但不幸的是，黛米最无法克服的偏见是拒绝睡觉，那天晚上他决定横冲直撞。 可怜的梅格唱歌、摇晃、讲故事，尝试了她能想出的每一种令人入睡的诡计，但一切都是徒劳，那双大眼睛就是不肯闭上，黛西已经走了很久，就像那群善良的胖乎乎的小家伙一样。她是，顽皮的黛米躺在那里，盯着灯光，脸上带着最令人沮丧的清醒表情。

‘Will Demi lie still like a good boy, while Mamma runs down and gives poor Papa his tea?’ asked Meg, as the hall door softly closed, and the well-known step went tip-toeing into the dining room.
“当妈妈跑下来给可怜的爸爸倒茶时，黛米会像个好孩子一样安静地躺着吗？”梅格问道，门厅的门轻轻地关上了，人们开始蹑手蹑脚地走进餐厅。

‘Me has tea!’ said Demi, preparing to join in the revel.
“我有茶！”黛米说道，准备加入狂欢。

‘No, but I’ll save you some little cakies for breakfast, if you’ll go bye-by like Daisy. Will you, lovey?’
“不，但如果你能像黛西一样告别的话，我会给你留一些小蛋糕当早餐。”你愿意吗，亲爱的？

‘Iss!’ and Demi shut his eyes tight, as if to catch sleep and hurry the desired day.
“是！”黛米紧紧闭上眼睛，仿佛要睡一觉，尽快迎来想要的一天。

Taking advantage of the propitious moment, Meg slipped away and ran down to greet her husband with a smiling face and the little blue bow in her hair which was his especial admiration. He saw it at once and said with pleased surprise, ‘Why, little mother, how gay we are tonight. Do you expect company?’
趁着这个吉利的时刻，梅格溜了出去，跑下来迎接她的丈夫，脸上带着微笑，头上戴着的蓝色小蝴蝶结是他特别钦佩的。他立刻看到了，惊喜地说道：“哎呀，小妈妈，我们今晚多么快乐啊。”你需要有人陪伴吗？

‘Only you, dear.’
“只有你，亲爱的。”

‘No, I’m tired of being dowdy, so I dressed up as a change. You always make yourself nice for table, no matter how tired you are, so why shouldn’t I when I have the time?’
“不，我厌倦了邋遢，所以我打扮得有些改变。不管你有多累，你总是在餐桌上让自己变得漂亮，那么当我有时间的时候为什么我不应该呢？

‘I do it out of respect for you, my dear,’ said old-fashioned John.
“我这样做是出于对你的尊重，亲爱的，”老派的约翰说。

‘Ditto, ditto, Mr. Brooke,’ laughed Meg, looking young and pretty again, as she nodded to him over the teapot.
“同上，同上，布鲁克先生，”梅格笑着说，她在茶壶上向他点点头，看起来又年轻又漂亮了。

‘Well, it’s altogether delightful, and like old times. This tastes right. I drink your health, dear.’ And John sipped his tea with an air of reposeful rapture, which was of very short duration however, for as he put down his cup, the door handle rattled mysteriously, and a little voice was heard, saying impatiently ...
“嗯，这真是太令人愉快了，就像以前一样。这个味道对了。亲爱的，我为你的健康干杯。”约翰带着一种平静而狂喜的神情喝了一口茶，然而这持续的时间很短，因为当他放下杯子时，门把手神秘地嘎嘎作响，听到一个小小的声音，说不耐烦地...

‘Opy doy. Me’s tummin!’
‘哎呀，哎呀。我很烦！

‘It’s that naughty boy. I told him to go to sleep alone, and here he is, downstairs, getting his death a-cold pattering over that canvas,’ said Meg, answering the call.
‘就是那个调皮的孩子。我让他一个人去睡觉，而他就在楼下，在画布上冷冷地拍打着他的死亡。”梅格接电话说道。

‘Mornin’ now,’ announced Demi in joyful tone as he entered, with his long nightgown gracefully festooned over his arm and every curl bobbing gayly as he pranced about the table, eyeing the ‘cakies’ with loving glances.
“早上好，”黛米进来时用快乐的语气宣布，他的长睡衣优雅地披在手臂上，每根卷发都在桌子上欢快地摆动，用充满爱意的目光看着“蛋糕”。

‘No, it isn’t morning yet. You must go to bed, and not trouble poor Mamma. Then you can have the little cake with sugar on it.’
「不，现在还没到早上呢。」你必须去睡觉，不要打扰可怜的妈妈。然后你就可以吃上面加糖的小蛋糕了。

‘Me loves Parpar,’ said the artful one, preparing to climb the paternal knee and revel in forbidden joys. But John shook his head, and said to Meg...
“我爱帕尔帕尔。”狡猾的家伙说道，准备爬上父亲的膝盖，享受禁忌的欢乐。但约翰摇了摇头，对梅格说……

‘If you told him to stay up there, and go to sleep alone, make him do it, or he will never learn to mind you.’
“如果你让他留在上面，一个人去睡觉，就让他这么做，否则他永远不会学会关心你。”

‘Yes, of course. Come, Demi.’ And Meg led her son away, feeling a strong desire to spank the little marplot who hopped beside her, laboring under the delusion that the bribe was to be administered as soon as they reached the nursery.
'是的当然。来吧，黛米。”梅格领着她的儿子走了，她强烈地想打那个在她身边跳来跳去的小马普洛特，她误以为他们一到托儿所就会受到贿赂。

Nor was he disappointed, for that shortsighted woman actually gave him a lump of sugar, tucked him into his bed, and forbade any more promenades till morning.
他也没有失望，因为那个近视的女人实际上给了他一块糖，把他塞到床上，并禁止他在早上之前再散步。

‘Iss!’ said Demi the perjured, blissfully sucking his sugar, and regarding his first attempt as eminently successful.
“是的！”作伪证的黛米说道，幸福地吮吸着糖，并认为他的第一次尝试非常成功。

Meg returned to her place, and supper was progressing pleasantly, when the little ghost walked again and exposed the maternal delinquencies by boldly demanding, ‘More sudar, Marmar.’
梅格回到了自己的位置，晚餐正在愉快地进行着，这时小鬼魂又走了过来，大胆地要求“再来点苏达尔，马尔马尔”，揭露了母亲的过失。

‘Now this won’t do,’ said John, hardening his heart against the engaging little sinner. ‘We shall never know any peace till that child learns togo to bed properly. You have made a slave of yourself long enough. Give him one lesson, and then there will be an end of it. Put him in his bed and leave him, Meg.’
“现在这样不行了，”约翰说，对这个可爱的小罪人硬起了心肠。 “除非那个孩子学会正确睡觉，否则我们永远不会有任何平安。”你已经让自己成为奴隶已经够久了。给他一个教训，事情就会结束。让他躺在床上，然后离开他，梅格。”

‘He won’t stay there, he never does unless I sit by him.’
“他不会呆在那里，除非我坐在他身边，否则他永远不会呆在那里。”

‘I’ll manage him. Demi, go upstairs, and get into your bed, as Mamma bids you.’
‘我会管理他的。黛米，按照妈妈的吩咐，上楼去床上。”

‘S’ant!’ replied the young rebel, helping himself to the coveted ‘cakie’, and beginning to eat the same with calm audacity.
“S'ant！”年轻的叛逆者回答道，一边吃着令人垂涎的“蛋糕”，一边平静而大胆地开始吃起来。

‘You must never say that to Papa. I shall carry you if you don’t go yourself.’
“你绝对不能对爸爸说这种话。如果你不自己走，我就背你去。

‘Go ‘way, me don’t love Parpar.’ And Demi retired to his mother’s skirts for protection.
“走吧，我不爱帕尔帕尔。”黛米退到他母亲的裙子里寻求保护。

But even that refuge proved unavailing, for he was delivered over to the enemy, with a ‘Be gentle with him, John,’ which struck the culprit with dismay, for when Mamma deserted him, then the judgment day was at hand. Bereft of his cake, defrauded of his frolic, and borne away by a strong hand to that detested bed, poor Demi could not restrain his wrath, but openly defied Papa, and kicked and screamed lustily all the way upstairs. The minute he was put into bed on one side, he rolled out on the other, and made for the door, only to be ignominiously caught up by the tail of his little toga and put back again, which lively performance was kept up till the young man’s strength gave out, when he devoted himself to roaring at the top of his voice. This vocal exercise usually conquered Meg, but John sat as unmoved as the post which is popularly believed to be deaf. No coaxing, no sugar, no lullaby, no story, even the light was put out and only the red glow of the fire enlivened the ‘big dark’ which Demi regarded with curiosity rather than fear. This new order of things disgusted him, and he howled dismally for ‘Marmar’, as his angry passions subsided, and recollections of his tender bondwoman returned to the captive autocrat. The plaintive wail which succeeded the passionate roar went to Meg’s heart, and she ran up to say beseechingly...
但事实证明，即使这样的避难所也无济于事，因为他被交给了敌人，一句“对他温柔点，约翰”，这让罪犯感到沮丧，因为当妈妈抛弃他时，审判日就在眼前。他的蛋糕被剥夺了，他的嬉闹被骗了，被一只强有力的手拖到了那张可恶的床上，可怜的黛米无法抑制他的愤怒，而是公然蔑视爸爸，一路踢着，尖叫着上楼。他一被放到一侧的床上，就从另一侧滚了出去，向门口走去，却被他的小托加长袍的尾巴可耻地抓住了，又被放了回去，这种热闹的表演一直持续到了晚上。当年轻人全力以赴地咆哮时，他的力气已经耗尽。这种发声练习通常会征服梅格，但约翰却一动不动地坐着，就像人们普遍认为是聋子一样。没有哄骗，没有糖，没有摇篮曲，没有故事，连灯都熄灭了，只有火的红光照亮了黛米好奇而不是恐惧的“大黑暗”。这种新的秩序让他感到厌恶，当他愤怒的激情消退时，他凄凉地呼喊着“马尔马尔”，对他温柔的女奴的回忆又回到了被俘的独裁者身上。激昂的吼叫声接续着哀怨的哭声，直达梅格的心头，她跑上前去恳求地说……

‘Let me stay with him, he’ll be good now, John.’
“让我留在他身边，他现在会好起来的，约翰。”

‘No, my dear. I’ve told him he must go to sleep, as you bid him, and he must, if I stay here all night.’
'不是，亲爱的。我已经告诉他，他必须按照你的吩咐去睡觉，如果我整晚都待在这里，他也必须去睡觉。

‘But he’ll cry himself sick,’ pleaded Meg, reproaching herself for deserting her boy.
“但他会哭得恶心。”梅格恳求道，责备自己抛弃了儿子。

‘No, he won’t, he’s so tired he will soon drop off and then the matter is settled, for he will understand that he has got to mind. Don’t interfere, I’ll manage him.’
“不，他不会，他太累了，很快就会倒下，然后事情就解决了，因为他会明白他必须介意。”你别插手，我来对付他。”

‘He’s my child, and I can’t have his spirit broken by harshness.’
“他是我的孩子，我不能让他的精神被严厉打击。”

‘He’s my child, and I won’t have his temper spoiled by indulgence. Go down, my dear, and leave the boy to me.’
“他是我的孩子，我不会让他的脾气因为纵容而坏掉。”下去吧，亲爱的，把孩子留给我。

When John spoke in that masterful tone, Meg always obeyed, and never regretted her docility.
当约翰用那种专横的语气说话时，梅格总是服从，并且从不后悔她的顺从。

‘Please let me kiss him once, John?’
“约翰，请让我吻他一次好吗？”

‘Certainly. Demi, say good night to Mamma, and let her go and rest, for she is very tired with taking care of you all day.’
'当然。黛米，跟妈妈道晚安，让她去休息吧，因为她照顾你一整天已经很累了。”

Meg always insisted upon it that the kiss won the victory, for after it was given, Demi sobbed more quietly, and lay quite still at the bottom of the bed, whither he had wriggled in his anguish of mind.
梅格总是坚持认为这个吻赢得了胜利，因为在亲吻之后，黛米抽泣得更小声了，一动不动地躺在床底，他在痛苦的心灵中蠕动着。

‘Poor little man, he’s worn out with sleep and crying. I’ll cover him up, and then go and set Meg’s heart at rest.’ thought John, creeping to the bedside, hoping to find his rebellious heir asleep.
“可怜的小男人，他因睡眠和哭泣而疲惫不堪。我会帮他盖好被子，然后去让梅格的心平静下来。”约翰一边想，一边爬到床边，希望能看到他那叛逆的继承人睡着了。

But he wasn’t, for the moment his father peeped at him, Demi’s eyes opened, his little chin began to quiver, and he put up his arms, saying with a penitent hiccough, ‘Me’s dood, now.’
但他不是，就在他父亲偷看他的那一刻，黛米的眼睛睁开了，他的小下巴开始颤抖，他举起双臂，悔恨地打嗝说：“现在我完蛋了。”

Sitting on the stairs outside Meg wondered at the long silence which followed the uproar, and after imagining all sorts of impossible accidents, she slipped into the room to set her fears at rest. Demi lay fast asleep, not in his usual spreadeagle attitude, but in a subdued bunch, cuddled close in the circle of his father’s arm and holding his father’s finger, as if he felt that justice was tempered with mercy, and had gone to sleep a sadder and wiser baby. So held, John had waited with a womanly patience till the little hand relaxed its hold, and while waiting had fallen asleep, more tired by that tussle with his son than with his whole day’s work.
梅格坐在外面的楼梯上，对喧闹之后的长时间沉默感到惊讶，在想象了各种不可能的事故后，她溜进房间，平息了自己的恐惧。黛米睡得很熟，不像平常那​​样张开双臂，而是蜷缩成一团，紧紧地依偎在父亲的手臂上，握着父亲的手指，仿佛他觉得正义被仁慈所调和，然后就睡着了。更悲伤、更聪明的宝宝。就这样，约翰以女人般的耐心等待着，直到那只小手松开了手，然后在等待的过程中睡着了，与儿子的争吵比他一整天的工作更累。

As Meg stood watching the two faces on the pillow, she smiled to herself, and then slipped away again, saying in a satisfied tone, ‘I never need fear that John will be too harsh with my babies. He does know how to manage them, and will be a great help, for Demi is getting too much for me.’
梅格站在那里看着枕头上的两张脸，她对自己笑了笑，然后又溜走了，用满意的语气说道：“我从来不需要担心约翰会对我的孩子们太严厉。”他确实知道如何管理它们，并且会提供很大的帮助，因为黛米对我来说太多了。

When John came down at last, expecting to find a pensive or reproachful wife, he was agreeably surprised to find Meg placidly trimming a bonnet, and to be greeted with the request to read something about the election, if he was not too tired. John saw in a minute that a revolution of some kind was going on, but wisely asked no questions, knowing that Meg was such a transparent little person, she couldn’t keep a secret to save her life, and therefore the clue would soon appear. He read a long debate with the most amiable readiness and then explained it in his most lucid manner, while Meg tried to look deeply interested, to ask intelligent questions, and keep her thoughts from wandering from the state of the nation to the state of her bonnet. In her secret soul, however, she decided that politics were as bad as mathematics, and the the mission of politicians seemed to be calling each other names, but she kept these feminine ideas to herself, and when John paused, shook her head and said with what she thought diplomatic ambiguity, ‘Well, I really don’t see what we are coming to.’
当约翰最后下来时，以为会找到一位忧郁或责备的妻子，他惊讶地发现梅格正在平静地修剪一顶帽子，并要求他阅读一些有关选举的内容，如果他不太累的话。约翰立刻就看到了某种革命正在发生，但他明智地没有提出任何问题，因为他知道梅格是一个如此透明的小人物，她无法保守秘密来挽救自己的生命，因此线索很快就会出现。他以最和蔼可亲的态度读了一篇长篇辩论，然后以最清晰的方式进行了解释，而梅格则试图表现出浓厚的兴趣，提出明智的问题，并避免她的思绪从国家的状态转移到她的状态。引擎盖。然而，在她秘密的灵魂里，她认为政治和数学一样糟糕，政治家的使命似乎是互相辱骂，但她把这些女性化的想法留给了自己，当约翰停顿时，她摇摇头说：她认为外交含糊不清，“好吧，我真的不明白我们会面临什么。”

John laughed, and watched her for a minute, as she poised a pretty little preparation of lace and flowers on her hand, and regarded it with the genuine interest which his harangue had failed to waken.
约翰笑了，看了她一会儿，她把一小块蕾丝和鲜花放在手上，并以他的长篇大论未能唤醒的真正兴趣注视着它。

‘She is trying to like politics for my sake, so I’ll try and like millinery for hers, that’s only fair,’ thought John the Just, adding aloud, ‘That’s very pretty. Is it what you call a breakfast cap?’
“她试图为了我而喜欢政治，所以我会尝试为她喜欢女帽，这很公平，”公正的约翰想，大声补充道，“那非常漂亮。”这就是你们所说的早餐帽吗？

‘My dear man, it’s a bonnet! My very best go-to-concert-and-theater bonnet.’
“我亲爱的朋友，这是一顶帽子！我最好的去音乐会和剧院的帽子。

‘I beg your pardon, it was so small, I naturally mistook it for one of the flyaway things you sometimes wear. How do you keep it on?’
“请原谅，它太小了，我很自然地将它误认为是你有时穿的一件飘逸的衣服。你如何保持它？

‘These bits of lace are fastened under the chin with a rosebud, so.’ And Meg illustrated by putting on the bonnet and regarding him with an air of calm satisfaction that was irresistible.
“这些花边是用玫瑰花蕾固定在下巴下面的，所以。”梅格戴上帽子，用一种令人无法抗拒的平静满足的神情看着他。

‘It’s a love of a bonnet, but I prefer the face inside, for it looks young and happy again.’ And John kissed the smiling face, to the great detriment of the rosebud under the chin.
“这是对帽子的喜爱，但我更喜欢里面的脸，因为它看起来又年轻又快乐。”约翰吻了吻那张笑脸，这极大地损害了下巴下的玫瑰花蕾。

‘I’m glad you like it, for I want you to take me to one of the new concerts some night. I really need some music to put me in tune. Will you, please?’
“我很高兴你喜欢它，因为我希望你有一天晚上带我去听一场新的音乐会。我真的需要一些音乐来调整自己的节奏。请你？'

‘Of course I will, with all my heart, or anywhere else you like. You have been shut up so long, it will do you no end of good, and I shall enjoy it, of all things. What put it into your head, little mother?’
“我当然愿意，全心全意，或者你喜欢的任何其他地方。你被关了这么久，这对你有无穷的好处，我会很享受它的。是什么让你想到了这个，小妈妈？

‘Well, I had a talk with Marmee the other day, and told her how nervous and cross and out of sorts I felt, and she said I needed change and less care, so Hannah is to help me with the children, and I’m to see to things about the house more, and now and then have a little fun, just to keep me from getting to be a fidgety, broken-down old woman before my time. It’s only an experiment, John, and I want to try it for your sake as much as for mine, because I’ve neglected you shamefully lately, and I’m going to make home what it used to be, if I can. You don’t object, I hope?’
“嗯，前几天我和妈妈谈过一次，告诉她我感到多么紧张、生气和不舒服，她说我需要改变和更少的照顾，所以汉娜要帮助我照顾孩子，而我”我要更多地关心房子的事情，时不时地享受一点乐趣，只是为了防止我在临终前变成一个烦躁、崩溃的老太婆。这只是一个实验，约翰，我想尝试一下，既是为了你，也是为了我自己，因为我最近可耻地忽视了你，如果可以的话，我会让家恢复到以前的样子。我希望你不会反对吧？

Never mind what John said, or what a very narrow escape the little bonnet had from utter ruin. All that we have any business to know is that John did not appear to object, judging from the changes which gradually took place in the house and its inmates. It was not all Paradise by any means, but everyone was better for the division of labor system. The children throve under the paternal rule, for accurate, stedfast John brought order and obedience into Babydom, while Meg recovered her spirits and composed her nerves by plenty of wholesome exercise, a little pleasure, and much confidential conversation with her sensible husband. Home grew homelike again, and John had no wish to leave it, unless he took Meg with him. The Scotts came to the Brookes’ now, and everyone found the little house a cheerful place, full of happiness, content, and family love. Even Sallie Moffatt liked to go there. ‘It is always so quiet and pleasant here, it does me good, Meg,’ she used to say, looking about her with wistful eyes, as if trying to discover the charm, that she might use it in her great house, full of splendid lonliness, for there were no riotous, sunny-faced babies there, and Ned lived in a world of lis own, where there was no place for her.
别介意约翰说了什么，也别介意这顶小帽子是多么九死一生才免于彻底毁灭。我们所知道的是，从房子和里面的人逐渐发生的变化来看，约翰似乎并没有反对。无论如何，这并不完全是天堂，但由于分工制度，每个人都变得更好。孩子们在父亲的统治下茁壮成长，因为准确而坚定的约翰给巴比王国带来了秩序和服从，而梅格则通过大量有益健康的锻炼、一点点快乐以及与她明智的丈夫的秘密交谈，恢复了精神并稳定了神经。家又变得像家了，约翰不想离开它，除非他带着梅格一起走。斯科特一家现在来到了布鲁克斯家，每个人都发现这座小房子是一个令人愉快的地方，充满了幸福、满足和家庭之爱。甚至萨莉·莫法特也喜欢去那里。 “这里总是那么安静、令人愉快，这对我有好处，梅格，”她常常这样说，用渴望的眼睛环顾四周，仿佛试图发现它的魅力，以便她可以在她那座充满了色彩的大房子里使用它。这是一种美妙的孤独，因为那里没有喧闹、阳光明媚的婴儿，而奈德生活在她自己的世界里，那里没有她的容身之地。

This household happiness did not come all at once, but John and Meg had found the key to it, and each year of Married life taught them how to use it, unlocking the treasuries of real home love and mutual helpfulness, which the poorest may possess, and the richest cannot buy. This is the sort of shelf on which young wives and mothers may consent to be laid, safe from the restless fret and fever of the world, finding loyal lovers in the little sons and daughters who cling to them, undaunted by sorrow, poverty, or age, walking side by side, through fair and stormy weather, with a faithful friend, who is, in the true sense of the good old Saxon word, the ‘house-band’, and learning, as Meg learned, that a woman’s happiest kingdom is home, her highest honor the art of ruling it not as a queen, but as a wise wife and mother.
这种家庭幸福并不是一下子就到来的，但约翰和梅格找到了它的钥匙，婚姻生活的每一年都教会他们如何使用它，打开最贫穷的人可能拥有的真正的家庭之爱和相互帮助的宝库，最有钱的人买不到。年轻的妻子和母亲可能会同意躺在这样的架子上，远离尘世的烦躁和狂热，在依附于他们的小儿子和女儿身上找到忠实的情人，不畏悲伤、贫困或恐惧。年龄，与一个忠实的朋友并肩行走，穿过晴朗和暴风雨的天气，他是撒克逊古老的好词的真正含义，“家庭乐队”，并学习，正如梅格所了解到的，一个女人最幸福的事情王国是家，她的最高荣誉不是作为女王，而是作为明智的妻子和母亲来统治国家。

CHAPTER THIRTY-NINE
第三十九章

Laurie went to Nice intending to stay a week, and remained a month. He was tired of wandering about alone, and Amy’s familiar presence seemed to give a homelike charm to the foreign scenes in which she bore a part. He rather missed the ‘petting’ he used to receive, and enjoyed a taste of it again, for no attentions, however flattering, from strangers, were half so pleasant as the sisterly adoration of the girls at home. Amy never would pet him like the others, but she was very glad to see him now, and quite clung to him, feeling that he was the representative of the dear family for whom she longed more than she would confess. They naturally took comfort in each other’s society and were much together, riding, walking, dancing, or dawdling, for at Nice no one can be very industrious during the gay season. But, while apparently amusing themselves in the most careless fashion, they were half-consciously making discoveries and forming opinions about each other. Amy rose daily in the estimation of her friend, but he sank in hers, and each felt the truth before a word was spoken. Amy tried to please, and succeeded, for she was grateful for the many pleasures he gave her, and repaid him with the little services to which womanly women know how to lend an indescribable charm. Laurie made no effort of any kind, but just let himself drift along as comfortably as possible, trying to forget, and feeling that all women owed him a kind word because one had been cold to him. It cost him no effort to be generous, and he would have given Amy all the trinkets in Nice if she would have taken them, but at the same time he felt that he could not change the opinion she was forming of him, and he rather dreaded the keen blue eyes that seemed to watch him with such half-sorrowful, half-scornful surprise.
劳里去尼斯本来打算待一周，结果待了一个月。他厌倦了独自徘徊，而艾米熟悉的存在似乎给她所扮演的异国场景增添了一种温馨的魅力。他相当怀念以前受到的“宠爱”，现在又很享受这种滋味，因为陌生人的关注，无论多么谄媚，都不如家里女孩们姐妹般的崇拜更令人愉快。艾米从来不会像其他人那样宠爱他，但她现在很高兴见到他，并且非常粘着他，觉得他是这个亲爱的家庭的代表，她对这个家庭的渴望比她承认的还要多。他们很自然地在彼此的社交中感到安慰，经常在一起，骑马、散步、跳舞或闲逛，因为在尼斯，在同性恋季节没有人能非常勤奋。但是，虽然表面上他们以最粗心的方式自娱自乐，但他们却在半自觉地发现彼此并形成对彼此的看法。艾米对她朋友的评价日益上升，但他对她的评价却下降了，每个人在开口说话之前都感受到了真相。艾米试图取悦他，并且成功了，因为她很感激他给她带来的许多快乐，并用女人知道如何赋予她难以形容的魅力的小服务来回报他。劳里没有做出任何努力，只是让自己尽可能舒服地漂流，试图忘记，并感觉所有女人都欠他一句善意的话，因为有人对他很冷淡。 他不费吹灰之力就表现得慷慨，如果艾米愿意的话，他会把尼斯的所有小饰品都给她，但同时他觉得自己无法改变她对他的看法，他宁愿他害怕那双锐利的蓝眼睛，它们似乎带着半悲伤、半轻蔑的惊讶看着他。

‘All the rest have gone to Monaco for the day. I preferred to stay at home and write letters. They are done now, and I am going to Valrosa to sketch, will you come?’ said Amy, as she joined Laurie one lovely day when he lounged in as usual about noon.
“剩下的人今天都去了摩纳哥。我更喜欢呆在家里写信。现在它们已经完成了，我要去瓦罗萨画素描，你会来吗？”艾米在一个美好的一天和劳里一起说道，当时劳里正像往常一样在中午闲逛。

‘Well, yes, but isn’t it rather warm for such a long walk?’ he answered slowly, for the shaded salon looked inviting after the glare without.
“嗯，是的，但是走这么长的路不是很热吗？”他慢慢地回答，因为在外面的刺眼的阳光照射下，阴凉的沙龙看起来很诱人。

‘I’m going to have the little carriage, and Baptiste can drive, so you’ll have nothing to do but hold your umbrella, and keep your gloves nice,’ returned Amy, with a sarcastic glance at the immaculate kids, which were a weak point with Laurie.
“我要开一辆小马车，巴蒂斯特会开车，所以你们除了撑伞、戴好手套之外什么都不用做。”艾米讽刺地看了一眼那些完美无瑕的孩子们，说道。劳里的一个弱点。

‘Then I’ll go with pleasure.’ And he put out his hand for her sketchbook. But she tucked it under her arm with a sharp...
“那我很乐意去。”他伸出手去拿她的素描本。但她用一把锋利的刀把它夹在腋下……

‘Don’t trouble yourself. It’s no exertion to me, but you don’t look equal to it.’
‘别为难自己了。对我来说这并不费力，但你看起来还不够。

Laurie lifted his eyebrows and followed at a leisurely pace as she ran downstairs, but when they got into the carriage he took the reins himself, and left little Baptiste nothing to do but fold his arms and fall asleep on his perch.
劳里扬起眉毛，悠闲地跟着她跑下楼，但当他们上了马车时，他亲自掌控了缰绳，留下小巴蒂斯特什么也不做，只是抱着双臂，在高处睡着了。

The two never quarreled. Amy was too well-bred, and just now Laurie was too lazy, so in a minute he peeped under her hatbrim with an inquiring air. She answered him with a smile, and they went on together in the most amicable manner.
两人从不吵架。艾米太有教养了，刚才劳里太懒了，所以一会儿他就带着询问的神情从她的帽檐下往外看。她微笑着回答他，然后他们就以最友好的方式一起走下去。

It was a lovely drive, along winding roads rich in the picturesque scenes that delight beauty-loving eyes. Here an ancient monastery, whence the solemn chanting of the monks came down to them. There a bare-legged shepherd, in wooden shoes, pointed hat, and rough jacket over one shoulder, sat piping on a stone while his goats skipped among the rocks or lay at his feet. Meek, mouse-colored donkeys, laden with panniers of freshly cut grass passed by, with a pretty girl in a capaline sitting between the green piles, or an old woman spinning with a distaff as she went. Brown, soft-eyed children ran out from the quaint stone hovels to offer nosegays, or bunches of oranges still on the bough. Gnarled olive trees covered the hills with their dusky foliage, fruit hung golden in the orchard, and great scarlet anemones fringed the roadside, while beyond green slopes and craggy heights, the Maritime Alps rose sharp and white against the blue Italian sky.
这是一次愉快的驾车旅行，沿着蜿蜒的道路行驶，风景如画，让爱美的人大饱眼福。这里有一座古老的修道院，僧侣们庄严的诵经声从那里传来。那里有一个光着腿的牧羊人，穿着木鞋，戴着尖顶帽子，肩膀上穿着粗糙的夹克，坐在一块石头上吹着笛子，而他的山羊则在岩石间跳跃或躺在他的脚边。温顺的、老鼠色的驴子驮着刚割下的草驮经过，绿色的草堆中间坐着一个穿着斗篷的漂亮女孩，或者一个老妇人边走边纺纱。眼睛柔和的棕色孩子们从古色古香的石屋里跑出来，献上花束，或者说还在树枝上的一串橙子。粗糙的橄榄树用暗淡的叶子覆盖了山丘，果园里挂着金色的果实，路边点缀着巨大的猩红色海葵，而在绿色的山坡和崎岖的高地之外，海上阿尔卑斯山在意大利蓝色的天空的映衬下尖锐而白色。

Valrosa well deserved its name, for in that climate of perpetual summer roses blossomed everywhere. They overhung the archway, thrust themselves between the bars of the great gate with a sweet welcome to passers-by, and lined the avenue, winding through lemon trees and feathery palms up to the villa on the hill. Every shadowy nook, where seats invited one to stop and rest, was a mass of bloom, every cool grotto had its marble nymph smiling from a veil of flowers and every fountain reflected crimson, white, or pale pink roses, leaning down to smile at their own beauty. Roses covered the walls of the house, draped the cornices, climbed the pillars, and ran riot over the balustrade of the wide terrace, whence one looked down on the sunny Mediterranean, and the white-walled city on its shore.
瓦罗萨（Valrosa）名副其实，因为在永久夏季的气候下，玫瑰到处盛开。他们悬挂在拱门上方，插入大门的铁栅之间，向路人发出甜蜜的欢迎，并沿着大道排列，蜿蜒穿过柠檬树和羽毛状的棕榈树，一直到达山上的别墅。每一个阴暗的角落，座位上都开满了鲜花，每一个凉爽的洞穴里都有大理石仙女在鲜花的面纱中微笑，每一个喷泉都反射着深红色、白色或淡粉色的玫瑰，俯下身子微笑着她们自己的美丽。玫瑰覆盖了房子的墙壁，挂满了飞檐，攀上了柱子，在宽阔露台的栏杆上肆意地绽放，从那里可以俯瞰阳光明媚的地中海和海岸上的白墙城市。

‘This is a regular honeymoon paradise, isn’t it? Did you ever see such roses?’ asked Amy, pausing on the terrace to enjoy the view, and a luxurious whiff of perfume that came wandering by.
“这就是一个普通的蜜月天堂，不是吗？”你见过这样的玫瑰吗？”艾米问道，她在露台上停下来欣赏风景，还有一股奢华的香水味飘来。

‘No, nor felt such thorns,’ returned Laurie, with his thumb in his mouth, after a vain attempt to capture a solitary scarlet flower that grew just beyond his reach.
“不，也没有感觉到这样的刺。”劳里嘴里含着拇指，试图抓住一朵孤零零的猩红色花朵，但徒劳无功。

‘Try lower down, and pick those that have no thorns,’ said Amy, gathering three of the tiny cream-colored ones that starred the wall behind her. She put them in his buttonhole as a peace offering, and he stood a minute looking down at them with a curious expression, for in the Italian part of his nature there was a touch of superstition, and he was just then in that state of half-sweet, half-bitter melancholy, when imaginative young men find significance in trifles and food for romance everywhere. He had thought of Jo in reaching after the thorny red rose, for vivid flowers became her, and she had often worn ones like that from the greenhouse at home. The pale roses Amy gave him were the sort that the Italians lay in dead hands, never in bridal wreaths, and for a moment he wondered if the omen was for Jo or for himself, but the next instant his American common sense got the better of sentimentality, and he laughed a heartier laugh than Amy had heard since he came.
“试着往下一点，挑那些没有刺的，”艾米一边说，一边收集了她身后墙上的三颗奶油色的小刺。她把它们放在他的纽扣孔里作为和平祭品，他站了一会儿，低头看着它们，表情好奇，因为在他的意大利性格中，有一丝迷信，而他当时正处于半昏半醒的状态。 -当富有想象力的年轻人在琐事中发现意义并到处寻找浪漫的食物时，甜蜜，半苦的忧郁。他想到了乔伸手去抓那朵带刺的红玫瑰，因为鲜艳的花朵很适合她，而且她经常戴家里温室里的那种花。艾米送给他的淡玫瑰是意大利人放在死人手里的那种，从来没有放在新娘花环上，有那么一会儿，他想知道这个预兆是给乔的还是给他自己的，但下一刻他的美国常识就占了上风。多愁善感，他笑得比艾米来后听过的更爽朗。

‘It’s good advice, you’d better take it and save your fingers,’ she said, thinking her speech amused him.
“这是个好建议，你最好接受它，保住你的手指，”她说，觉得她的演讲逗乐了他。

‘Thank you, I will,’ he answered in jest, and a few months later he did it in earnest.
“谢谢你，我会的。”他开玩笑地回答，几个月后，他认真地回答了。

‘Laurie, when are you going to your grandfather?’ she asked presently, as she settled herself on a rustic seat.
“劳里，你什么时候去你祖父那里？”她在一张乡村风格的椅子上坐下来问道。

‘Very soon.’
'很快。'

‘You have said that a dozen times within the last three weeks.’
“过去三周内你已经说过十几次了。”

‘I dare say, short answers save trouble.’
“我敢说，简短的回答可以省去麻烦。”

‘He expects you, and you really ought to go.’
“他在等你，你真的应该去。”

‘Hospitable creature! I know it.’
‘好客的生物！我知道这。'

‘Then why don’t you do it?’
“那你为什么不这么做呢？”

‘Natural depravity, I suppose.’
“我想，这是天生的堕落。”

‘Natural indolence, you mean. It’s really dreadful!’ And Amy looked severe.
“你的意思是，自然的懒惰。真是太可怕了！”艾米表情严肃。

‘Not so bad as it seems, for I should only plague him if I went, so I might as well stay and plague you a little longer, you can bear it better, in fact I think it agrees with you excellently.’ And Laurie composed himself for a lounge on the broad ledge of the balustrade.
“看起来还不错，因为如果我去的话我只会困扰他，所以我还不如留下来再困扰你一会儿，你可以更好地忍受，事实上我认为这非常适合你。”劳里他在栏杆宽阔的窗台上休息了一会儿。

Amy shook her head and opened her sketchbook with an air of resignation, but she had made up her mind to lecture ‘that boy’ and in a minute she began again.
艾米摇摇头，一脸无奈地打开素描本，但她已经下定决心要教训一下‘那个男孩’了，一会儿又开始了。

‘What are you doing just now?’
“你刚才在做什么？”

‘Watching lizards.’
“观察蜥蜴。”

‘No, no. I mean what do you intend and wish to do?’
'不，不。我的意思是你打算做什么？

‘Smoke a cigarette, if you’ll allow me.’
“如果你允许的话，抽支烟吧。”

‘How provoking you are! I don’t approve of cigars and I will only allow it on condition that you let me put you into my sketch. I need a figure.’
‘你真是太挑衅了！我不赞成抽雪茄，只有在你让我把你放进我的素描中的情况下我才会允许。我需要一个数字。

‘With all the pleasure in life. How will you have me, full length or three-quarters, on my head or my heels? I should respectfully suggest a recumbent posture, then put yourself in also and call it ‘Dolce far niente’.’
‘带着生活中所有的乐趣。你将如何让我，全长或四分之三，在我的头上或我的脚后跟？我应该恭敬地建议你采取卧姿，然后也把自己摆进去，称之为“Dolce far niente”。

‘Stay as you are, and go to sleep if you like. I intend to work hard,’ said Amy in her most energetic tone.
‘保持现状，如果你愿意的话就去睡觉吧。我打算努力工作。”艾米用她最有活力的语气说道。

‘What delightful enthusiasm!’ And he leaned against a tall urn with an ir of entire satisfaction.
“多么令人愉快的热情啊！”他靠在一个高高的瓮上，脸上洋溢着满足的神情。

‘What would Jo say if she saw you now?’ asked Amy impatiently, hoping to stir him up by the mention of her still more energetic sister’s name.
“如果乔现在看到你，她会说什么？”艾米不耐烦地问道，希望通过提到她更加精力充沛的妹妹的名字来激起他的兴趣。

‘As usual, ‘Go away, Teddy. I’m busy!’’ He laughed as he spoke, but the laugh was not natural, and a shade passed over his face, for the utterance of the familiar name touched the wound that was not healed yet. Both tone and shadow struck Amy, for she had seen and heard them before, and now she looked up in time to catch a new expression on Laurie’s face—a hard bitter look, full of pain, dissatisfaction, and regret. It was gone before she could study it and the listless expression back again. She watched him for a moment with artistic pleasure, thinking how like an Italian he looked, as he lay basking in the sun with uncovered head and eyes full of southern dreaminess, for he seemed to have forgotten her and fallen into a reverie.
“像往常一样，‘走开，泰迪。我很忙！”他边说边笑，但笑起来并不自然，脸上掠过一丝阴霾，因为熟悉的名字触动了尚未愈合的伤口。声音和影子都让艾米震惊，因为她以前见过、听过它们，现在她抬起头，及时发现了劳里脸上的新表情——一种严厉、痛苦的表情，充满了痛苦、不满和遗憾。她还没来得及研究它，它就消失了，无精打采的表情又回来了。她带着艺术的愉悦看了他一会儿，觉得他看起来多么像一个意大利人，躺在阳光下，裸着头，眼睛里充满了南方的梦幻，因为他似乎已经忘记了她，陷入了沉思。

‘You look like the effigy of a young knight asleep on his tomb,’ she said, carefully tracing the well-cut profile defined against the dark stone.
“你看起来就像一位睡在坟墓上的年轻骑士的雕像，”她一边说，一边仔细地描绘着黑色石头上轮廓分明的轮廓。

‘Wish I was!’
“但愿我是！”

‘That’s a foolish wish, unless you have spoiled your life. You are so changed, I sometimes think—‘ There Amy stopped, with a half-timid, half-wistful look, more significant than her unfinished speech.
‘这是一个愚蠢的愿望，除非你毁了你的生活。你变了很多，我有时想——’艾米停了下来，她的表情一半是胆怯，一半是渴望，比她未完成的演讲更重要。

Laurie saw and understood the affectionate anxiety which she hesitated to express, and looking straight into her eyes, said, just as he used to say it to her mother, ‘It’s all right, ma’am.’
劳里看到并理解了她犹豫要表达的深情焦虑，他直视着她的眼睛，就像他过去对她母亲说的那样，说道：“没关系，女士。”

That satisfied her and set at rest the doubts that had begun to worry her lately. It also touched her, and she showed that it did, by the cordial tone in which she said...
这让她很满意，也消除了最近开始让她担心的疑虑。这也触动了她，她用亲切的语气说……

‘I’m glad of that! I didn’t think you’d been a very bad boy, but I fancied you might have wasted money at that wicked Baden-Baden, lost your heart to some charming Frenchwoman with a husband, or got into some of the scrapes that young men seem to consider a necessary part of a foreign tour. Don’t stay out there in the sun, come and lie on the grass here and ‘let us be friendly’, as Jo used to say when we got in the sofa corner and told secrets.’
‘我对此很高兴！我不认为你是一个很坏的孩子，但我想你可能在那个邪恶的巴登巴登浪费了钱，对某个有丈夫的迷人法国女人失去了心，或者陷入了年轻人所面临的一些困境。似乎被认为是出国旅游的必要组成部分。不要呆在阳光下，来躺在这里的草地上，‘让我们友好一点’，就像乔在我们坐在沙发角告诉秘密时常说的那样。”

Laurie obediently threw himself down on the turf, and began to amuse himself by sticking daisies into the ribbons of Amy’s hat, that lay there.
劳里顺从地躺在草地上，开始把雏菊插到艾米帽子的丝带上取乐。

‘I’m all ready for the secrets.’ And he glanced up with a decided expression of interest in his eyes.
“我已经准备好接受秘密了。”他抬起头，眼中流露出明显的兴趣。

‘I’ve none to tell. You may begin.’
“我没什么可说的。”你可以开始了。

‘Haven’t one to bless myself with. I thought perhaps you’d had some news from home..’
‘没有人可以祝福我自己。我想也许你从家里得到了一些消息……”

‘You have heard all that has come lately. Don’t you hear often? I fancied Jo would send you volumes.’
‘你已经听到了最近发生的一切。你不是经常听到吗？我以为乔会寄给你很多卷。

‘She’s very busy. I’m roving about so, it’s impossible to be regular, you know. When do you begin your great work of art, Raphaella?’ he asked. changing the subject abruptly after another pause, in which he had been wondering if Amy knew his secret and wanted to talk about it.
‘她很忙。我到处流浪，不可能保持正常，你知道。 “拉斐拉，你什么时候开始创作你伟大的艺术作品？”他问道。又停顿了一下，他突然改变了话题，他一直在想艾米是否知道他的秘密并想谈谈它。

‘Never,’ she answered, with a despondent but decided air. ‘Rome took all the vanity out of me, for after seeing the wonders there, I felt too insignificant to live and gave up all my foolish hopes in despair.’
“从来没有。”她回答道，神情沮丧但又坚定。 “罗马夺走了我所有的虚荣心，因为在看到那里的奇迹之后，我感到自己太渺小，无法生存，并在绝望中放弃了所有愚蠢的希望。”

‘Why should you, with so much energy and talent?’
“你有这么多的精力和才华，为什么要这么做呢？”

‘That’s just why, because talent isn’t genius, and no amount of energy can make it so. I want to be great, or nothing. I won’t be a common-place dauber, so I don’t intend to try any more.’
‘这就是原因，因为天赋并不是天才，再多的精力也无法使它成为天才。我想要变得伟大，或者什么都不是。我不会做一个普通的涂抹者，所以我不打算再尝试了。

‘And what are you going to do with yourself now, if I may ask?’
“请问，你现在打算怎么办？”

‘Polish up my other talents, and be an ornament to society, if I get the chance.’
“如果有机会的话，磨练我的其他才能，成为社会的装饰品。”

It was a characteristic speech, and sounded daring, but audacity becomes young people, and Amy’s ambition had a good foundation. Laurie smiled, but he liked the spirit with which she took up a new purpose when a long-cherished one died, and spent no time lamenting.
这是一次很有特色的演讲，听起来很大胆，但大胆是年轻人的特点，艾米的野心有很好的基础。劳里微笑着，但他喜欢她在心爱的人去世后找到新目标的精神，并且没有花时间哀悼。

‘Good! And here is where Fred Vaughn comes in, I fancy.’
'好的！我想这就是弗雷德·沃恩发挥作用的地方。

Amy preserved a discreet silence, but there was a conscious look in her downcast face that made Laurie sit up and say gravely, ‘Now I’m going to play brother, and ask questions. May I?’
艾米保持着谨慎的沉默，但她低下的脸上有一种自觉的表情，这让劳里坐了起来，严肃地说：“现在我要扮演兄弟，问问题。”我可以？'

‘I don’t promise to answer.’
“我不保证回答。”

‘Your face will, if your tongue won’t. You aren’t woman of the world enough yet to hide your feelings, my dear. I heard rumors about Fred and you last year, and it’s my private opinion that if he had not been called home so suddenly and detained so long, something would have come of it, hey?’
“如果你的舌头不会，你的脸会。”亲爱的，你还不够成熟，还不足以隐藏你的感情。去年我听到了关于弗雷德和你的谣言，我个人认为，如果他没有这么突然被叫回家并被拘留这么长时间，事情会发生的，嘿？

‘That’s not for me to say,’ was Amy’s grim reply, but her lips would smile, and there was a traitorous sparkle of the eye which betrayed that she knew her power and enjoyed the knowledge.
“这不是我该说的，”艾米冷酷地回答，但她的嘴唇会微笑，眼睛里闪烁着背叛的光芒，暴露出她知道自己的力量并享受这些知识。

‘You are not engaged, I hope?’ And Laurie looked very elder-brotherly and grave all of a sudden.
“我希望你没有订婚吧？”劳里突然显得非常有哥哥气，而且很严肃。

‘No.’
'不。'

‘But you will be, if he comes back and goes properly down on his knees, won’t you?’
“但如果他回来并正确地跪下来，你就会的，不是吗？”

‘Very likely.’
'很可能。'

‘Then you are fond of old Fred?’
“那你喜欢老弗雷德吗？”

‘I could be, if I tried.’
“如果我努力的话，我可以的。”

‘But you don’t intend to try till the proper moment? Bless my soul, what unearthly prudence! He’s a good fellow, Amy, but not the man I fancied you’d like.’
“但是你不打算在适当的时候尝试吗？保佑我的灵魂，多么超凡的谨慎啊！他是个好人，艾米，但不是我想象中你会喜欢的人。”

‘He is rich, a gentleman, and has delightful manners,’ began Amy, trying to be quite cool and dignified, but feeling a little ashamed of herself, in spite of the sincerity of her intentions.
“他很有钱，是位绅士，举止令人愉快，”艾米开始说，她努力表现得冷静而有尊严，但尽管她的意图是真诚的，但她还是感到有点羞愧。

‘I understand. Queens of society can’t get on without money, so you mean to make a good match, and start in that way? Quite right and proper, as the world goes, but it sounds odd from the lips of one of your mother’s girls.’
'我明白。社会上的女王没有钱就过不下去，所以你就想撮合好，就这样开始吗？就世界而言，这是非常正确和恰当的，但从你母亲的一个女儿嘴里说出来，听起来很奇怪。”

‘True, nevertheless.’
“不过，确实如此。”

A short speech, but the quiet decision with which it was uttered contrasted curiously with the young speaker. Laurie felt this instinctively and laid himself down again, with a sense of disappointment which he could not explain. His look and silence, as well as a certain inward self-disapproval, ruffled Amy, and made her resolve to deliver her lecture without delay.
演讲很短，但其平静的决定与这位年轻的演讲者形成了奇怪的对比。劳里本能地感觉到了这一点，然后又躺了下来，带着一种他无法解释的失望感。他的表情和沉默，以及内心的某种自我否定，让艾米很恼火，并让她决心立即发表演讲。

‘I wish you’d do me the favor to rouse yourself a little,’ she said sharply.
“我希望你能帮我让自己清醒一点，”她尖锐地说。

‘Do it for me, there’s a dear girl.’
“为我做吧，有一个亲爱的女孩。”

‘I could, if I tried.’ And she looked as if she would like doing it in the most summary style.
“如果我尝试的话，我可以。”她看起来好像很想以最概括的方式来做这件事。

‘Try, then. I give you leave,’ returned Laurie, who enjoyed having someone to tease, after his long abstinence from his favorite pastime.
‘那就试试吧。我允许你离开了，”劳里回答道，在长期戒除自己最喜欢的消遣之后，他很喜欢有人来取笑。

‘You’d be angry in five minutes.’
“五分钟后你就会生气。”

‘I’m never angry with you. It takes two flints to make a fire. You are as cool and soft as snow.’
‘我从来不生你的气。生火需要两块打火石。你像雪一样凉爽、柔软。”

‘You don’t know what I can do. Snow produces a glow and a tingle, if applied rightly. Your indifference is half affectation, and a good stirring up would prove it.’
‘你不知道我能做什么。如果使用得当，雪会产生光泽和刺痛感。你的冷漠一半是矫揉造作，好好煽动一下就可以证明这一点。

‘Stir away, it won’t hurt me and it may amuse you, as the big man said when his little wife beat him. Regard me in the light of a husband or a carpet, and beat till you are tired, if that sort of exercise agrees with you.’
“滚开，这不会伤害我，而且可能会让你觉得好笑，正如大个子在他的小妻子殴打他时所说的那样。把我当作丈夫或地毯，然后打到你累了，如果这种运动适合你的话。

Being decidedly nettled herself, and longing to see him shake off the apathy that so altered him, Amy sharpened both tongue and pencil, and began.
艾米显然很恼火，也渴望看到他摆脱改变他的冷漠，于是她削尖了舌头和铅笔，开始了。

‘Flo and I have got a new name for you. It’s Lazy Laurence. How do you like it?’
“弗洛和我给你起了一个新名字。这是懒惰的劳伦斯。你喜欢吗？'

She thought it would annoy him, but he only folded his arms under his head, with an imperturbable, ‘That’s not bad. Thank you, ladies.’
她以为这会惹恼他，但他只是将双臂抱在头下，一副泰然自若的样子，“那还不错。”谢谢你们，女士们。

‘Do you want to know what I honestly think of you?’
“你想知道我对你的真实看法吗？”

‘Pining to be told.’
“渴望被告知。”

‘Well, I despise you.’ If she had even said ‘I hate you’ in a petulant or coquettish tone, he would have laughed and rather liked it, but the grave, almost sad, accent in her voice made him open his eyes, and ask quickly...
“好吧，我鄙视你。”如果她用任性或卖弄的语气说“我恨你”，他一定会笑起来，而且相当喜欢，但她声音中严肃、近乎悲伤的口音让他睁开了眼睛。 ，赶紧询问……

‘Why, if you please?’
“请问，为什么？”

‘Because, with every chance for being good, useful, and happy, you are faulty, lazy, and miserable.’
“因为，尽管你有一切机会变得善良、有用和快乐，但你却是错误的、懒惰的和痛苦的。”

‘Strong language, mademoiselle.’
“用词很重，小姐。”

‘If you like it, I’ll go on.’
“如果你喜欢，我就继续。”

‘Pray do, it’s quite interesting.’
“请这样做，这很有趣。”

‘I thought you’d find it so. Selfish people always like to talk about themselves.’
“我以为你会这么认为。自私的人总是喜欢谈论自己。

‘Am I selfish?’ The question slipped out involuntarily and in a tone of surprise, for the one virtue on which he prided himself was generosity.
“我自私吗？”这个问题不由自主地以一种惊讶的语气脱口而出，因为他引以为豪的一项美德就是慷慨。

‘Yes, very selfish,’ continued Amy, in a calm, cool voice, twice as effective just then as an angry one. ‘I’ll show you how, for I’ve studied you while we were frolicking, and I’m not at all satisfied with you. Here you have been abroad nearly six months, and done nothing but waste time and money and disappoint your friends.’
“是的，非常自私。”艾米继续说道，她的声音平静而冷静，比当时愤怒的声音有效一倍。 “我会告诉你怎么做，因为我在我们嬉戏时研究过你，而且我对你一点也不满意。你已经在国外呆了将近六个月了，除了浪费时间和金钱，让你的朋友失望之外，什么也没做。”

‘Isn’t a fellow to have any pleasure after a four-year grind?’
“一个人经过四年的磨练，难道没有一点乐趣吗？”

‘You don’t look as if you’d had much. At any rate, you are none the better for it, as far as I can see. I said when we first met that you had improved. Now I take it all back, for I don’t think you half so nice as when I left you at home. You have grown abominably lazy, you like gossip, and waste time on frivolous things, you are contented to be petted and admired by silly people, instead of being loved and respected by wise ones. With money, talent, position, health, and beauty, ah you like that old Vanity! But it’s the truth, so I can’t help saying it, with all these splendid things to use and enjoy, you can find nothing to do but dawdle, and instead of being the man you ought to be, you are only...’ There she stopped, with a look that had both pain and pity in it.
“你看上去好像拥有的不多。无论如何，在我看来，你并没有因此而变得更好。我们第一次见面的时候我就说过你进步了。现在我收回这一切，因为我觉得你已经不如我把你留在家里时那么好了。你变得极其懒惰，喜欢八卦，把时间浪费在无聊的事情上，你满足于被愚蠢的人宠爱和崇拜，而不是被聪明的人爱戴和尊重。有金钱、有才华、有地位、有健康、有美丽，啊你就像那个老虚荣！但这是事实，所以我忍不住要说，有这么多美妙的东西可以使用和享受，你却除了混日子之外无所事事，你不是成为你应该成为的人，你只是…… ”说到这里，她停了下来，脸上的神情中充满了痛苦和怜悯。

‘Saint Laurence on a gridiron,’ added Laurie, blandly finishing the sentence. But the lecture began to take effect, for there was a wide-awake sparkle in his eyes now and a half-angry, half-injured expression replaced the former indifference.
“烤架上的圣劳伦斯，”劳里补充道，温和地结束了这句话。但讲座开始生效，因为他的眼睛里现在闪烁着清醒的光芒，半生气半受伤的表情取代了之前的冷漠。

‘I supposed you’d take it so. You men tell us we are angels, and say we can make you what we will, but the instant we honestly try to do you good, you laugh at us and won’t listen, which proves how much your flattery is worth.’ Amy spoke bitterly, and turned her back on the exasperating martyr at her feet.
“我以为你会这么认为。你们这些人告诉我们我们是天使，并说我们可以让你成为我们想要的，但当我们真诚地试图为你做好事的那一刻，你嘲笑我们并且不听，这证明了你的奉承是多么值得。”艾米她痛苦地说道，然后背对着脚下令人恼火的烈士。

In a minute a hand came down over the page, so that she could not draw, and Laurie’s voice said, with a droll imitation of a penitent child, ‘I will be good, oh, I will be good!’
过了一会儿，一只手落在了纸上，她无法画画了，劳里的声音滑稽地模仿着悔罪的孩子说：“我会好的，哦，我会好的！”

But Amy did not laugh, for she was in earnest, and tapping on the outspread hand with her pencil, said soberly, ‘Aren’t you ashamed of a hand like that? It’s as soft and white as a woman’s, and looks as if it never did anything but wear Jouvin’s best gloves and pick flowers for ladies. You are not a dandy, thank Heaven, so I’m glad to see there are no diamonds or big seal rings on it, only the little old one Jo gave you so long ago. Dear soul, I wish she was here to help me!’
但艾米没有笑，她很认真，用铅笔敲着那只伸出的手，严肃地说：“你这样的手不感到羞耻吗？”它像女人的手一样柔软、洁白，看起来除了戴上茹文最好的手套、为女士们摘花之外，什么也没做。感谢老天，你不是花花公子，所以我很高兴看到上面没有钻石或大密封戒指，只有乔很久以前送给你的那个小旧戒指。亲爱的灵魂，我希望她能在这里帮助我！

‘So do I!’
'我也是！'

The hand vanished as suddenly as it came, and there was energy enough in the echo of her wish to suit even Amy. She glanced down at him with a new thought in her mind, but he was lying with his hat half over his face, as if for shade, and his mustache hid his mouth. She only saw his chest rise and fall, with a long breath that might have been a sigh, and the hand that wore the ring nestled down into the grass, as if to hide something too precious or too tender to be spoken of. All in a minute various hints and trifles assumed shape and significance in Amy’s mind, and told her what her sister never had confided to her. She remembered that Laurie never spoke voluntarily of Jo, she recalled the shadow on his face just now, the change in his character, and the wearing of the little old ring which was no ornament to a handsome hand. Girls are quick to read such signs and feel their eloquence. Amy had fancied that perhaps a love trouble was at the bottom of the alteration, and now she was sure of it. Her keen eyes filled, and when she spoke again, it was in a voice that could be beautifully soft and kind when she chose to make it so.
那只手消失得突然，来得突然，而她的愿望的回声中蕴藏着足够的能量，甚至适合艾米。她低头看了他一眼，心中有了新的想法，但他正躺着，帽子半遮着脸，仿佛是为了遮荫，小胡子遮住了他的嘴。她只看到他的胸膛起伏，长长的呼吸像是一声叹息，戴着戒指的手依偎在草丛中，仿佛隐藏着什么珍贵又温柔的东西。刹那间，各种暗示和琐事在艾米的脑海中形成了形状和意义，告诉了她姐姐从未向她吐露过的事情。她记得劳里从来没有主动提起过乔，她记得刚才他脸上的阴影，他性格的变化，还有那只在英俊的手上毫无装饰的小戒指。女孩们很快就能读懂这些标志并感受到它们的口才。艾米曾以为这种改变的根源可能是爱情问题，现在她确信了这一点。她的目光充满了锐利，当她再次说话时，她的声音可以是美丽的、柔和的、友善的，只要她选择这样做。

‘I know I have no right to talk so to you, Laurie, and if you weren’t the sweetest-tempered fellow in the world, you’d be very angry with me. But we are all so fond and proud of you, I couldn’t bear to think they should be disappointed in you at home as I have been, though, perhaps they would understand the change better than I do.’
“我知道我没有权利对你这么说，劳里，如果你不是世界上脾气最温和的人，你就会生我的气。但我们都非常喜欢你，为你感到骄傲，我不忍心认为他们会像我一样对你在家里感到失望，不过，也许他们会比我更理解这种变化。

‘I think they would,’ came from under the hat, in a grim tone, quite as touching as a broken one.
“我想他们会的，”帽子下面传来，语气冷酷，就像破碎的语气一样令人感动。

‘They ought to have told me, and not let me go blundering and scolding, when I should have been more kind and patient than ever. I never did like that Miss Randal and now I hate her!’ said artful Amy, wishing to be sure of her facts this time.
“他们应该告诉我，而不是让我犯错误和责骂，而我本应该比以往更加友善和耐心。我从来不喜欢兰德尔小姐，现在我恨她！”狡猾的艾米说道，希望这次能确定她的事实。

‘Hang Miss Randal!’ And Laurie knocked the hat off his face with a look that left no doubt of his sentiments toward that young lady.
“绞死兰德尔小姐！”劳里把帽子从脸上摘了下来，他的表情毫无疑问地表明了他对那位年轻女士的感情。

‘I beg pardon, I thought...’ And there she paused diplomatically.
“请原谅，我想……”然后她外交地停了下来。

‘No, you didn’t, you knew perfectly well I never cared for anyone but Jo,’ Laurie said that in his old, impetuous tone, and turned his face away as he spoke.
“不，你没有，你很清楚，除了乔，我从来不关心任何人，”劳里用他古老而急躁的语气说道，一边说一边把脸转开。

‘I did think so, but as they never said anything about it, and you came away, I supposed I was mistaken. And Jo wouldn’t be kind to you? Why, I was sure she loved you dearly.’
“我确实这么认为，但由于他们从未对此说过任何话，而你却离开了，我想我错了。乔不会对你友善吗？为什么，我确信她深爱着你。

‘She was kind, but not in the right way, and it’s lucky for her she didn’t love me, if I’m the good-for-nothing fellow you think me. It’s her fault though, and you may tell her so.’
“她很友善，但方式不对，如果我是你认为的没出息的人，她很幸运她不爱我。”但这是她的错，你可以这样告诉她。

The hard, bitter look came back again as he said that, and it troubled Amy, for she did not know what balm to apply.
当他说这句话的时候，那种冷酷、苦涩的表情再次出现，这让艾米很烦恼，因为她不知道该用什么药膏。

‘I was wrong, I didn’t know. I’m very sorry I was so cross, but I can’t help wishing you’d bear it better, Teddy, dear.’
‘我错了，我不知道。我很抱歉我这么生气了，但我不禁希望你能忍受得更好，泰迪，亲爱的。

‘Don’t, that’s her name for me!’ And Laurie put up his hand with a quick gesture to stop the words spoken in Jo’s half-kind, half-reproachful tone. ‘Wait till you’ve tried it yourself,’ he added in a low voice, as he pulled up the grass by the handful.
“别这样，那是她给我起的名字！”劳里迅速举起手，制止了乔用半友善、半责备的语气说的话。 “等你亲自尝试一下，”他一边低声补充道，一边一把把草拔了起来。

‘I’d take it manfully, and be respected if i couldn’t be loved,’ said Amy, with the decision of one who knew nothing about it.
“如果我不能被爱，我会勇敢地接受它，并受到尊重，”艾米说道，这是一个对此一无所知的人的决定。

Now, Laurie flattered himself that he had borne it remarkably well, making no moan, asking no sympathy, and taking his trouble away to live it down alone. Amy’s lecture put the Matter in a new light, and for the first time it did look weak and selfish to lose heart at the first failure, and shut himself up in moody indifference. He felt as if suddenly shaken out of a pensive dream and found it impossible to go to sleep again. Presently he sat up and asked slowly, ‘Do you think Jo would despise me as you do?’
现在，劳里自以为自己已经很好地忍受了这一切，没有发出任何抱怨，没有寻求同情，而是把烦恼抛在脑后，独自度过这一切。艾米的演讲让这件事有了新的视角，第一次失败就灰心丧气，把自己封闭在喜怒无常的冷漠之中，这确实显得软弱和自私。他感觉自己好像突然从沉思的梦中惊醒，再也无法入睡。过了一会儿，他坐了起来，慢慢地问道：“你认为乔会像你一样鄙视我吗？”

‘Yes, if she saw you now. She hates lazy people. Why don’t you do something splendid, and make her love you?’
“是的，如果她现在看到你的话。”她讨厌懒惰的人。你为什么不做一些出色的事情，让她爱你呢？

‘I did my best, but it was no use.’
“我已经尽力了，但没有用。”

‘Graduating well, you mean? That was no more than you ought to have done, for your grandfather’s sake. It would have been shameful to fail after spending so much time and money, when everyone knew that you could do well.’
‘你的意思是，顺利毕业？为了你祖父的缘故，这不过是你应该做的。当每个人都知道你可以做得很好时，花费了这么多时间和金钱之后却失败了，那将是可耻的。”

‘I did fail, say what you will, for Jo wouldn’t love me,’
“无论你怎么说，我确实失败了，因为乔不会爱我。”

began Laurie, leaning his head on his hand in a despondent attitude.
劳里开口说道，他把头靠在手上，一副沮丧的样子。

‘No, you didn’t, and you’ll say so in the end, for it did you good, and proved that you could do something if you tried. If you’d only set about another task of some sort, you’d soon be your hearty, happy self again, and forget your trouble.’
‘不，你没有，最后你会这么说，因为这对你有好处，并证明如果你尝试的话你可以做一些事情。如果你只着手去做另一项任务，你很快就会再次变得热情、快乐，并忘记你的烦恼。

‘That’s impossible.’
'这不可能。'

‘Try it and see. You needn’t shrug your shoulders, and think, ‘Much she knows about such things’. I don’t pretend to be wise, but I am observing, and I see a great deal more than you’d imagine. I’m interested in other people’s experiences and inconsistencies, and though I can’t explain, I remember and use them for my own benefit. Love Jo all your days, if you choose, but don’t let it spoil you, for it’s wicked to throw away so many good gifts because you can’t have the one you want. There, I won’t lecture any more, for I know you’ll wake up and be a man in spite of that hardhearted girl.’
‘试试看吧。你不必耸耸肩，想，“她对这些事情了解很多”。我并不假装聪明，但我在观察，而且我看到的东西比你想象的要多得多。我对其他人的经历和不一致之处很感兴趣，虽然我无法解释，但我会记住并利用它们来为自己谋取利益。如果你愿意的话，一生一世地爱乔，但不要让它毁了你，因为因为得不到你想要的一件而扔掉这么多好礼物是邪恶的。在那里，我不会再讲课了，因为我知道你会醒来并成为一个男人，尽管有那个铁石心肠的女孩。

Neither spoke for several minutes. Laurie sat turning the little ring on his finger, and Amy put the last touches to the hasty sketch she had been working at while she talked. Presently she put it on his knee, merely saying, ‘How do you like that?’
双方都没有说话几分钟。劳里坐在那儿转动手指上的小戒指，艾米对她一边说话一边草草写下的草图进行了最后的润色。不久，她把它放在他的膝盖上，只是说：“你觉得怎么样？”

He looked and then he smiled, as he could not well help doing, for it was capitally done, the long, lazy figure on the grass, with listless face, half-shut eyes, and one hand holding a cigar, from which came the little wreath of smoke that encircled the dreamer’s head.
他看了看，然后笑了，他情不自禁地笑了，因为这件事做得太棒了，草地上那个懒洋洋的长身影，表情无精打采，半闭着眼睛，一只手拿着一支雪茄，从雪茄中传来了做梦者的头周围环绕着一圈烟雾。

‘How well you draw!’ he said, with a genuine surprise and pleasure at her skill, adding, with a half-laugh, ‘Yes, that’s me.’
“你画得多好！”他说，对她的技巧感到由衷的惊讶和高兴，半笑着补充道，“是的，那就是我。”

‘As you are. This is as you were.’ And Amy laid another sketch beside the one he held.
'就像你一样。这就是你原来的样子。”艾米在他拿着的草图旁边放了另一张草图。

It was not nearly so well done, but there was a life and spirit in it which atoned for many faults, and it recalled the past so vividly that a sudden change swept over the young man’s face as he looked. Only a rough sketch of Laurie taming a horse. Hat and coat were off, and every line of the active figure, resolute face, and commanding attitude was full of energy and meaning. The handsome brute, just subdued, stood arching his neck under the tightly drawn rein, with one foot impatiently pawing the ground, and ears pricked up as if listening for the voice that had mastered him. In the ruffled mane. The rider’s breezy hair and erect attitude, there was a suggestion of suddenly arrested motion, of strength, courage, and youthful buoyancy that contrasted sharply with the supine grace of the ‘DOLCE FAR NIENTE’ sketch. Laurie said nothing but as his eye went from one to the other, Amy say him flush up and fold his lips together as if he read and accepted the little lesson she had given him. That satisfied her, and without waiting for him to speak, she said, in her sprightly way...
虽然做得不太好，但里面有一种生命和精神，可以弥补许多过失，而且它对过去的回忆如此生动，以至于年轻人的脸上突然发生了变化。只有劳里驯马的粗略草图。帽子和外套都脱掉了，活跃的身材、坚毅的面容、威严的姿态，每一处线条都充满了活力和意义。英俊的畜生刚刚被制服，在紧紧勒住的缰绳下拱起脖子，一只脚不耐烦地刨着地面，竖起耳朵，仿佛在倾听控制他的声音。在皱褶的鬃毛里。骑手轻柔的头发和挺拔的姿势，给人一种突然停止的动作、力量、勇气和青春活力的暗示，与“DOLCE FAR NIENTE”草图中仰卧的优雅形成鲜明对比。劳里一言不发，但当他的目光从一只移到另一只时，艾米说他脸红了，双唇合拢，好像他读到并接受了她给他的这一点教训。这让她很满意，不等他说话，她就轻快地说道……

‘Don’t you remember the day you played Rarey with Puck, and we all looked on? Meg and Beth were frightened, but Jo clapped and pranced, and I sat on the fence and drew you. I found that sketch in my portfolio the other day, touched it up, and kept it to show you.’
“你不记得那天你和帕克一起打雷里，我们都在旁边看着吗？”梅格和贝丝很害怕，但乔一边拍手一边跳跃，我则坐在栅栏上吸引你。前几天我在我的作品集中发现了那张草图，对其进行了润色，然后保留下来给你看。

‘Much obliged. You’ve improved immensely since then, and I congratulate you. May I venture to suggest in ‘ a honeymoon paradise’ that five o’clock is the dinner hour at your hotel?’
'多谢。从那时起你已经有了很大的进步，我祝贺你。我可以冒昧地建议，在“蜜月天堂”中，五点钟是您酒店的晚餐时间吗？

Laurie rose as he spoke, returned the pictures with a smile and a bow and looked at his watch, as if to remind her that even moral lectures should have an end. He tried to resume his former easy, indifferent air, but it was an affectation now, for the rousing had been more effacious than he would confess. Amy felt the shade of coldness in his manner, and said to herself . ..
劳里一边说一边站了起来，微笑着鞠躬归还照片，然后看了看手表，仿佛在提醒她，即使是道德讲座也应该结束。他试图恢复以前轻松、冷漠的神情，但现在那是一种做作，因为这种兴奋比他承认的更有效。艾米感受到了他态度中的一丝冰冷，自言自语道。 ..

‘Now, I’ve offended him. Well, if it does him good, I’m glad, if it makes him hate me, I’m sorry, but it’s true, and I can’t take back a word of it.’
‘现在，我冒犯了他。好吧，如果这对他有好处，我很高兴，如果这让他恨我，我很抱歉，但这是事实，我无法收回一句话。

They laughed and chatted all the way home, and little Baptist, up behind, thought that monsieur and madamoiselle were in charming spirits. But both felt ill at ease.
